ExplntnTxt: Funds are provided to a related organization to allow that organization to fulfill its mission by funding its operating expenses. Goodwill Industries of Middle Georgia, Inc. provides certain oversight functions to the related entity.

UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT MEDICAL CENTER, INC. (UVM MEDICAL CENTER) REQUIRES ITS GRANTEES TO PROVIDE SEMI-ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS WITH PERCENTAGES COMPLETE AND RESULTS FOR EACH OF THE GRANTS AWARDED. SCHOLARSHIP MONITORING THE ORGANIZATION REQUIRES STRICT APPLICATION AND APPROVAL CRITERIA FOR SCHOLARSHIP RECIPIENTS TO MAINTAIN THE INTEGRITY OF EACH RESPECTIVE AWARD. NURSING SCHOLARSHIPS: NURSING SCHOOL ASSISTANCE IS AWARDED TO APPLICANTS IN ORDER FOR THEM TO OBTAIN A DEGREE IN NURSING. FOR THE APPLICANT TO QUALIFY FOR THE SCHOLARSHIP, HE/SHE MUST AGREE THAT THEY WILL USE IT TO HELP FURTHER UVM MEDICAL CENTER'S CHARITABLE STATUS. THIS IS DONE BY HAVING THE APPLICANT COMMIT TO TWO YEARS OF SERVICE AT THE ORGANIZATION AFTER SUCCESSFUL COMPLETION OF THE DEGREE PROGRAM. IN ADDITION, A WRITTEN PROPOSAL STATING HOW ATTAINMENT OF THE DEGREE WILL BENEFIT NURSING AT THE ORGANIZATION IS REQUIRED. ALLIED HEALTH SCHOLARSHIPS: ALLIED HEALTH SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO SUPPORT THE CAREER DEVELOPMENT OF UVM MEDICAL CENTER'S EMPLOYEES IN POSITION CATEGORIES WHERE CURRENT AND PROJECTED SHORTAGES EXIST. FOR THE APPLICANT TO QUALIFY FOR THE SCHOLARSHIP, HE OR SHE MUST BE AN EMPLOYEE OF UVM MEDICAL CENTER FOR ONE YEAR OR MORE, COMPLETE AN APPLICATION AND WRITTEN ESSAY, HAVE A HISTORY OF SOLID JOB PERFORMANCE, BE ACCEPTED INTO AN APPROVED ACADEMIC PROGRAM, AND PROVIDE TWO LETTERS OF RECOMMENDATION. ONCE THE SCHOLARSHIP IS AWARDED, RECIPIENTS MUST SIGN AN AGREEMENT TO WORK FOR UVM MEDICAL CENTER FOR A MINIMUM OF THREE YEARS UPON GRADUATION, TAKE A MINIMUM OF SIX CREDIT HOURS EACH SEMESTER, MAINTAIN HIGH GRADES, AND WORK A MINIMUM OF 20 HOURS PER WEEK. SCHOLARSHIPS FROM THE NURSING EDUCATION ENDOWMENT FUND AND THE MARY FLETCHER HOSPITAL SCHOOL OF NURSING ALUMNI FUND: ASSISTANCE FROM THE NURSING EDUCATION ENDOWMENT FUND IS AWARDED TO ELIGIBLE APPLICANTS GOING INTO THE NURSING FIELD. APPLICANTS MUST BE EMPLOYED AT LEAST TWO YEARS AT UVM MEDICAL CENTER, WORK AT LEAST 40 HOURS PER PAY PERIOD, BE ENROLLED IN A NURSING CERTIFICATE, DEGREE OR DOCTORATE PROGRAM, AND NO CURRENT DISCIPLINARY ACTION IN THEIR FILE. DECISION TO APPROVE FUNDING IS BASED ON THE APPLICANT'S COMPLETED APPLICATION FORM, TWO LETTERS OF RECOMMENDATION, AND COMMITMENT TO TWO YEARS OF SERVICE AT UVM MEDICAL CENTER AFTER SUCCESSFUL COMPLETION OF THE DEGREE PROGRAM. ASSISTANCE FROM THE MARY FLETCHER HOSPITAL SCHOOL OF NURSING ALUMNI FUND IS ALSO AWARDED TO ELIGIBLE APPLICANTS GOING INTO THE NURSING FIELD. APPLICANTS MUST BE ENROLLED IN EITHER A FORMAL OR CONTINUING EDUCATION PROGRAM RELATED TO SOME ASPECT OF HEALTH CARE (FOR EXAMPLE, HOLISTIC NURSING, CHILD-BIRTH EDUCATION, CHEMICAL DEPENDENCY, NURSE PRACTITIONER). IN ADDITION, APPLICANTS MUST MEET THE FOLLOWING REQUIREMENTS: BE EMPLOYED BY UVM MEDICAL CENTER FOR AT LEAST ONE YEAR, AND PROVIDE A COMPLETED APPLICATION FORM, RESUME, WRITTEN ESSAY AND TWO LETTERS OF RECOMMENDATION.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2: GRANT MONITORING PROCEDURES -
ExplntnTxt: The Financial Aid Director at each campus is given an amount that MAY be awarded at their campus for the fiscal year, with a chart of how many students and the amount for each term.
THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE DETERMINES STUDENT ELIGIBILITY FOR FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITUTIONAL SCHOLARSHIPS ACCORDING TO THE UNIVERSITY'S ESTABLISHED ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA AND REGULATIONS.
The college's Financial AId office follows all regulations when awarding grants and scholarships.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2, Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
ExplntnTxt: SCHOLARSHIPS ISSUED TO UNIVERSITY STUDENTS ARE APPLIED TO THE STUDENTS ACCOUNT. A LIST OF SCHOLARSHIP, FELLOWSHIP AND GRANT ASSISTANCE AWARDED IS ON FILE AT THE UNIVERSITY. ALTHOUGH THERE MAY BE RECIPIENTS WHO ARE RELATED TO PERSONS HAVING INTEREST IN THE UNIVERSITY, SUCH PERSONS ARE SELECTED ON AN EQUAL AND OBJECTIVE BASIS AS WITH OTHER RECIPIENTS. ALL STUDENTS RECEIVING ASSISTANCE ARE SELECTED ON THE UNIVERSITY'S CRITERIA FOR ACADEMIC AND FINANCIAL NEED, AND OTHER SIMILAR CRITERIA. THE UNIVERSITY DOES NOT DISCRIMINATE ON THE BASIS OF AGE, GENDER, ETHNIC OR RACIAL ORIGIN, PHYSICAL OR MENTAL DISABILITY, MARITAL OR VETERAN STATUS IN ADMINISTRATION OF SCHOLARSHIPS OR LOANS. ALSO, NOTE THAT THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES REMITTED TUITION TO QUALIFIED FACULTY, STAFF AND CERTAIN DEPENDENTS AS A BENEFIT OF EMPLOYMENT.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: THE UNIVERSITY ENSURES THAT SCHOLARSHIPS ARE USED FOR THEIR PROPER PURPOSE BY APPLYING THE AWARDED AMOUNT DIRECTLY AGAINST THE APPLICABLE STUDENT'S TUITION CHARGES.

THE ASSOCIATION ROUTINELY MAKES GRANTS TO ITS PARENT ORGANIZATION, JOHN JAY COLLEGE OF CRIMINAL JUSTICE, CHILDREN'S CENTER AND LIBRARY. NO GRANTS WERE MADE TO THE COLLEGE OR THE LIBRARY DURING THE FISCAL YEAR. ONLY THE CHILDREN'S CENTER RECEIVED ITS ANNUAL CONTRIBUTION. THESE MONIES ARE USED TO SUPPORT THE COLLEGE'S CHARITABLE MISSION. SINCE THE ASSOCIATION'S PRIMARY EXEMPT PURPOSE IS TO SUPPORT THE COLLEGE'S TAX-EXEMPT MISSION, IT IS NOT REQUIRED TO MONITOR THE USAGE OF THE FUNDS IT REMITS, AS IT IS GUARANTEED THAT THOSE FUNDS WILL BE USED TO SUPPORT STUDENT EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES.

APPLICATIONS FOR GRANTS ARE REVIEWED AND APPROVED BASED ON PREDETERMINED CRITERIA. THE PROJECTS AND PROGRAMS ARE MONITORED BY INTERNATIONAL TEAMS FIELD STAFF TO ENSURE FUNDS ARE USED IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE GRANT'S STATED PURPOSE. PERIODIC REPORTING, AS SPECIFIED IN THE GRANT AGREEMENT, IS REQUIRED.
Current student financial aid records are verified and compared with eligibility requirements before grants are awarded.

MERIT AND ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS BASED ON PREVIOUS AND CURRENT ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT. OTHER INTERNAL AND ENDOWED SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS BASED ON CRITERIA SPECIFIC TO THE SCHOLARSHIP. SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED ARE MONITORED BY THE FINANCIAL AID AND THE FINANCE OFFICE OF THE COLLEGE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: ALL AWARDS TO STUDENTS ARE MAINTAINED IN THE UNIVERSITYS FINANCIAL AID SOFTWARE. DOCUMENTATION REGARDING ELIGIBILITY IS MAINTAINED IN EACH STUDENTS FILE. CRITERIA FOR INSTITUTIONAL AID IS DETERMINED BY THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT AND VARIOUS COMMITTEES. ALSO, MANY INSTITUTIONAL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE DONOR-FUNDED AND CONTAIN ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA SPECIFIED BY THE DONOR.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: The University enters into their computer system (POISE), as budgeted amounts, the amounts that the Department of Education has allocated to be awarded to eligible students. The Financial Aid Department prints out a fund report from POISE that shows the budget amount, how much has been awarded, and how much is available to be awarded. Then the Financial Aid Department awards to each student who has applied for financial aid and meets the University's qualifications, State, and federal guidelines for financial aid the amount that the student is eligible to receive. The amounts that the student receives are credited to their account at the University, then the University automatically deducts tuition, books, and University fees. If there is a balance remaining, it is then refunded to the student. The Financial Aid Department is audited each year by independent certified public accountants.

SCHOLARSHIP AMOUNTS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS AFTER A THOROUGH REVIEW OF ELIGIBILITY AND SELECTION CRITERIA. THE UNIVERSITY HAS AN EXPERIENCED FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT THAT MONITORS THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS.

The Vice President for Finance collects grant award letters and instructions from the granting agencies or the BCU grant managers. The Vice President for Finance keeps a fiscal file for each grant, including award letters, instructions, annual accounting records, and financial reports submitted to the grantors. Either the Vice President for Finance or the grant manager submits reports to agencies, depending on the grant. The Vice President for Finance creates a budget for each grant in the grants fund, based on award letters and input from the BCU grant managers. If the grant allows, grant managers may request budget transfers within their grant, which the Vice President for Finance or the Assistant Vice President for Finance enter in Datatel. The grant manager signs off on expenditures for the grant. The Vice President for Finance reviews all grant expenditures monthly, with more in-depth review as needed for reporting grantors. The Vice President for Finance reconciles grant expenditures annually, for both the BCU fiscal year and the grant fiscal year if different. Financial aid grants are approved and reported by the Financial Aid department. Checks for grant revenues are received in the Business Office; some agencies mail them to the grant managers, who then turn them into the Business Office for deposit. Some agencies pay BCU through direct deposit into BCU checking accounts. The Vice President for Finance draws down federal grant funds electronically through the online G5 system; drawdowns are usually done monthly.

SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS ARE MONITORED COLLABORATIVELY BY THE OFFICE OF THE REGISTRAR, OFFICE OF THE BURSAR, FINANCIAL PLANNING, AND THE ACCOUNTING OFFICE TO VERIFY ELIGIBILITY, APPROPRIATE SELECTION CRITERIA AND APPLICATION OF SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS. FUNDS ARE CREDITED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS.
THESE GRANT FUNDS ARE ALL FOR STUDENTS IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND IS MONITORED BY THE STUDENT FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT AND IS AUDITED FOR COMPLIANCE EACH YEAR AND REPORTED ON A-133 AUDIT REPORT.

SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED TO ENROLLED STUDENTS ARE CREDITED TO THE STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS TO COVER TUITION AND FEES. GRADE REPORTS ARE GENERATED FOR EACH TERM, AND EACH INDIVIDUAL STUDENT IS REVIEWED TO ENSURE THEY ARE MAKING SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS TO MAINTAIN THEIR GRANT/SCHOLARSHIP FUNDING. ALSO, FINANCIAL AID RUNS ENROLLMENT REPORTS EACH TERM TO CHECK THE NUMBER OF CREDIT HOURS FOR EACH STUDENT.

The Director of Financial Aid reviews each endowment scholarship award criteria and awards scholarships based on donor intent. Merit scholarships are awarded by the Director of Financial Aid based on a review of the ACT scores and incoming GPA.

STUDENTS ARE REQUIRED TO COMPLETE A FAFSA. ELIGIBILITY FOR SCHOLARSHIPS IS DETERMINED BY THE APPLICABLE FEDERAL AND STATE GUIDELINES, BY THEIR ACADEMIC CREDENTIALS, AND FINANCIAL NEED. STUDENTS ARE APPROPRIATELY AWARDED SCHOLARSHIPS IN THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AND THE AWARDS ARE TRANSFERRED TO THE STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS IN THE BUSINESS OFFICE. ALL SCHOLARSHIP AND GRANT FUNDS ARE RECONCILED EACH SEMESTER AND REPORTED TO THE APPROPRIATE AUTHORITIES OR AGENCIES. FUNDS ARE ALSO AUDITED ANNUALLY.

ALL UNIVERSITY STUDENTS ARE CONSIDERED FOR GRANTS AND/OR ASSISTANCE. THE UNIVERSITY'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE EVALUATES EACH STUDENT'S FINANCIAL NEED BASED UPON INFORMATION PROVIDED ON THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA). FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MANAGEMENT AWARD MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS WHO QUALIFY BASED UPON DONOR STIPULATIONS AND AWARD FEDERAL, STATE, AND PRIVATE NEED-BASED AWARDS BASED ON FEDERAL OR OTHER GUIDELINES. STUDENTS RECEIVING AWARDS PROVIDE INFORMATION AND PARTICIPATE IN INTERVIEWS TO ENSURE THAT GUIDELINES AND RESIDENCY RULES AND REGULATIONS ARE MET.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2, Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
ExplntnTxt: ALL STUDENT SCHOLARSHIPS, GRANTS, OR OTHER ASSISTANCE ARE MONITORED THROUGHOUT THE AWARD, ACCEPTANCE, AND APPLICATION PROCESSES. APPROPRIATE RECORDS ARE MAINTAINED AND DOCUMENTED.

Students qualify for federal, state, and institutional scholarships, grants, and loans based on their individual FAFSA application. Merit awards are based on levels of achievement academically, musically, or artistically. Entitlement grants are given for students with a family connection to the College, denominational affiliation, and travel grants for students traveling a long distance from campus. International students may be awarded grants and scholarships to come to our campus to study. Grants are awarded by the financial aid office following federal, state, and institutional guidelines, which are also monitored and applied in the business office. Funds are audited annually by independent auditors.
SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BY THE SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE ACCORDING TO THE SCHOLARSHIP POLICIES IN PLACE AT THE COLLEGE.

THE SCHOOL HAS FELLOWSHIP RECIPIENTS SIGN THE AWARD LETTER TO ACCEPT CONDITIONS OF THE FELLOWSHIP, INCLUDING THE CONDITION THAT RECIPIENTS PARTICIPATE IN AN EXIT INTERVIEW WITH THE SCHOOL'S STAFF WITHIN SIX MONTHS AFTER CARRYING OUT THEIR FELLOWSHIP SERVICE.

Monitoring the Use of Grants Nyack College grants funds to students in the form of scholarships, student loans as well as other financial aid. Financial Aid is granted to students based on eligibility guidelines as defined by the Federal Department of Education, the State of New York, and Nyack College Scholarship Grant Program. Nyack College grants funds to students in the form of institutional aid based on merit, need and other specific criteria as outlined in Nyacks Scholarship and Grant Program.

ALL FUNDS ARE AWARDED THROUGH THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AND POSTED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS BY THE STUDENT ACCOUNTS OFFICE. STUDENTS MAY BE AWARDED GRANT FUNDS ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT AND/OR FINANCIAL NEED. IN EACH CASE THE STUDENT CAN RETAIN ELIGIBILITY FOR FUNDING FOR AS MANY AS EIGHT SEMESTERS AS A FULL-TIME STUDENT, PROVIDED THE STUDENT MEETS THE RENEWAL CRITERIA SUCH AS GRADE POINT AVERAGE AND GRADE PROCESSION AS OUTLINED IN THE STUDENT HANDBOOK. AN INDIVIDUAL STUDENT MAY NOT RECEIVE MORE THAN THE COST OF TUITION FROM THE INSTITUTIONAL GRANT FUNDS. A RECONCILIATION IS DONE REGULARLY BETWEEN THE TWO DEPARTMENTS/SYSTEMS TO ENSURE ACCURACY AND PROPER USE OF THE FUNDS. IN ADDITION, AN ANNUAL AUDIT IS PERFORMED BY AN OUTSIDE ACCOUNTING FIRM TO REVIEW COMPLIANCE WITH ALL FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITUTIONAL POLICIES AND PROCEDURES.

QUESTION 2 FUNDS ARE DISTRIBUTED BASED ON NEED AND MERIT. STUDENT AID IS HANDLED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AND STUDENT ACCOUNTING AND CREDITED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT ACCOUNT. EACH STUDENT APPLIES FOR FINANCIAL AID BY FILLING OUT A FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA). THE AWARD IS BASED ON THE INFORMATION IN THIS APPLICATION. STUDENTS CAN ALSO APPLY FOR GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON ELIGIBILITY.

THE GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED BY CLEARY UNIVERSITY ARE USED TO PAY TUITION AND FEE CHARGES ON STUDENT ACCOUNTS. THE UNIVERSITY IS ABLE TO MONITOR WHETHER RECIPIENTS REMAIN STUDENTS AT THE UNIVERSITY THROUGH THE REGISTRAR'S OFFICE, AND CLASS ATTENDANCE TAKEN BY PROFESSORS.

GRANTS PAID TO OTHER ORGANIZATIONS OR GOVERNMENTS ARE MONITORED AND IN COMPLIANCE WITH THE REQUIREMENTS OF LAWS, REGULATIONS, CONTRACTS AND GRANTS APPLICABLE TO EACH PROGRAM WITH STANDARDS SET FORTH IN OMB CIRCULAR A-133. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE GRANTS TO STUDENTS AND ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT BY THE UNIVERSITY.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: MARTIN UNIVERSITY ONLY AWARDS INSTITUTIONAL AND PRIVATELY FUNDED FINANCIAL AID AWARDS AS ASSISTANCE FOR STUDENTS BASED ON A CASE BY CASE BASIS, BASED ON MERIT AND NEED. IN DOING SO, THE UNIVERSITY'S FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT ADHERES STRICTLY TO ALL FEDERAL AND STATE REGULATIONS AND IS SUBJECT TO THE COMPLIANCE AND INTERNAL CONTROL REQUIREMENTS OF OMB CIRCULAR A-133.

UNIVERSITY OF PIKEVILLE MONITORS THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS BY ENTERING EACH STUDENT AND THEIR INSTITUTIONAL SCHOLARSHIP ON THE UNIVERSITY'S ACCOUNTING SOFTWARE, DATATEL. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE GRANTED BASED ON CRITERIA SET FORTH BY THE UNIVERSITY ADMINISTRATION AND FINANCIAL AID OFFICE.

Boricua College Scholarships are only awarded to students that attend the College and are reviewed annually for compliance and need by the School committee that oversees the selection process. Criteria for Eligibility and Selection: Academic Excellence: A student must be in good academic standing and should have acquired 12-15 credits per term with acceptable G.P.A. Financial Need: This is a Non Need-Based Fund therefore distribution of funds will be determined based on tuition costs after all conventional financial sources have been exhausted. Procedure: The College will notify the student of the intended award. If student accepts the award, the students account is credited via a financial aid award letter. Priority: Preference may be given to students: 1.In Bachelors and Masters Programs. 2.Who may have exhausted all conventional SFA award eligibility. 3.Determined ineligible based on SFA agencies conventional methodology 4.With recommendations from academic administrators and Faculty Facilitators.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS
ExplntnTxt: PART I, LINE 2 MARYVILLE UNIVERSITY USES FINANCIAL AID COMPUTER SOFTWARE THAT PROVIDES ALL DETAILS OF FINANCIAL AID AWARDS TO RECIPIENTS TO INCLUDE ANNUAL AND CUMULATIVE AMOUNTS AND ELIGIBILITY. ALL GRANTS IN AID ARE POSTED AS A CREDIT TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS.

POEC gives need-based and merit-based scholarships. Need-based scholarships are monitored through the Department of Education FAFSA form. Students with $0 estimated family contribution (EFC), based on the Department of Education guidelines, will be automatically awarded a scholarship. Merit-based scholarships are granted to students who submit all required admissions documentation by certain deadlines and apply with good academic standing.

The Chicago School - California, Inc. gives need-based and merit-based scholarships. Need-based scholarships are monitored through the Department of Education FAFSA form. Students with $0 estimated family contribution (EFC), based on the Department of Education guidelines, will be automatically awarded a scholarship. Merit-based scholarships are granted to students who submit all required admission documentation by certain deadlines and apply with a 4.0 undergraduate GPA or GRE score of 1,300. The Chicago School and its partners award fellowships to students who contribute to the academic community in and outside the classroom. Fellowship recipients dedicate 10 to 15 hours a week of work to the specific department through which the fellowship is offered. Applicants are judged on their ability to demonstrate a commitment to learning, developing, and participating in the programmatic, research, and administrative activities within the department or office.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2, Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
ExplntnTxt: THE COLLEGE'S RECEIVES GRANT FUNDS FROM THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION THROUGH THE TITLE III AND IV PROGRAMS. THE COLLEGE AWARDS FEDERAL FINANCIAL AID TO STUDENTS BASED ON ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA SPECIFIED BY FEDERAL REGULATIONS. THE COLLEGE HAS SOPHISTICATED INTERNAL PROCESSES TO DETERMINE A STUDENT'S ELIGIBILITY FOR FEDERAL FINANCIAL AID, AND TO MONITOR COMPLIANCE.

The Chicago School - Washington, D.C., Inc. gives need-based and merit-based scholarships. Need-based scholarships are monitored through the Department of Education FAFSA form. Students with $0 estimated family contribution (EFC), based on the Department of Education guidelines, will be automatically awarded a scholarship. Merit-based scholarships are granted to students who submit all required admission documentation by certain deadlines and apply with a 4.0 undergraduate GPA or GRE score of 1,300. The Chicago School and its partners award fellowships to students who contribute to the academic community in and outside the classroom. Fellowship recipients dedicate 10 to 15 hours a week of work to the specific department through which the fellowship is offered. Applicants are judged on their ability to demonstrate a commitment to learning, developing, and participating in the programmatic, research, and adminstrative activities within the department or office.

GRANTS GIVEN TO OTHER ORGANIZATIONS ARE TO FURTHER EDUCATION, HEALTHCARE AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT IN THE AREAS SURROUNDING THE ORGANIZATION. ALL GRANTS ARE GIVEN TO ORGANIZATIONS WITH BOARDS CONSISTING OF CIVIC, PHILANTHROPIC AND BUSINESS LEADERS WHO MONITOR THE USE OF GRANTS AND ENSURE THEY'RE USED FOR PROPER PURPOSES. SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TOWARDS THE STUDENTS ACCOUNTS TO OFFSET TUITION COSTS TO ENSURE THAT SCHOLARSHIPS ARE USED ONLY FOR STUDENT EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES.

Santa Barbara & Ventura Colleges of Law provides scholarships to new and continuing students. These scholarships are dependent upon factors such as alumni recommendations, academic standing, and other criteria related to admission/participation in the program. Santa Barbara & Ventura Colleges of Law maintains records of the scholarship award amounts, evidence of good academic standing and criteria for scholarship selection.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: DESCRIPTION FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE UNITED STATES
ExplntnTxt: SCHEDULE I, PART I, QUESTION 2 The College provides scholarships to students matriculating at the College. Certain criteria are established that each student is required to meet to retain their scholarship. The College does not need to monitor the use of scholarship funds as those amounts are directly spent to defray the cost of tuition. There is no opportunity for the funds to be directed to another purpose.
The organization reviews that grant funds are used for their intended purposes regularly.

THE COLLEGE FIRST INSPECTS CHARGES TO ENSURE THAT THEY ARE APPROPRIATE AND ALLOWABLE. THIS INCLUDES CHECKING CLERICAL ACCURACY, REVIEWING ENCUMBRANCE BALANCES, AND CHECKING COMPLIANCE WITH APPLICABLE AGENCY AND FEDERAL GUIDELINES. THE COLLEGE ALSO MAKES SURE THAT EXPENSE FALLS WITHIN THE REQUIRED CATEGORIES AND BUDGET AMOUNTS. THIS INCLUDES REVIEWING EXPENSE CATEGORIES, REBUDGETING, OR TRANSFERRING EXPENSES AS NEEDED, AND DETERMINING IF THE AWARD WILL BE UNDER SPENT AT THE END OF THE BUDGET OR PROJECT PERIOD.
SCHOLARSHIPS ARE MONITORED THROUGH THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE, TO ENSURE THAT ALL SCHOLARSHIP MONIES ARE USED FOR HOUSING, TUITION, MEALS AND BOOKS.

The Chicago School of Professional Psychology gives need-based and merit-based scholarships. Need-based scholarships are monitored through the Department of Education FAFSA form. Students With $0 estimated family contribution (EFC), based on the Department of Education guidelines, will be automatically awarded a need-based scholarship. Merit-based scholarships are granted to students who submit all required admissions documentation by certain deadlines and apply with a 4.0 undergraduate GPA or GRE score of 1300. The Chicago School and its partners award fellowships to students who contribute to the academic community in and outside the classroom. Fellowship recipients dedicate 10 to 15 hours a week of work to the specific department through which the fellowship is offered. Applicants are judged on their ability to demonstrate a commitment to learning, developing, and participating in the programmatic, research, and administrative activities within the department office.

The College awards merit-based scholarships to incoming freshmen as well as continuing students. Scholarships awarded to freshmen are determined by the admissions committee. Eligibility for these scholarships is determined through a combination of undergraduate cumulative science GPA, ranking of the college attended and the score achieved on the MCAT, a standardized medical school admissions test. For continuing students, the top five students with a cumulative GPA of 3.7 or higher for each grade, 2nd, 3rd, and 4th year students, receive these scholarships.

PRE-AWARD SUBRECIPIENT MONITOR: Federal awards are identified by informing each subrecipient of CFDA title and number, award name and number, award year, and name of Federal agency. If any of this information is not available, the pass-through entity shall provide the best information available to describe the Federal award. The subrecipient is advised of requirements imposed by governing laws, regulations, and provisions of contracts or grant agreements and supplemental requirements imposed by the pass-through entity. The subrecipient's activities are monitored to ensure awards are used for authorized purposes in compliance with laws, regulations, and the provisions of contracts or grant agreements and performance goals are achieved. Assurance is ascertained that any subrecipient expending $500,000 or more in Federal awards during the subrecipient's fiscal year must meet the audit requirements of OMB A-133. A management decision on audit findings must be issued within six months after receipt of the subrecipient's audit report and management must follow up to ensure that the subrecipient takes appropriate and timely corrective action. A determination is made as to whether subrecipient audits necessitate adjustment of the pass-through entity's own records. Each subrecipient is required to permit the pass-through entity and auditors to have access to the records and financial statements as necessary for the pass-through entity to comply with this part. POST-AWARD SUBRECIPIENT MONITORING: The Principal Investigator (PI) or Program Director (PD) is responsible for monitoring the activities. The subrecipient should submit progress reports, technical reports and other deliverables to the PI/PD by specified due dates. The PI/PD is responsible for forwarding copies of the subrecipient's report(s) to the Office of Research and Sponsored Programs (ORSP). Subrecipient invoices submitted to the university must contain the following information: invoice must be on subcontractor's letterhead, date of invoice, invoice number, period of performance covered by the invoice, itemized description of services and backup documentation, current period costs, including cost sharing, cumulative project costs, including cost sharing, subrecipient contact person with respect to invoice, invoice must be signed by an authorized official of the subcontractor, invoice must contain a certification that all payments requested are for appropriate purposes and in accordance with the agreements set forth in the application and award documents. The PI/PD is responsible for reviewing and approving invoices from subrecipient(s) for adherence to the budget. The signature of the PI/PD on the invoice indicates that the review has taken place and that the invoice adheres to budget. Grant Accounting will review the subrecipient's invoice(s) for the following: period of performance is within the contract period, appropriate invoice format and level of detail, signatures of the PI/PD, certification of signature by authorized subrecipient representatives, funds are available in contract, and cost share documentation is provide, if applicable. Grant Accounting is responsible for ensuring that subrecipients that expend $500,000 or more of federal funds each fiscal year submit an A133 Audit Certification Letter. The following is required to close out a subrecipient award: receipt of final invoice, receipt of cost share documentation, if applicable, time and effort certifications, final progress and technical reports, annual A133 certification letter. Grant Accounting is responsible for tracking payments made to individuals or organizations where payments are made when out of the US as required by the Schedules F and I - Form 990." EDUCATIONAL ASSISTANCE: Educational assistance is awarded based on financial need and merit. Need based assistance is awarded after review of the student's FAFSA, tax return transcripts, W-2 statements, and other relevant financial documents. Students are required to maintain satisfactory academic progress in order to continue to be eligible for need based assistance. Students' Grade Point Averages and earned units are reviewed each academic year to ensure satisfactory academic progress is achieved. Merit based educational assistance is awarded to students via Committee. Students who are awarded merit based assistance are required to maintain satisfactory academic progress in accordance with the terms of the assistance received. Need and merit based educational assistance are funded directly to the student's accounts receivable balance to offset tuition, fees, and room and board. Any resulting refunds are issued to the student. Students are granted research awards by their academic departments and work with faculty advisors who monitor the research performed by the student.

THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION MONITORS THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS BY ADHERING TO SPECIFIC POLICIES AND PROCEDURES TO ENSURE THAT GRANT FUNDS ARE BEING USED FOR AUTHORIZED PURPOSES AND AS REQUIRED BY THE GRANT AGREEMENT AND APPLICABLE REGULATIONS. SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO THE UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS BASED UPON VARIOUS SETS OF CRITERIA ESTABLISHED BY THE RESTRICTED PROJECTS AND BY TYPE OF AWARDS LISTED IN THE CUNY CATALOGUE. STUDENTS MUST SUBMIT THEIR FAFSA FEDERAL FORM TO DOCUMENT THEIR NEED FOR FEDERAL FINANCIAL AID. THE UNIVERSITY OFFERS SEVERAL TYPES OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BY THE SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE UPON ADMISSION BASED ON APPLICATION AND ESSAY SUBMISSION. THE SCHOLARSHIPS MAY BE ONE TIME OR RECUR EACH QUARTER, DEPENDING ON THE TYPE OF SCHOLARSHIP. THE ADMISSIONS DEPARTMENT MONITORS APPLICATIONS AND AWARDS, AND THE FINANCIAL SERVICES OFFICE, IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE REGISTRAR, MONITORS QUARTERLY ELIGIBILITY OF RECURRING SCHOLARSHIPS. Within the limits of available resources, the College makes every effort to make financial aid opportunities available to needy and academically eligible students. Traditional-age students must be enrolled in a full-time undergraduate degree program to be considered for College academic scholarships, grants and/or need-based financial aid. With the exception of some academic scholarships, students who wish to apply for grants, loans, or work-study should submit the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA). Awards are considered on the basis of financial need and/or a student's academic profile. Awards are packaged using a combination of grants and scholarships, loans and work-study assignments. Students must be in good academic and social standing and achieve the minimum standards of academic progress. We use College Board's PowerFAIDS software to manage our financial aid database and awarding procedures.

(a)Non-funded Financial Aid is funded from the College's unrestricted resources. Funded Financial Aid consists of the calculated spending proceeds from endowed scholarships and gifts donated to help students pay for the cost of their education. Various state grants also provide scholarships to assist students with paying for their education.(b)98% of traditional students at the College received some form of Financial Aid. Therefore, the number of recipients was estimated by multiplying 98% by 2,004 or 1,964 students and then prorating 1,985 students to Non-funded and Funded aid.

Gordon College awards three types of grants/scholarships: merit scholarships, need-based grants and endowment funded restricted scholarships. Merit scholarships are awarded based on the incoming student's academic criteria determined by the Admissions Office. These scholarships are renewed annually by verification of the Registrar's Office that cumulative GPA requirements are met. Need-based grants are awarded based on the student's determined financial need. We determine financial need using information provided by the FAFSA. We practice level-funding of the need-based grants to future years unless there is a significant change in determined financial need. Endowment funded restricted scholarships are awarded based on criteria established by donors. The criteria information on specific eligible students is provided by the Registrar, Admissions and Financial Aid Offices. Students are evaluated annually to verify they continue to meet the donor criteria for an endowment award.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: THE GRANTS ARE SUBJECT TO FEDERAL REGULATIONS. THE ORGANIZATION HAS A MONITORING POLICY FOR THE GRANTS, WHEN THEY ARE AWARDED A BUDGET IS APPROVED ESTABLISHING THE ALLOWABLE EXPENSES UNDER THE GRANT. IN THE CASE THAT FUNDS WERE ASSIGNED TO ANOTHER PERSON OR ENTITY THROUGH SUBCONTRACTING, WE HAVE A WRITTEN POLICY ESTABLISHING HOW TO MONITOR THE AGREEMENT WITH THE OTHER ENTITY OR PERSON. ALONG THE MONITORING WE PERFORM, WE ENSURE THAT SUB-RECIPIENTS HAVE MET THE REQUIREMENTS TO PERFORM AN INDEPENDENT FINANCIAL AUDIT IN ACCORDANCE WITH OMB CIRCULAR A-133. UNDER THE AFOREMENTIONED STANDARDS THE SUB-RECIPIENT WILL NEED TO PROVIDE US A DOCUMENT INDICATING THAT THEY MEET THE REQUIREMENTS ESTABLISHED AND PROVIDE A COPY OF THE AUDITOR'S REPORT FROM SUCH A-133. WE ALSO PERFORM SITE VISITS, REQUIRE THE SUB-RECIPIENT TO SUBMIT REPORTS AMONG OTHER MONITORING TECHNIQUES WE ENFORCE IN ORDER TO MONITOR PERFORMANCE. FURTHERMORE, WE HAVE A COMPLIANCE OFFICE THAT APPROVES EVERY DISBURSEMENT AFTER VERIFYING THAT IT MEETS REGULATIONS. AFTERWARDS, THE BUDGET DEPARTMENT IS IN CHARGE OF APPROVING EXPENSES, ACCORDING TO THE PREVIOUSLY APPROVED BUDGET BY THE AGENCY THAT GRANTS THE FUNDS.

FIELDING GRADUATE UNIVERSITY AWARDS TUITION SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY AND ARE IMMEDIATELY APPLIED AGAINST THE STUDENT'S TUITION CHARGES. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MAINTAINS RECORDS TO SUBSTANTIATE THE AMOUNT OF THE GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE, THE GRANTEE'S ELIGIBILITY FOR THE GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE, AND THE SELECTION CRITERIA USED TO AWARD THE GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE. AID OFFICE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: THE PROCESS OF AWARDING STUDENT FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE WITHOUT EXCEEDING THE STUDENT'S FINANCIAL NEED IS TRADITIONALLY CALLED FINANCIAL AID PACKAGING. "NEED" IS DEFINED AS THE COST OF ATTENDANCE COA (TUITION, FEES, BOOKS, ROOM & BOARD, TRANSPORTATION, AND PERSONAL EXPENSES) MINUS THE EXPECTED FAMILY CONTRIBUTION EFC AS DETERMINED BY THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION NEED ANALYSIS FORMULAE. THE COORDINATION OF INSTITUTIONAL GRANT AID OCCURS SUBSEQUENT TO THE FEDERAL REGULATIONS REQUIREMENT THAT FEDERAL AND STATE GRANT AID AWARDS BE DETERMINED FIRST. A DETERMINATION OF AN INSTITUTIONAL "SCHOLARSHIP" AWARD IS BASED ON ACADEMIC MERIT (CUMULATIVE GRADE POINT AVERAGE) ACHIEVED IN HIGH SCHOOL OR A PREVIOUS COLLEGE. A DETERMINATION OF AN INSTITUTIONAL "GRANT" AWARD IS BASED ON "REMAINING NEED." A STUDENT MAY RECEIVE BOTH A MERIT AND NEED AWARD. ONE-HALF OF EACH AWARD IS PAID IN EACH OF TWO SEMESTERS, WHICH IS CALLED AN "ACADEMIC YEAR." ANNUAL AGGREGATE BUDGET MAXIMUMS ARE ESTABLISHED FOR EACH INSTITUTIONAL AID AWARD TITLE. ACTUAL AWARDS TO STUDENTS ARE MADE BY THE DIRECTOR OF FINANCIAL AID. THE DIRECTOR OF INSTITUTIONAL COMPLIANCE AND THE CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER MONITORS THE NUMBER OF, AND AMOUNTS OF, INSTITUTIONAL AID AWARDED TO ENROLLED STUDENTS ON A MONTHLY BASIS THROUGHOUT THE ACADEMIC YEAR. QUARTERLY STUDENT FILE REVIEWS ARE CONDUCTED TO ENSURE THAT ALL FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITUTIONAL AID AWARDS DO NOT EXCEED THE STUDENT'S INITIAL "NEED." ANY AWARD DETERMINED TO EXCEED NEED IS ADJUSTED IN THE SUBSEQUENT SEMESTER AS A CORRECTIVE ACTION. AT THE END OF THE ACADEMIC YEAR, A SUMMARY OF THE AWARDS AND EXPENDITURES MADE IS REVIEWED WITH THE VICE PRESIDENT FOR FINANCE AND THE PROVOST SO THAT MERIT OR NEED AID BUDGET ADJUSTMENTS, IF ANY, ARE IN PLACE FOR THE SUBSEQUENT ACADEMIC YEAR.

THE COLLEGE DOES NOT GIVE ANY NON-CASH SCHOLARSHIPS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE DISBURSED TO STUDENTS THROUGH CREDITING THEIR STUDENT ACCOUNTS. IF THE STUDENT HAS ANY EXCESS SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS OVER THEIR CHARGES, THESE FUNDS ARE DISBURSED TO THE STUDENT BY CHECK. THE COLLEGE'S PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING GRANT FUNDS IN THE U.S. ARE AS FOLLOWS: THE COLLEGE HAS APPOINTED DIRECTORS, WHO REPORT TO THE APPROPRIATE VICE PRESIDENTS, OVER ALL FEDERAL GRANT PROGRAMS. THESE DIRECTORS ARE CHARGED WITH PERFORMING ALL GRANT-RELATED ACTIVITIES INCLUDING APPLICATION, MONITORING OF EXPENDITURES AND REPORTING, WITH THE EXCEPTION OF DRAW-DOWNS OF FEDERAL FUNDS. DRAW-DOWNS ARE PERFORMED BY THE COLLEGE'S CONTROLLER AFTER REQUESTS ARE MADE BY THE DIRECTOR TO THE CONTROLLER. THE CONTROLLER REVIEWS THE REQUESTS FOR DRAW-DOWNS, WHICH INCLUDE DOCUMENTATION OF ALL DIRECT AND INDIRECT PROGRAM EXPENSES, BEFORE MAKING THE DRAW-DOWNS. A SINGLE AUDIT IS PERFORMED ANNUALLY BY THE COLLEGE'S INDEPENDENT AUDITORS.

Part I, Line 2 - E&H College maintains complete records for the grants and scholarships provided to all individuals. Those records indicate the criteria used to award the grants, documentation supporting the grantee's eligibility of the award, and substantiation of the amounts awarded. Documentation is also maintained as to when and how the funds are utilized. Where appropriate, periodic reports are prepared, summarizing the allocation of funds and a reconciliation of the amounts spent for each grant and scholarship. THE UNIVERSITY'S OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID, ADMINISTERS A WIDE VARIETY OF FEDERAL, STATE, INSTITUTIONAL AND PRIVATE FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS. ITS MAJOR OBJECTIVE IS THE EQUITABLE DISTRIBUTION OF FINANCIAL AID TO ALL STUDENTS. THE ORGANIZATION SERVICES IN ORDER TO HELP STUDENTS FINANCE THEIR EDUCATION. College financial aid is administered and awarded for students attending Roanoke College by the college's Financial Aid office.

All scholarships are awarded based upon specific criteria maintained by the financial aid office. Requirements for receiving scholarships depends on factors such as grade point average, family income, economic need or athletic talents. The Colleges financial aid staff monitors guidelines to ensure compliance.

Hillsdale College awards both scholarships and grants to its students. Students can receive a scholarship at matriculation in the form of merit or performance scholarship. Merit scholarship is awarded by committee based upon an incoming student's high school gpa, standardized test scores, and other, more subjective criteria such as community involvement, interviews, essays, letters of recommendation, and admissions rank. Performance scholarships are awarded by budget managers (typically coaches and fine arts chairs) based upon their own evaluations. Criteria for renewal of merit scholarships generally require students to maintain a 3.0 accumulative gpa. The Financial Aid Office polices this 3.0 requirement and any other scholarship criteria which may be attached to privately funded, named scholarships. Correspondence is sent to students at the end of each semester pertaining to their progress toward scholarship requirements. Students may become eligible for additional scholarship after their freshman year based upon classroom performance and campus involvement. These scholarship decisions are also made by committee after a review of scholarship budgets and criteria. With respect to grants, Hillsdale College students may become eligible for grant monies only by demonstrating significant need on Hillsdale College's Confidential Family Financial Statement (CFFS). All new applicants are required to submit a copy of the most recent signed tax information of parent(s) and student and any other necessary documents to complete verification of eligibility. This needs test must be resubmitted each year for renewal consideration and adjustments to amounts may be made based upon changes in demonstrated need. In addition to demonstrated financial need, grant recipients are required to meet academic standards of progress, exhibit good citizenship and moral character, and be enrolled at least half time. The Financial Aid Office monitors these additional components each semester using information provided by the Dean's Office and Registrar's Office. During fiscal year 2014, Hillsdale College awarded monetary grants/prizes to three educational institutions based on specified criteria. One prize recognizes one outstanding public or private school teacher with his/her school receiving the funds. The recipient is chosen among the teachers nationally who are implementing the ideas and curriculum contained in a comprehensive educational resource designed by Hillsdale College professors. The school is required to prepare an annual report on the expenditure(s) of the Prize until such funds are entirely expended. The other two grants supported the launch of K-12 charter schools which are based on a classical liberal arts model and which have a strong civics component which will equip students to understand and defend the principles of the American founding. The recipients are required to provide Hillsdale College documentation on the use of the funds in addition to on-site visits by Hillsdale College staff.

The College of Idaho uses a combination of federal methodology and instructional policy to provide a uniform method to assess a family's financial strength and the student's academic performance to estimate the expected family contribution toward the student's cost of education. The cost of education includes tuition, fees, books, supplies, room, board, personal expenses and transportation allowance.

All Federal financial aid administered by Barnard College is based on demonstrated financial need as determined by the Federal Methodology formula. However institutional aid is determined using a Barnard Need Analysis formula which takes into consideration all sources of income and all assets. Barnard does not provide merit scholarships. The College believes that the primary responsibility for financing educational cost rests with each student's family, and all college aid is supplementary to family resources. Once need has been established, Barnard makes every effort to meet the need of all eligible students with a combination of grants, loans and employment opportunities. A student who is admitted to Barnard with financial aid cannot be guaranteed college grants for future years. Awards are for one academic year only. A student can receive Barnard aid for a maximum of eight semesters. Each semester a student is enrolled is counted towards the eight semesters of eligibility whether or not aid was received. No financial aid is given for summer study. If a student has room in her academic year financial aid package and has not already borrowed the maximum loans, these funds may be borrowed during the academic year to be used for classes the following semester. For financial statement purposes, the Pell grant awards of $2,094,167 are excluded.
EMPLOYEE DESIGNATED TO MONITOR GRANTS ANNUALLY AND REPORT AND FOLLOW UP ON ANY FINDINGS.

FOR FEDERAL AND STATE FINANCIAL AID GRANTS, INDIVIDUAL FAFSA AND PERSONAL TAX RETURNS ARE VERIFIED FOR RECIPIENT ELIGIBILITY. The Colleges financial aid staff monitors guidelines to ensure compliance. The College also undergoes the required OMB A-133 audit annually.

FEDERAL AND INSTITUTIONAL GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED CONSISTENT WITH FEDERAL AND INSTITUTIONAL GUIDELINES. FEDERAL PROGRAMS ARE SUBJECT TO AN ANNUAL INDEDPENDENT AUDIT. THE SCHOOL'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICES MONITORS ALL RECIPIENTS OF SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS TO DETERMINE BOTH INITIAL AND CONTINUING ELIGIBILITY BASED UPON THE CRITERIA FOR EACH TYPE OF AWARD. VARIOUS CRITERIA MAY INCLUDE BUT IS NOT LIMITED TO, ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE, FINANCIAL NEED OR OTHER CRITERIA ESTABLISHED BY THE FUNDING SOURCE.

Financial Aid / Grants are awarded based on need (as evidenced by application and supporting documents), and provided based on supported (receipts) expenses for approved travel, books and health insurance. Stipends for meals are set by allowance.

PROCESS FOR MONITORING GRANTS Biola University awards both merit and need-based scholarships to students at the graduate and undergraduate levels. Merit awards are based on eligibility criteria such as academic, athletic, and music abilities. These typically have academic or participation requirements for renewal. Continued eligibility based on stated requirements is monitored by the Financial Aid office or by the office that makes the awards. Need-based awards are typically awarded based on specific formulas that are based on an institutional or federal cost amount combined with the federal EFC determined by the FAFSA. Continued eligibility is normally contingent on ongoing need in subsequent years. Most of the grants and scholarships awarded by Biola are funded from general funds; however, a portion are funded from restricted funds that have been provided by donors, and are awarded based on the eligibility criteria established by the donors. The Financial Aid office works closely with Accounting and Finance offices to monitor availability of funds from both the general fund and restricted fund accounts.

All scholarships are awarded based upon specific criteria maintained by the financial aid office. Requirements for receiving scholarships depend upon other factors, such as grade point average, family income or economic need. The Colleges financial aid staff monitors the eligibility guidelines to ensure compliance. The College also undergoes the required OMB A-133 audit annually.

HGST offers three scholarships for students currently enrolled at HGST and onY scholarship for new students. Scholarship recipients are selected on an annual basis and total award amounts are paid in two equal installments, one at the beginning of the fall semester and one at the beginning of the spring semester. For consideration, all interested students must submit the complete scholarship application prior to the application deadline. After the applications are received, the Scholarship Committee comprised of the Chief Operating/Financial Officer, Acting Academic Dean, and the Associate Dean, meet to review all the applications and determine the scholarship award recipients. Letters to all applicants are sent, both recipients and non-recipients. Scholarship awards are posted to the student financial accounts as described above. All recipients are required to send thank you notes to the scholarship funders before the awards can be posted.

THE COLLEGE'S PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS REQUIRES THE VERIFICATION OF 1) ENROLLMENT STATUS, 2) NUMBER OF HOURS ENROLLED, 3) NUMBER OF EARNED CREDIT HOURS, 4) GPA, AND 5) HOUSING STATUS. IN ADDITION, A REVIEW OF STUDENT ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE IS CONDUCTED EACH SEMESTER TO DETERMINE OVERALL STANDING IN RELATION TO THE COLLEGE'S ESTABLISHED SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC POLICY (SAP).

TRINITY PARTICIPATES IN THE FEDERAL TITLE IV FINANCIAL AID PROGRAMS, AND FOLLOWS THE PROCEDURES PRESCRIBED BY THE US DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION RELATED TO THE DISBURSEMENT OF TITLE IV FUNDS, INSTITUTIONAL AWARDS, AND SCHOLARSHIPS AND ASSISTANCE FROM OTHER SOURCES. THESE PROCEDURES INCLUDE ENSURING THAT STUDENTS COMPLETE A FAFSA EACH ACADEMIC YEAR, COMPLETING THE VERIFICATION REQUIREMENTS, CALCULATING SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS, AND ENSURING THAT STUDENTS WHO WITHDRAW OR STOP ATTENDING ARE REVIEWED AND HANDLED AS PRESCRIBED BY THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2, Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
ExplntnTxt: SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS CAN BE USED FOR TUITION, BOOKS AND LIVING EXPENSES. IN GENERAL THEY ARE APPLIED FIRST TO TUITION AND BALANCES SENT TO STUDENTS. IT IS REVIEWED EVERY SCHOOL TERM AND IS MONITORED IN COMPLIANCE WITH STUDENT AID PROTOCOLS. THE STUDENT LOAN PROGRAM IS AUDITED EVERY YEAR IN COMPLIANCE WITH FEDERAL SINGLE AUDIT STANDARDS
The grants are given to other 501 (c)(3) organizations that are related to the furtherance of the organization's exempt purpose. No other action is taken after distribution.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: Students' eligibility for grant funds are based on the information from their FAFSA and calculated by using federal methodology to determine their EFC.For Federal Grants (Pell and SEOG), we ensure that students are eligible and verify all financial or demographic information if necessary. Grant funds do not get posted to the students' accounts until the student has completed all necessary paperwork and has completed registration.State Grants are determined by the FAFSA information and usually an additional application processed directly with the participating state agency. A roster from the state is sent to us and we verify enrollment. We receive the funds and post to the students' accounts.Institutional grants are applied to the students' accounts based on eligibility and enrollment.All Grant funds are reconciled with the business office after each residency to ensure eligibility and disbursement.

CCA MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS THAT COMPLETE ADMISSION APPLICATION REQUIREMENTS BY THE PUBLISHED DEADLINE AND ARE BASED ON ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT AND PORTFOLIO REVIEW. NEED-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS WITH DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED AND ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT. RECIPIENTS OF NEED-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS AND SEOG FUNDS MUST COMPLETE A FAFSA APPLICATION, BE US CITIZENS OR ELIGIBLE NON-CITIZENS, AND BE ENROLLED FULL-TIME.

PRESBYTERIAN COLLEGE AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS, GRANTS, AND LOANS TO ITS STUDENTS. THE PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF THE FUNDS ARE PART OF THE COLLEGE FINANCIAL AID GUIDELINES AND THEY ARE UTILIZED TO DETERMINE THE QUALIFICATIONS OF THE RECIPIENT. THE GUIDELINES ARE PUBLISHED IN THE PRESBYTERIAN COLLEGE ACADEMIC CATALOG AND COMPLY WITH THE ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS PUBLISHED BY THE US DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION AND THE SC DEPARTMENT OF REVENUE. COMPLIANCE AUDITS ARE ALSO COMPLETED ANNUALLY BY AN INDEPENDENT ACCOUNTING FIRM. THE GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS.
Grants are administered through the Office of Financial Aid for all Federal, State and Institutional aid programs.

IONA COLLEGE GIVES AID TO STUDENTS IN TWO FORMS: MERIT AID AND NEEDS BASED AID. THE AMOUNT OF MERIT AID A STUDENT RECEIVES IS BASED ON A CALCULATED ACADEMIC INDEX THAT IS DERIVED FROM THEIR GPA & SAT SCORES. NEED BASED AID IS DETERMINED FROM THE STUDENT EFC. STUDENTS ARE GIVEN THESE AWARDS UPON ACCEPTANCE TO THE COLLEGE AND THE AWARDS ARE RENEWED ON AN ANNUAL BASIS ASSUMING THE STUDENT MEETS THE REQUIRED CUMULATIVE GPA AND THEIR NEED AS DETERMINED BY THE FAFSA HAS NOT CHANGED. ALL SCHOLARSHIPS ISSUED BY THE COLLEGE ARE INTENDED TO BE USED TO DEFRAY TUITION COSTS AND ENABLE STUDENTS TO MATRICULATE AT IONA COLLEGE, THE STUDENT HAS NO DISCRETION ON HOW TO EXPEND THOSE FUNDS. ACCORDINGLY, THE COLLEGE DOES NOT FORMALLY MONITOR THE USE OF THE SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS SINCE IT IS REQUIRED THAT SUCH FUNDS BE USED TO OFFSET TUITION COSTS.

ALL STUDENT AWARDS ARE MAINTAINED IN THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID SOFTWARE SYSTEM. FEDERAL AWARDS ARE BASED ON FINANCIAL AND OTHER DATA PROVIDED BY THE STUDENT AND VERIFIED, AS APPROPRIATE, BY THE COLLEGE. FEDERAL AWARDS ARE SUBJECT TO AN ANNUAL AUDIT BASED ON STANDARDS FOUND IN OMB CIRCULAR A-133 AND PERFORMED BY AN INDEPENDENT AUDITOR. SELECTION CRITERIA FOR DONOR-FUNDED SCHOLARSHIPS ARE MOSTLY DETERMINED BY THE DONOR AND IS AVAILABLE IN THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. SELECTION CRITERIA FOR FEDERAL AND STATE AID IS ALSO FOUND IN THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AND AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC ON THE INTERNET.
THE COLLEGE MAINTAINS RECORDS WITHIN ITS FINANCIAL AID SOFTWARE TO ACCOUNT FOR ALL GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED TO EACH STUDENT.

THE GRANTS MADE BY THE UNIVERSITY ARE PRIMARILY FOR STUDENT AID AND SCHOLARSHIPS. A LIST OF RECIPIENTS OF SCHOLARSHIPS IS ON FILE AT THE UNIVERSITY AND IS AVAILABLE UPON REQUEST. ALL STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS ARE JUDGED WORTHY BY THE UNIVERSITY ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC AND ATHLETIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED, AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS.

ORGANIZATIONS THAT RECEIVE GRANTS ARE PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS. THE UNIVERSITY'S STUDENTS GAIN PRACTICAL EXPERIENCE WHILE ASSISTING AT THESE ORGANIZATIONS. BECAUSE OF THIS CLOSE RELATIONSHIP, THE UNIVERSITY IS ABLE TO MONITOR THE USE OF THE FUNDS. The University applies scholarships directly to students' tuition accounts.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: THE COLLEGE FOLLOWS GUIDELINES SET FORTH BY THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION AND BY THE COLLEGE TO DETERMINE STUDENT ELIGIBILITY FOR SCHOLARSHIPS. STUDENTS QUALIFY FOR LINCOLN COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON VARIOUS CRITERIA INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, SCHOLARSHIP, EXTRA-CURRICULAR PARTICIPATION AND NEED. THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT HAS NUMEROUS POLICIES IN PLACE TO DETERMINE WHO RECEIVES, HOW THEY ARE ADMINISTERED, AND WHEN THE STUDENTS RECEIVE THE SCHOLARSHIPS.
THE COLLEGE RECONCILES GRANTS AWARDED AND DRAWDOWNS OF FUNDS. GRANT PROGRAMS ARE AUDITED BY INDEPENDENT AUDITORS DURING THE ANNUAL INDEPENDENT AUDIT.
THE COLLEGE MAINTAINS AN OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID, WHICH IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE MONITORING OF GRANT FUNDS AWARDED TO THE COLLEGE AND STUDENTS.

THE UNIVERSITY ISSUES GRANTS AND OTHER FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE TO STUDENTS, WHICH ALLOWS STUDENTS TO FURTHER THEIR EDUCATION. GRANTED FUNDS ARE CREDITED TO THE STUDENT'S UNIVERSITY BILLING ACCOUNT AND APPLIED TO TUITION, FEES, AND OTHER COSTS OF EDUCATION. IN FISCAL YEAR 2013-2014 THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDED DOMESTIC FINANCIAL AID TO SUPPORT 1325 STUDENTS.

The Office of Financial Aid administers the following policies to assure that institutional grants and scholarships are used for proper purposes: The aggregate of institutional funds that an individual student receives is restricted to an amount equivalent to tuition and fees; Enrollment is confirmed each semester prior to disbursement of institutional funds; Eligibility for academic scholarships is limited to a maximum of eight (8) semesters. Renewal grade point average requirements are checked at the end of each academic year; Eligibility for institutional general grants requires a demonstration of need based on submission of the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FASFA); Endowed scholarships have selection criteria specific to each fund and the Director of Financial Aid oversees the selection of eligible students; when a student withdraws from school, the percentage adjustments made to institutional aid are the same as the percentage adjustments made to tuition as specified in the catalog.

The College provides scholarships to students matriculating at the College based on need and/or merit. The College monitors students' files to ensure that the student receives necessary financial assistance based on grades, course of study and financial need. All funds granted are required to be used to defray the costs of attendance; funds may not be spent on discretionary items.
STUDENTS AWARDED WITH AN HONOR SCHOLARSHIP MUST BE PART OF THE UNIVERSITY'S HONOR PROGRAM
AND THIS PROGRAM HAS SPECIFIC REQUIREMENTS THAT THE STUDENTS MUST MEET EVERY
TRIMESTER IN ORDER TO RECEIVE THE SCHOLARSHIP.
STUDENTS AWARDED WITH AN ATHLETIC SCHOLARSHIP MUST MEET CERTAIN REQUIREMENTS
ESTABLISHED BY THE ATHLETIC DEPARTMENT. STUDENTS ARE SELECTED BY A COMMITTEE
PART OF THE VICE PRESIDENCY OF STUDENTS AFFAIRS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2, Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
ExplntnTxt: THE ORGANIZATION HAS RULES IN PLACE TO ENSURE THAT SCHOLARSHIP AID PROVIDED TO STUDENTS IS USED FOR AUTHORIZED PURPOSES. ADDITIONAL DETAIL IS AVAILABLE UPON REQUEST.

BETHANY LUTHERAN COLLEGE OFFERS SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS TO HELP REDUCE THEIR OUT-OF-POCKET TUITION COSTS. STUDENTS RECEIVING FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE OF THIS FORM MUST MEET SPECIFIC CRITERIA SUCH AS ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED, AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS WHETHER PUT IN PLACE BY THE COLLEGE OR BY DONORS OF RESTRICTED FUNDS.

THE UNIVERSITY ABIDES BY THE REGULATORY PROVISIONS SET ASIDE IN ALL GRANT AWARDS TO ENSURE PROPER FINANCIAL AND PROGRAMMATIC REPORTING. THE UNIVERSITY'S OFFICE OF SPONSORED PROGRAMS (OSP) PROVIDES OVERSIGHT AND MONITORING OF ALL GRANTS. OSP RECEIVED MONTHLY, QUARTERLY, AND ANNUAL REPORTS FROM ALL GRANTS FUNDED PROJECT DIRECTORS (PD) AND PROJECT INVESTIGATORS (PI) ASSOCIATED WITH THE IMPLEMENATION OF THE GRANT AWARDS. OSP MEETS WITH THE PDS AND PIS WEEKLY TO ENSURE THAT THE GRANTS ARE ON TARGET FOR COMPLETION. OSP WORKS CONJUNCTIVELY WITH THE DEPARTMENT OF ADMINISTRATION AND FINANCE TO MONITOR AND RECONCILE ALL FINANCIAL OBLIGATIONS WITHIN GRANTS AND CONTRACTS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PART I, LINE 1:CRITERIA FOR RECEIVING A SCHOLARSHIPS THROUGH THE UNIVERSITY
ExplntnTxt: 1. QUANTITATIVE MEASURE - THE STUDENT MUST SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETE (C OR BETTER) AT LEAST 75% OF ALL ATTEMPTED HOURS AT HUSTON-TILLOTSON UNIVERSITY. 2. QUALITATIVE MEASURE - THE STUDENT MUST ATTAIN A MINIMUM 1.8 CUMULATIVE GPA AT THE END OF THE FIRST YEAR TO RECEIVE FINANCIAL AID. AFTER COMPLETING TWO YEARS, THE STUDENT MUST MAINTAIN A MINIMUM 2.0 CUMULATIVE GPA TO RECEIVE FINANCIAL AID. 3. SECOND DEGREE SEEKING STUDENTS - STUDENTS MUST MEET THE SAME QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE STANDARDS AS SET FORTH FOR OTHER UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS.

THE OFFICE OF ADMISSIONS AWARDS ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON HIGH SCHOOL GRADES AND ACT/SAT SCORES. A FRESHMAN WITH A 3.0 CORE GPA AND A 25 ACT, OR ABOUT A 1700 SAT, WILL QUALIFY FOR AN ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIP. TRANSFER STUDENTS WITH LESS THAN 30 COLLEGE CREDIT HOURS WILL HAVE BOTH HIGH SCHOOL GRADES AND COLLEGE GRADES CONSIDERED FOR ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIP. A TRANSFER STUDENT WITH MORE THAN 30 COLLEGE HOURS WILL NOT NEED TO SUBMIT HIGH SCHOOL TRANSCRIPTS AND ONLY COLLEGE TRANSCRIPTS WILL BE EVALUATED. TRANSFER STUDENTS MUST HAVE A 3.0 CORE GPA TO QUALIFY. THE RANGE IS FROM $2,000 UP TO HALF-TUITION PER YEAR: THE HIGHER THE SCORES, THE HIGHER THE SCHOLARSHIP AMOUNT. THE OFFICE OF ADMISSIONS COORDINATES THE AWARDING OF DEPARTMENTAL SCHOLARSHIPS. THESE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AVAILABLE TO NEW STUDENTS WHO SUBMIT REQUIRED PROJECTS TO DEPARTMENT CHAIRS FOR JUDGING. DEPARTMENT SCHOLARSHIPS RANGE FROM $1,000-$5,000 PER YEAR. FOR ALL SCHOLARSHIPS, STUDENTS ARE NOTIFIED BY PHONE AND BY MAIL WITH AN OFFICIAL LETTER. THE OFFICE OF STUDENT FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE SENDS AN AWARD LETTER TO NOTIFY THE STUDENT OF ALL AID OFFERED TO THEM. MOST SCHOLARSHIPS (THE MERIT SCHOLARSHIP FOR CURRENT STUDENTS IS AN EXCEPTION) ARE RENEWABLE FOR FOUR YEARS AS LONG AS SPECIFIC ACADEMIC MINIMUMS ARE MAINTAINED. O'MORE WORK STUDY AND THE O'MORE GRANT ARE THE ONLY INSTITUTIONAL NEED-BASED FUNDS OFFERED BY THE COLLEGE. O'MORE WORK STUDY IS CREDITED TO STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS LIKE A GRANT. THE SCHOOL DETERMINES RECIPIENTS BY A FORMULA THAT IDENTIFIES NET NEED AFTER CALCULATING GROSS NEED (DIRECT COST-EFC) AND THEN CREDITING FEDERAL/STATE GRANTS, INSTITUTIONAL SCHOLARSHIPS/GRANTS, AND STUDENT LOANS. THIS INFORMATION IS MAILED TO THE STUDENT IN A LETTER AND A COPY IS KEPT IN THEIR FINANCIAL AID FOLDER.
SCHOLARSHIPS AND FINANCIAL AID ARE BASED ON APPLICATION PROCESS, EXPECTED FAMILY CONTRIBUTIONS AND COST OF TUITION.

ALL APPLICATIONS ARE PRESCREENED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE FOR ELIGIBILITY BEFORE BEING PASSED TO CHAIRS/HEADS OF EACH ACADEMIC PROGRAM FOR REVIEW AND RECOMMENDATION. THE RECOMMENDED APPLICANTS ARE THEN REVIEWED AND THEIR APPLICATIONS ARE DISCUSSED BY THE FINANCIAL AID COMMITTEE BEFORE FORWARDING THEM TO THE PRESIDENT'S OFFICE FOR APPROVAL. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE NOTIFIES EACH AWARDEE AND DISBURSES SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS INTO THEIR STUDENT ACCOUNT AFTER VERIFYING EACH AWARDEE'S ENROLLMENT STATUS AND ACADEMIC STANDING AT THE BEGINNING OF EACH SEMESTER.
ALL SCHOLARSHIPS & GRANTS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS ATTENDING MCPHERSON COLLEGE. THESE SCHOLARSHIPS & GRANTS ARE NON-CASH AWARDS, REQUIRING THE AWARDS TO BE USED AS A DIRECT REDUCTION IN TUITION COST.

DESCRIPTION OF ORGANIZATION'S PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF FUNDS TO ENHANCE ITS RESEARCH AGENDA AND PROVIDE VALUABLE TRAINING IN POLICY ANALYSIS, THE RAND CORPORATION PARTICIPATES IN A NUMBER OF PROGRAMS THAT PROVIDE FUNDING FOR FELLOWSHIPS. OUTSIDE ORGANIZATIONS, AGENCIES, AND FOUNDATIONS OCCASIONALLY MAKE FELLOWSHIPS AVAILABLE THROUGH GRANTS AWARDED TO RAND. SUCH OPPORTUNITIES ARE GENERALLY WIDELY ADVERTISED AND A COMPETITIVE APPLICATION PROCESS DETERMINES THE FELLOWSHIP RECIPIENT. FELLOWSHIP FUNDS ARE SEGREGATED AND MANAGEMENT ACTIVELY MONITORS SPENDING TO ENSURE ANY AND ALL REQUIREMENTS ARE MET, WHICH INCLUDES SUBMITTING PROGRESS REPORTS ATTESTING TO THE WORK COMPLETED BY THESE FELLOWS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: Scholarships are awarded to students based on the scholarship criteria. For example, a student may need to be an accounting major, with a GPA of 2.0 or higher. Students complete a scholarship application and the applications are given to a scholarship committee for review. The scholarship committee verifies the student meets the scholarship criteria and then determines the distribution.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2, Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
ExplntnTxt: THE UNIVERSITY AWARDS ONLY FINANCIAL AID GRANTS TO ENROLLED STUDENTS. GRANTS ARE CREDITED TO THE RECIPIENTS' ACCOUNTS FOR TUITION, FEES, ROOM AND BOARD.

FUNDS ARE DISTRIBUTED TO STUDENTS BASED ON NEED AND MERIT. STUDENT AID IS HANDLED BY THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT AND CREDITED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT ACCOUNT. EACH STUDENT APPLIES FOR FINANCIAL AID BY FILLING OUT A FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA). THE AWARD IS BASED ON THE INFORMATION IN THIS APPLICATION. STUDENTS CAN ALSO APPLY FOR GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON ELIGIBILITY. THERE IS AN AWARD ELIGIBILITY CALCULATOR AVAILABLE ON THE HEIDELBERG WEBSITE TO SEE IF YOU QUALIFY.

STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS ARE DETERMINED BY THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID THROUGH CAREFUL STUDY OF THE INFORMATION ON THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA), THE STUDENT'S ACADEMIC RECORD, TEST SCORES, AND RECOMMENDATIONS. DETAILED RECORDS AND STATISTICS ARE MAINTAINED BY THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID AND THE OFFICE OF ASSESSMENT AND INSTITUTIONAL RESEARCH IN REGARDS TO ALL FINANCIAL AID AWARDED TO STUDENTS OF THE COLLEGE, INCLUDING GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS.
FINANCIAL AID AND SCHOLARSHIPS FOR OLIVET COLLEGE STUDENTS ENROLLED AND ATTENDING CLASSES. ALL RECORDS ARE RETAINED BY THE COLLEGE.
Student financial aid is credited to the individual student accounts and their net balances are monitored by the Business Office.

MEREDITH COLLEGE FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE OFFICE HAS SYSTEMS AND INTERNAL PROCEDURES IN PLACE THAT ENSURES THE PROPER DETERMINATION, DISBURSEMENT AND MONITORING OF GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS. THESE SYSTEMS AND PROCEDURES COMPLY WITH THE FEDERAL STUDENT TITLE IV AID REGULATIONS, NORTH CAROLINA STATE EDUCATION ASSISTANCE AUTHORITY RULES, AND INSTITUTIONAL POLICIES.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: Students are free to use scholarship funds for any purpose. Scholarships are awarded contingent upon successful completion of a semester's work. This is related to the standards for "Satisfactory Academic Progress," as defined in the IBS catalogue. Funds are distributed at the end of semester, so as to avoid students receiving funds and then discontinuing their studies. By issuing funds at the end of each semester, students are then better able to pay tuition for the following term. Scholarship applications are reviewed by the Scholarship Committee (Dean and Director of the Center for Contemporary Shin Buddhist Studies), with attention to both student goals and progress, and donors' intent. While some scholarship endowments make funds available for any IBS students, a few others specifically designate "ministerial candidates," a status determined by the office of the Bishop, Buddhist Churches of America.
GRANTS TO INDIVIDUALS ARE MONITORED ANNAULLY IN CONJUNCTION WITH ACADEMIC ADVISING FOR STUDENTS.

PRIOR TO JULY 1, 2014 FINANCIAL AID WAS ADMINISTERED THROUGH A SHARED SERVICE AGREEMENT WITH CLAREMONT SCHOOL OF THEOLOGY. SCHOLARSHIPS WERE GRANTED TO STUDENTS BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED OR MERIT. FINANCIAL NEED QUALIFICATIONS INCLUDED DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED PER THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION FFSA, WHICH WAS UPDATED ANNUALLY. MERIT-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS WERE MONITORED FOR GRADE-POINT AVERAGE AND OTHER SIGNALS OF ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE. ALL NEED BASED RECORDS WERE MAINTAINED BY CST'S OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID AND MERIT BASED SCHOLARSHIPS WERE MAINTAINED BY CST'S OFFICE OF ADMISSION. THE UNIVERSITY REVIEWED ALL AWARDS AND HAD ACCESS TO ALL THE RECORDS. ON JULY 1, 2014, WHEN CLAREMONT LINCOLN UNIVERSITY SEPARATED FROM CLAREMONT SCHOOL OF THEOLOGY, CLU ELECTED TO NOT PARTICIPATE IN THE FEDERAL TITLE IV FUNDING PROGRAM.

SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED ON THE BASIS OF SCHOLASTIC ABILITY, PERSONAL PRESENTATION SKILLS AND FINANCIAL NEED. STUDENTS MUST MAINTAIN A MINIMUM GPA OF 2.5 TO QUALIFY FOR CONSIDERATION FOR ANY ADDITIONAL SCHOLARSHIP FUNDING.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2, Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
ExplntnTxt: THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AND BUSINESS OFFICE OPERATE TOGETHER TO ENSURE GRANTS ARE USED FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES. GRANTS ARE APPLIED TO STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS BY THE BUSINESS OFFICE AFTER THE GRANTS ARE APPROVED AND DISBURSED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: ORGANIZATION'S PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS
ExplntnTxt: SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2: FINANCIAL AID MONITORS ALL OF THE SCHOLARSHIPS THAT ARE AWARDED TO THE STUDENTS TO ENSURE THAT THEY MEET THE REQUIRED GUIDELINES.

OUR FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MONITORS THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE TO INDIVIDUALS IN THE UNITED STATES. THEY REVIEW EACH STUDENT TO VERIFY THEIR ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS FOR THE SPECIFIC GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE.

WORKSTUDY AND SEOG CONTRIBUTION NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS IS BASED ON AN ESTIMATE SINCE BOTH FIGURES ARE CALCULATED ON THE INSTITUTIONAL SHARE BASED ON TOTAL AMOUNT OF FUNDS AWARDED. FOR EXAMPLE, THE AVERAGE AMOUNT OF SEOG GIVEN TO STUDENTS IS $1,000 PER YEAR AND THE TOTAL INSTITUTIONAL FUNDS GIVEN IS $53,151. DIVIDING $53,151 BY $1,000 YIELDS APPROXIMATELY 53 STUDENTS.
THE UNIVERSITY OF TULSA FOLLOWS ALL WRITTEN PROCEDURES AS OUTLINED IN ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA.

The aid provided is in the form of scholarships and discounts awarded to students. The University has a well developed system of internal controls for Admissions, Financial Aid, Registration, Student Accounts, and Accounting. The system is monitored by experienced staff who ensure the use of aid is in compliance with all governing laws, regulations, and policies.
THE UNIVERSITY FOLLOWS ALL GOVERNMENT GUIDELINES FOR AWARDING SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE MADE FOR ACADEMIC MERIT AND FINANCIAL NEED.

Grants are awarded based on established criteria for each grant. The availability of funds, the need per FAFSA, and the date of the application are also considered. The funds are awarded and disbursed after all eligibility criteria have been confirmed. Tuition waivers must follow the approval process outline in the Human Resources Handbook. Waivers are awarded and disbursed based on the school year and semester registration.

THE OFFICE OF STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES ADMINISTERS, RECONCILES, AND REPORTS ALL AID TO STUDENTS IN ACCORDANCE WITH GRANT AGENCY PROCEDURES. FUNDS ARE VERIFIED, REVIEWED, AND RECONCILED TO ENSURE APPROPRIATE RECORDING.
THE USE OF FUNDS IS MONITORED VIA THE ACCOUNTS PAYABLE PROCESS. ALL FUNDS DISBURSED ARE REVIEWED FOR COMPLIANCE WITH DONOR INTENT.

CABRINI COLLEGE DOES NOT PROVIDE GRANTS TO OTHER ORGANIZATIONS, HOWEVER ON OCCASION DONATIONS ARE MADE TO OTHER CHARITABLE NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS. SINCE THESE ARE DONATIONS, THEY ARE NOT MONITORED FOR A SPECIFIC USE. SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS FOR STUDENTS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO A STUDENT'S CABRINI COLLEGE ACCOUNT AND APPLIED TO TUITION AND FEES. ALL FINANCIAL AID IS SUBJECT TO REVISION BASED ON AVAILABILITY, CHANGES IN FAMILY CONTRIBUTION AND/OR CREDIT LOAD. SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS MUST BE MAINTAINED ACCORDING TO STANDARDS PRESCRIBED BY CABRINI COLLEGE. ANNUAL RENEWAL OF FINANCIAL AID IS CONTINUOUS IF INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL NEED REMAINS, ALL REQUIRED DOCUMENTS ARE COMPLETED BY THE PUBLISHED DEADLINE AND SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS IS MAINTAINED CONSISTENT WITH THE CABRINI COLLEGE POLICY.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING USE OF GRANTS FUNDS IN U.S. FINANCIAL AID APPLICATIONS ARE RECEIVED AND GRANTED BASED ON NEED AND MERIT. IN ADDITION, THE UNDERGRADUATE RECIPIENTS ARE REQUIRED TO MAINTAIN A GRADE POINT AVERAGE AT OR ABOVE 3.0, FOR THE ACADEMIC YEAR FOR WHICH THE AID IS AWARDED.

All scholarships are awarded based upon specific criteria maintained by the financial aid office. Requirements for receiving scholarships depends on other factors such as grade point average, family income, or economic need. The Colleges financial aid staff monitors guidelines to ensure compliance. The College also under goes the required OMB A-133 audit annually.

All grants represent internal transfers of funds from endowment or other accounts to a revenue account for tuition payments. No funds are distributed directly to individuals. Merit Scholarships and SMU Grant Levels are based on the student's entering GPA and need. For incoming freshmen, test scores are also a factor. Provided that each student maintains the required GPA, does not exceed the maximum timeframe for institutional aid and submits either a FAFSA or FAFSA waiver by the March 1st deadline, the student will be eligible for his/her merit scholarship or SMU grant.

Shorter Univerity participates in the student financial assistance programs through the U.S. Department of Education. Funds are awarded and applied to student accounts based on the Department of Education guidelines set forth by the Title IV programs.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Description of Organization's Procedures for Monitoring the Use of Grants
ExplntnTxt: A LIST OF RECIPIENTS OF SCHOLARSHIPS, FELLOWSHIPS, AND GRANTS IS ON FILE AT THE INSTITUTION UPON REQUEST. ALTHOUGH THERE MAY BE RECIPIENTS WHO ARE RELATED TO PERSONS HAVING AN INTEREST IN THE ORGANIZATION, SUCH RECIPIENTS ARE ON AN EQUAL, OBJECTIVELY DETERMINABLE BASIS WITH OTHER RECIPIENTS; THAT IS ALL STUDENTS RECEIVING AID ARE JUDGED WORTHY BY THE INSTITUTION'S ASSESSMENT ON THE BASIS OF ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED, AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS.

SCHOLARSHIP RECIPIENTS ARE SELECTED BASED ON ESTABLISHED MERIT AND NEED BASED CRITERIA. THE FINANCIAL AID DIRECTOR AND ACADEMIC DEPARTMENT HEADS WORK TOGETHER TO SELECT RECIPIENTS OF IN-HOUSE SCHOLARSHIPS. QUALIFICATIONS FOR SCHOLARSHIPS VARY. ALL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE MONITORED BY THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT AND ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS.

THE ACADEMIC PROGRESS OF FINANCIAL AID RECIPIENTS IS MONITORED A MINIMUM OF ONCE EACH ACADEMIC YEAR. STUDENTS SHOULD CONTACT THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE WITH QUESTIONS REGARDING THE INTENT AND/OR INTERPRETATION OF THESE STANDARDS. COMPLETION RATE AND GRADE POINT AVERAGE (GPA) REQUIREMENTS FULL-TIME STUDENTS (STUDENTS ATTEMPTING 12 OR MORE CREDIT HOURS EACH SEMESTER) MUST PROGRESS ACCORDING TO THE FOLLOWING SCHEDULE: MINIMUM CREDITS MINIMUM REQUIRED SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETED CUMULATIVE GPA YEAR 1 24 1.70 YEAR 2 48 2.00 YEAR 3 72 2.00 YEAR 4 96 2.00 YEAR 5 123 2.00 THESE CREDIT HOURS MUST BE EARNED DURING THE ACADEMIC YEAR (FALL, WINTER AND SPRING). HOWEVER, IF A STUDENT DOES NOT MEET THESE REQUIRED HOURS, THEY MAY BE EARNED DURING THE FOLLOWING SUMMER SESSION(S). FAILURE TO ACHIEVE THIS STANDARD BY THE END OF THE SUMMER WILL RESULT IN THE LOSS OF FINANCIAL AID ELIGIBILITY UNTIL THE COMPLETED CUMULATIVE HOURS MEET THE MINIMUM STANDARDS. LOSS OF AID IS NOT THE SAME AS ACADEMIC SUSPENSION, WHICH IS HANDLED BY THE VICE PRESIDENT OF ACADEMIC AFFAIRS. PART-TIME STUDENTS MUST SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETE ONE-HALF OF THE CREDIT HOURS THEY ATTEMPT. COMBINED STUDENTS (STUDENTS BLENDING TERMS OF FULL- AND PART-TIME ENROLLMENT) MUST ACHIEVE A CUMULATIVE TOTAL THAT SATISFIES THE COMBINED FULL- AND PART-TIME STANDARDS. STUDENTS WHO DO NOT ACHIEVE THE MINIMUM CUMULATIVE GPA ARE GRANTED ONE PROBATIONARY SEMESTER IN WHICH TO RAISE THEIR CUMULATIVE GPA TO THE MINIMUM. FAILURE TO ACHIEVE THIS STANDARD AT ANY POINT FOLLOWING THE PROBATIONARY SEMESTER RESULTS IN THE LOSS OF FINANCIAL AID ELIGIBILITY UNTIL THE CUMULATIVE GPA MEETS THE MINIMUM STANDARDS.

WILKES UNIVERSITY MAINTAINS A COMPREHENSIVE PROGRAM OF FINANCIAL AID TO ASSIST STUDENTS IN THE FINANCING OF THEIR EDUCATION. THE UNIVERSITY AWARDS BOTH MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS AND NEED-BASED GRANTS TO UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS. MERIT AWARDS ARE BASED ON HIGH SCHOOL ACHIEVEMENT INCLUDING SAT SCORES AND HIGH SCHOOL CLASS RANK. STUDENTS MUST COMPLETE THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID TO HAVE THEIR ELIGIBILITY FOR NEED-BASED AID DETERMINED.

The Institute offers scholarships to students matriculating at the Institute. These scholarships are offered as direct reductions to tuition costs and no funds are remitted to the students. Since the student may not exercise any personal discretion as to how the funds are applied, the Institute is not required to monitor the use of the funds. Research fellows are chosen based on the qualifications in the area of research determined by the Director of the Center for Culture and Security. Grants are awarded based on grant budgets and funding availability. Once grants are awarded, funds are spent at the fellows discretion. Periodic updates are required as determined by the grant agreement that stipulate outcomes and deliverables. Academic fellows and students requesting scholarships apply to IWP, and are awarded fellowships and scholarships by the Financial Aid Committee.

NEUMANN UNIVERSITY'S PROCESS FOR MONITORING FINANCIAL AID AND MONITORING GRANT FUNDS IS A COMBINATION OF PROCEDURES INVOLVING THE FOLLOWING OFFICES - FINANCIAL AID, INSTITUTIONAL ADVANCEMENT, REGISTRAR, AND THE BUSINESS OFFICE. ALL GRANT EXPENDITURES ARE INITIALLY REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY GRANT PROJECT DIRECTORS. IF THE EXPENDITURE IS ABOVE $1,000, THEN IT IS ALSO REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY BOTH THE UNIT VICE PRESIDENT AND THE VICE PRESIDENT OF FINANCE AND ADMINISTRATION. BEFORE ANY EXPENSES ARE SUBMITTED BY THE UNIVERSITY FOR REIMBURSEMENT FROM THE GRANTING AGENCY, IT IS REVIEWED AGAIN BY THE UNIVERSITY'S CONTRACTS & GRANTS ACCOUNTANT TO ENSURE THE GRANT FUNDS WERE EXPENDED IN COMPLIANCE WITH UNIVERSITY POLICIES AND PROCEDURES, APPLICABLE OMB CIRCULARS, AND ANY ADDITIONAL SPONSOR OR PROGRAMMATIC REGULATIONS. THESE EXPENSES ARE THEN SUBMITTED BACK TO THE PROJECT DIRECTOR AND THE UNIVERSITY'S CONTROLLER FOR FINAL REVIEW AND SIGNATURE OF APPROVAL. INSTITUTIONAL ADVANCEMENT AND THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AWARD SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS ACCORDING TO THE SPECIFICATIONS/REQUIREMENTS OF THE SPECIFIC AWARD. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE, REGISTRAR, AND BUSINESS OFFICE COORDINATE THE AWARDING AND DOCUMENTATION OF FINANCIAL AID TO INCLUDE ELIGIBILITY OF FINANCIAL AID, NOTIFICATION OF STUDENTS, CHANGE OF STATUS, AND RECONCILEMENT OF STUDENT ACCOUNTS.

Scholarships and grants are distributed to students by posting the funds directly to their student accounts to offset charges for tuition, fees, and room and board. Any remaining credit is refunded to the student via check or direct deposit for use in purchasing books, housing, food, etc. Contributions to exempt organizations that further the University's exempt purpose require approval of a vice president.

ALL GRANT FUNDS ARE DETERMINED AND AWARDED BY THE OFFICE OF ENROLLMENT MANAGEMENT AND STUDENT FINANCIAL AID CONSISTENT WITH THE UNIVERSITY'S POLICIES AS WELL AS FEDERAL AND STATE GUIDELINES. GRANTEES MUST MAINTAIN PREDETERMINED ACADEMIC LEVELS IN ORDER TO QUALIFY FOR SUBSEQUENT GRANTS.

THE COLLEGE DOES NOT GIVE ANY NON-CASH SCHOLARSHIPS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE DISBURSED TO STUDENTS THROUGH CREDITING THEIR STUDENT ACCOUNTS. IF THE STUDENT HAS ANY EXCESS SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS OVER THEIR CHARGES, THESE FUNDS ARE DISBURSED TO THE STUDENT BY CHECK. THE COLLEGE'S PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING GRANT FUNDS IN THE U.S. ARE AS FOLLOWS: THE COLLEGE HAS APPOINTED DIRECTORS, WHO REPORT TO THE APPROPRIATE VICE PRESIDENTS, OVER ALL FEDERAL GRANT PROGRAMS. THESE DIRECTORS ARE CHARGED WITH PERFORMING ALL GRANT-RELATED ACTIVITIES INCLUDING APPLICATION, MONITORING OF EXPENDITURES AND REPORTING, WITH THE EXCEPTION OF DRAW-DOWNS OF FEDERAL FUNDS. DRAW-DOWNS ARE PERFORMED BY THE COLLEGE'S CONTROLLER AFTER REQUESTS ARE MADE BY THE DIRECTOR TO THE CONTROLLER. THE CONTROLLER REVIEWS THE REQUESTS FOR DRAW-DOWNS, WHICH INCLUDE DOCUMENTATION OF ALL DIRECT AND INDIRECT PROGRAM EXPENSES, BEFORE MAKING THE DRAW-DOWNS. A SINGLE AUDIT IS PERFORMED ANNUALLY BY THE COLLEGE'S INDEPENDENT AUDITORS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Procedure for Monitoring Use of Grant Funds Inside U.S.
ExplntnTxt: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 All financial aid grants are used for the intended purpose which is to providY aid to students with financial need to cover the students cost of attendance. These grants include federal pell grants, federal SEOG grants, and state PHEAA grants. The College also awards donor restricted grants that are provided from foundations, alumni scholarship donations, and other donors. Additionally, the College provides internal institutional grants to eligible students. These grants are awarded by the Financial Aid Office and posted to the eligible students accounts by the Business Office. These accounts are reconciled by the Business Office and Financial Aid Office on a monthly basis. The Financial Aid Office complies with the U.S. Department of Education guidelines as well as any donor restricted grant guidelines. The Financial Aid Office reports student grant awards to the U.S. Department of Education and PHEAA throughout the year and also submits the required annual FISAP report to the U.S. Department of Education. An annual A-133 audit (financial statements and report of independent certified public accounts in accordance with OMB Circular A-133) is conducted by the Colleges external independent auditors.
ALL GRANTS ARE INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL AID AND APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT BY THE UNIVERSITY.

ALL GRANTS ARE INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL AID AND APPLIED DIRECTLY TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS. IT IS A CONTINUAL PROCESS IN WHICH WE AWARD STUDENT AID WITHIN FEDERAL GUIDELINES AT THE INITIAL AWARDING TIME PERIOD. IF ANY CHANGES TO A STUDENT'S STATUS OCCUR, WE REVIEW THE STUDENT'S AID PACKAGE COMPONENTS TO ENSURE THAT ANY/ALL ADJUSTMENTS MADE MAINTAIN COMPLIANCE WITH TITLE IV FUND RULES. WE ALSO PERFORM SPOT CHECKS THROUGHOUT THE SEMESTER TO DOUBLE CHECK THAT AID ELIGIBILITY CALCULATIONS ARE MET.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: The college reports are regularly reviewed to be certain funds are used for proper purposes. Federal grant reporting and reconciliation occurs monthly and during the yearly A-133 audit. Awarding practices are reviewedforcompliance with federal regulations. Students are reviewed yearly for continued and new fund eligibility to be sure academic standards and other grant-specific criteria have been met.

ADMISSIONS IS GIVEN A PERCENTAGE OF GROSS TUITION TO AWARD AS INSTITUTIONAL GRANTS. THE CURRENT PERCENTAGE IS 23%. THE AMOUNT OF THE GRANT IS COMMUNICATED TO THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE WHO MAKES IT PART OF THE TOTAL FINANCIAL AID PACKAGE. ONCE THE STUDENT ACCEPTS ADMISSION, THE GRANT IS POSTED TO THE STUDENTS ACCOUNT BY FINANCIAL AID. THE BUSINESS OFFICE MONITORS THE TOTAL AWARDED TO ENSURE THEY ARE WITHIN BUDGET.
