THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE HAS A SET OF CRITERIA BY WHICH COLLEGE AID IS AWARDED TO STUDENTS. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MAINTAINS RECORDS OF ALL STUDENT AID AWARDED AND SUBSTANTIATION FOR THE AWARDS.
Financial aid assistance is awarded based on US Federal, State, and Private guidelines as required by the corresponding type of assistance.

Scholarships and stipends - Funds provided to students attending any of SUAGM's institutions that meet the requirements of a particular program (such as athletic and honor programs). Also, SUAGM may provide scholarships to students that present significant financial need. Scholarships may cover tuition, books and supplies costs; while stipends may cover other related living costs, like: food, housing and transportation. College work study - Funds may cover student's costs of living.

STUDENT ENROLLMENT IS MONITORED ON A REGULAR BASIS. AFTER VERIFICATION OF ENROLLMENT EACH TERM, FEDERAL FINANCIAL AID GRANTS ARE APPLIED TO THE STUDENTS' EDUCATIONAL COSTS PER FEDERAL REGULATIONS. STUDENT WITHDRAWALS ARE ALSO MONITORED AND GRANT FUNDS ARE ADJUSTED AND RETURNED AS NECESSARY.
Senior management recommends to the Executive Committee grants to other organizations for approval.
Scholarship assistance is approved and monitored for individuals through campus scholarship committees.

CARTHAGE COLLEGE OFFERS SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS TO HELP REDUCE THEIR OUT-OF-POCKET TUITION COSTS. STUDENTS RECEIVING FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE OF THIS FORM MUST MEET SPECIFIC CRITERIA SUCH AS ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS WHETHER PUT IN PLACE BY THE COLLEGE OR BY DONORS OF RESTRICTED FUNDS.

Scholarships and grants awarded to students are administered by the Student Financial Planning office and awarded in accordance with any donor imposed restrictions, need-based qualifications imposed by the US Department of Education, and institutional policies and procedures. Institutionally provided student financial aid is posted to the student accounts receivables and is funded primarily through the unrestricted budget, restricted gifts or the investment income of endowed scholarships. Merit awards are made for academic achievement, leadership and individual talent. Awards based on financial need are determined on the basis of information from the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) form.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: JD Admission Scholarships:Admission scholarships are granted based on merit. This includes, but is not always limited to: LSAT score and undergraduate grade point average. Some scholarships are also awarded based on merit and diversity. There is no separate application beyond the admissions application required for most of the scholarships. Merit Based Scholarships:California Western School of Law (the School) offers two forms of merit based scholarships that are awarded to students at the completion of their first year of law school. The Academic Merit Scholarship is typically awarded to students with GPAs from 3.33 to 4.33. It is awarded based solely on the student's GPA. The Dean's Diversity Scholarship is typically awarded to students with GPAs from 2.80 to 4.33. It is awarded through a competitive application process. The number of scholarships offered each year varies, based on the number of eligible students and the availability of funds.LL.M./M.C.L. Scholarships:These scholarships are awarded to the School's most academically outstanding LL.M./M.C.L. applicants based upon academic credentials, relevant work experience, impressive academic and professional recommendations, and strong command of English (as evidenced by quality writing on the applicant's personal statement and by the applicant's "Test of English as a Foreign Language" score).
THE ORGANIZATION PROVIDES INSTITUITIONAL AID TO UNIVERSITY STUDENTS MAINTAINING ENROLLMENT.

ASSISTANCE IS GIVEN TO INDIVIDUALS IN THE FORM OF CREDITS TOWARD THE COST OF TUITION, AND A RECORD OF THE ASSISTANCE PROVIDED IS RECORDED IN SEPARATE ACCOUNTS MAINTAINED FOR EACH STUDENT/RECIPIENT. DURING THE FISCAL YEAR ENDED 5/31/14, ASSISTANCE WAS ALSO PROVIDED TO CERTAIN QUALIFIED AND REPUTABLE CHARITABLE ORGANIZATIONS, AND USE OF THOSE FUNDS IS NOT SPECIFICALLY MONITORED.

Arcadia University awards both need-based and merit-based financial aid to students in good academic standing. The University maintains records to quantify the dollar amount of the financial assistance awarded, the number of recipients per grant/scholarship, and the selection criteria. All grants and scholarships awarded to students are credited directly to the student's billing account.
The University makes occasional donations to charitable organizations which are not monitored beyond the original grant determination process.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE IN THE UNITED STATES
ExplntnTxt: FORM 990, SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 The awarding of student financial aid grants under the U.S. Department of Education's Student Financial Assistance Program is monitored by the College's Financial Aid Office, which ensures that the College meets the compliance requirements of OMB Circular A-133. The College's Financial Aid Office is responsible for establishing and maintaining effective internal control over compliance with the requirements of laws, regulations, contracts, and grants applicable to federal programs. Monitoring of federal and foundation grants supporting College operating activities is coordinated between the Financial Aid Office, the Chancellor's office, the Controller's office and the VP of Institutional Advancement. These offices and individuals ensure that appropriate controls are established and that grant requirements for documentation, tracking, expenditure of funds and reporting are met. All students receiving scholarships are judged worthy by the institution's assessment on the basis of academic achievement, financial need, athletic ability and other similar standards.
THE FUNDS ARE CREDITED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT, WHICH DIRECTLY OFFSETS TUITION, FEES, ROOM AND BOARD.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Procedure for Monitoring Use of Grant Funds In the U.S.
ExplntnTxt: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Grants to Organizations in the U.S. AU partners with other Universities as necessary to perform the scope of the work outlined in the grants agreements. Prior to engaging with these sub-awardees, AU performs a risk assessment including a review of the most recent financial statements as well as ensuring they are not listed as a debarred entity with any federal agency. Grants to Individuals in the U.S. Schedule I, Part III, Line 1 ALL STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS ARE JUDGED WORTHY BY THE UNIVERSITY'S ASSESSMENT ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVMENT, FINANCIAL NEED AND SIMILAR STANDARDS. APPROXIMATELY 75% OF FULL TIME FRESHMEN APPLIED FOR NEED BASED FINANCIAL AID.
STUDENTS ARE VERIFIED FOR ELIGIBILITY AND FUNDS ARE POSTED TO EACH STUDENT'S ACCOUNT. ACCOUNT IS REFUNED IF NOT USED IN SPECIFIED TIME OR IF STUDENT WITHDRAWS.

DAVENPORT UNIVERSITY PROVIDES FUNDING FOR STUDENT SCHOLARSHIPS AND TUITION DISCOUNTS BASED ON MERIT, FINANCIAL NEED, SPECIAL CRITERIA BASED ON RESTRICTED ENDOWMENT FUNDS, AND INFORMATION PROVIDED BY THE STUDENT ON THE SCHOLARSHIP APPLICATION. ALLOCATIONS ARE DETERMINED FOR EACH ACCOUNT BY THE ACCOUNTING AND ALUMNI AND DEVELOPMENT OFFICES AND DISTRIBUTED TO THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICER RESPONSIBLE FOR SCHOLARSHIPS. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE IS RESPONSIBLE FOR COMMUNICATING AWARD GUIDELINES, PROCEDURES, AND REQUIREMENTS, AS WELL AS AWARD AMOUNTS, TO ACCOUNTS RECEIVABLE AND OTHER DEPARTMENTS AS NECESSARY TO ENSURE THE ACCURACY OF THE AWARDS. IN ADDITION, THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE IS RESPONSIBLE FOR ENSURING THAT AWARDS ARE MADE IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE SCHOLARSHIP CRITERIA AND AWARDED IN THE AMOUNT APPROVED BY THE ALUMNI AND DEVELOPMENT OFFICE.

REGIS UNIVERSITY COMPLIES WITH ALL APPLICABLE FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITUTIONAL LAWS, REGULATIONS, AND GUIDELINES INCLUDING, THE DEPT OF ED'S STUDENT FINANCIAL AID HANDBOOK AND THE COLORADO DEPT OF HIGHER ED'S POLICY GUIDELINES AND AUDIT GUIDE.
MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS: ALL GRANTS ARE APPLIED TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS AFTER VERIFYING ENROLLMENT STATUS ON AN INDIVIDUAL BASIS.

The University monitors their respective grants by establishing a separate accounting for each individual grant. All transactions are reviewed and approved by appropriate personnel prior to submission for processing to ensure they meet the requirements of the grant.

MIDLAND UNIVERSITY OFFERS SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS TO HELP REDUCE THEIR OUT-OF-POCKET TUITION COSTS. STUDENTS RECEIVING FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE OF THIS FORM MUST MEET SPECIFIC CRITERIA SUCH AS ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS WHETHER PUT IN PLACE BY THE COLLEGE OR BY DONORS OF RESTRICTED FUNDS.

THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT DETERMINES ALL FEDERAL AND STATE FINANCIAL AID FOR STUDENTS BASED ON THE RESPECTIVE LAWS AND REGULATIONS. THE REMAINING NEED FOR FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE IS THEN DETERMINED BY THE COLLEGE AND IS BASED ON CRITERIA SUCH AS STUDENT ACTIVITIES (ATHLETICS, ETC.), THE ACADEMIC PROGRAM THE STUDENT IS ENROLLED IN, THE STUDENT'S ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE, AND THE INCOME LEVEL OF THE STUDENT. THESE FACTORS ARE THEN CONSIDERED ALONG WITH THE AVAILABLE INSITUTIONAL SCHOLARSHIP AND GRANT FUNDS IN DETERMINING INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE PROVIDED TO THE STUDENTS.

GRANTS ARE MADE IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND STIPENDS TO ELIGIBLE STUDENTS. TOCC MAINTAINS RECORDS OF STUDENTS' QUALIFYING CRITERIA AND SEEKS TO ENSURE THAT EVERYONE HAS ACCESS TO QUALITY EDUCATION REGARDLESS OF NEED.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2, Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
ExplntnTxt: GRANT FUNDS/SCHOLARSHIPS ARE CREDITED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS TO ENSURE THE APPROPRIATE USE OF FUNDS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: THE UNIVERSITY AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS BASED ON SUPERIOR ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT AND DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED. INDIVIDUALS RECEIVING AWARDS FROM JOHN CARROLL UNIVERSITY ARE CHOSEN BASED UPON OBJECTIVE AND NON-DISCRIMINATORY CRITERIA WHICH ARE CONSISTENT WITH THE OVERALL TAX-EXEMPT PURPOSE OF THE UNIVERSITY.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS - PART I, LINE 2:
ExplntnTxt: THE COLLEGE'S ONLY GRANT-MAKING ACTIVITY IS TO PROVIDE SCHOLARSHIPS TO THOSE STUDENTS THAT MEET CERTAIN FINANCIAL AND MERIT CRITERIA. THESE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE DEDUCTED FROM EACH RECIPIENT'S BILL FOR TUITION AND FEES. AS SUCH, THE COLLEGE IS ASSURED THAT ITS GRANTS ARE USED FOR THE INTENDED PURPOSE OF HELPING STUDENTS WITH EDUCATIONAL EXPENSES.

AIE - WA did not provide cash grant funds directly to its students; rather, it provided scholarships to first and second-year students in the form of reduced tuition on a needs basis. Additional discounts were provided to individuals if requested by the individual and after a personal discussion and a financial evaluation by the school. Procedures and records are maintained at the AIE - WA location.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: THE COLLEGE HAS A FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT WHOSE STAFF IS TRAINED AND CONTINUOUSLY EDUCATED REGARDING FEDERAL FINANCIAL AID RULES AND REGULATIONS. THE STAFF OF THE COLLEGE DETERMINES THE FINANCIAL NEED OF THE STUDENT AND DETERMINES THE AMOUNT OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE THAT CAN BE AWARDED TO THE STUDENT BASED ON FEDERAL RULES AND REGULATIONS. THE FINANCIAL AID STAFF ALSO AWARDS GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON ENDOWED GIFTS THAT COMPLY WITH THE TERMS OF THE ENDOWED GIFTS.

THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MAINTAINS ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS AND MONITORS GRANTING OF AWARDS TO STUDENTS AND FOLLOWS U.S. FEDERAL AID REGULATIONS AND ALL STATES' REGULATIONS FOR GRANTS TO ITS STUDENTS.

Although students and their families bear the primary responsibility for meeting costs, many find they cannot pay the full cost of an education by themselves. In most cases a financial aid package will involve family contributions, acceptance of federal assistance (including grants and loans), and financial aid from John Brown University. These financial assistance programs help fill the gap between the amount a family is expected to pay and the total educational cost. The amount the family is expected to pay is based on information provided on the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA).

PRIVATE GRANTS - THE COLLEGE FOLLOWS THE TERMS OF THE PROVIDER IN THE POSTING AND RELEASING OF GRANT FUNDS. FEDERAL GRANTS - THE COLLEGE FOLLOWS THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION REGULATIONS TO ENSURE THAT GRANTS ARE UTILIZED APPROPRIATELY. THE NSLDS SYSTEM HELPS THE COLLEGE IDENTIFY ANY STUDENT THAT HAS BEEN POTENTIALLY AWARDED MORE THAN THEY ARE ELIGIBLE FOR.

QUALIFICATIONS TO RECEIVE PAYMENTS: GOVERNMENT GRANTS ARE AWARDED IN ACCORDANCE WITH APPROPRIATE FEDERAL REGULATIONS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE BASED ON ACT TEST SCORES, ACADEMIC STANDING, AS SHOWN BY HIGH SCHOOL TRANSCRIPTS, AS WELL AS COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT. GRANTS ARE AWARDED IN RECOGNITION OF THE QUALITY OF PAST ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT AT OUR LADY OF HOLY CROSS COLLEGE, FINANCIAL NEED AS DETERMINED BY THE SUBMISSION OF THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID, AND COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT.

Bryn Mawr College has several sub-recipients of government funds. The College complies with the provisions of Circular A-133 and any statutes governing sub-awards made by and to not-for-profit entities.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2, Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
ExplntnTxt: THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE NOTIFIES STUDENTS WHEN OUR COMPREHENSIVE ENDOWMENT SCHOLARSHIP APPLICATION GOES LIVE (FIRST WEEK OF FEBRUARY). ONCE NOTIFIED, STUDENTS FILL OUT AN APPLICATION TO APPLY FOR THE RESPECTIVE SCHOLARSHIP. IF THE SCHOLARSHIP IS FOR A SPECIFIC PROGRAM, THE DEAN OR OTHER FACULTY MEMBER FOR THAT PROGRAM WILL REVIEW THE APPLICATIONS AND MAKE RECOMMENDATIONS TO THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AND WHO SHOULD RECEIVE THE AWARD. FINANCIAL AID VERIFIES AGAIN IF THE STUDENT IS STILL ELIGIBLE FOR THE AWARD AND ISSUES THE FUNDS TO THE RECOMMENDED STUDENTS. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MONITORS THE USE OF THE FUNDS TO ENSURE THAT THEY ARE USED FOR THEIR INTENDED PURPOSE.
All assistance is in the form of grants and scholarships. These funds are applied directly to the student's account.

INSTITUTIONAL SCHOLARSHIPS AND DISCOUNTS AND ENDOWED SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE ARE RECONCILED BY THE ACCOUNTING DEPARTMENT TO VERIFY THE APPROPRIATE AMOUNT WAS CREDITED TO THE CORRECT STUDENT'S ACCOUNT EVERY SEMESTER.
THE ORGANIZATION PROVIDES ONGOING OVERSIGHT AND MONITORING TO ASSURE THE ACHIEVEMENT OF THE INTENDED PURPOSES AND TIMELY EXPENDITURES OF GRANT FUNDS.

PACIFIC LUTHERAN UNIVERSITY OFFERS SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS TO HELP REDUCE THEIR OUT-OF-POCKET TUITION COSTS. STUDENTS RECEIVING FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE OF THIS FORM MUST MEET SPECIFIC CRITERIA SUCH AS ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS WHETHER PUT IN PLACE BY THE COLLEGE OR BY DONORS OF RESTRICTED FUNDS.

THE UNIVERSITY OFFICE OF STUDENT FINANCIAL AID PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIP AND GRANTS TO STUDENTS IN ACCORDANCE WITH UNIVERSITY POLICIES AND DONOR GUIDELINES. THE UNIVERSITY ALSO MAINTAINS COMPREHENSIVE RECORD OF THE SAME.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2, Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
ExplntnTxt: THE INSTITUTION AWARDS BOTH NEED BASED AND MERIT BASED FUNDS AND ARE DISTRIBUTED IN A FAIR AND EQUITABLE BASIS. FUNDS ARE AWARDED BASED ON THE INSTITUTION'S PACKAGING POLICIES AND AWARDING CRITERIA. STUDENTS MUST COMPLETE THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) ON A YEARLY BASIS TO APPLY FOR NEED BASED INSTITUTIONAL ASSISTANCE. THE FAFSA RESULTS ARE USED TO DETERMINE ELIGIBILITY FOR NEED BASED AWARDS BASED ON THE ESTABLISHED INSTITUTIONS PACKAGING POLICIES. SPECIAL CIRCUMSTANCES MAY BE CONSIDERED WHEN AWARDING NEED-BASED FUNDS AND ARE CONSIDERED ON AN INDIVIDUAL BASIS. STUDENT RECORDS/FILES ARE KEPT FOR 4 YEARS FROM THE DATE OF LAST ENROLLMENT---FILES WILL INCLUDE FAFSA'S AND ALL SUPPORTING DOCUMENTATION FOR DETERMINING ELIGIBILITY. THE COLLEGE MAINTAINS CONTROL OF THESE FUNDS BY APPLYING THEM DIRECTLY TO A STUDENTS BILLING INSTEAD OF AWARDING THEM DIRECLTY TO THE STUDENT ENSURING PROPER USE..

Gustavus offers both merit-based and need-based scholarship assistance. Merit-based scholarships do not require a student to demonstrate financial eligibility and must be awarded during the Admission process. They also may be awarded as part of a need-based financial aid package. To be renewed, the student needs to maintain the established minimum standards. Need-based scholarships are offered to students who demonstrate financial eligibility by filing the FAFSA. The offered amounts can vary from year to year as determined by the family's Estimated Family Contribution (EFC) on the FAFSA and availability of funds. The Registrar's office monitors any changes to a student's enrollment status. Any changes are communicated to the Student Accounts office and the Financial Aid office to ensure funds are being properly disbursed. Also see Schedule F, Part V with respect to monitoring of students taking J-Term or semester studies outside of the United States.

PROCEDURE FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS INSIDE THE U.S. The College offers a wide variety of merit and need-based scholarships and awards to matriculating students. Merit awards are given in recognition of various achievements as specified in donors' correspondence and documents, or by College policy. Need-based awards are provided based on the income level, availability of awards offered elsewhere and similar standards. The College's Financial Aid Office uses various methods for the fair disbursement of grant funds within the requirements set by each grant source to monitor compliance. The College primarily makes scholarship grants that help offset tuition and other educational costs of the students, with most directly credited against the applicable student account, which assures proper use. The amount of the grant is adjusted by the Financial Aid Office, as necessary, based on any subsequent changes affecting the student's original eligibility.

THE UNIVERSITY STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES OFFICE MAINTAINS RECORDS TO SUBSTANTIATE THE AMOUNTS OF GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS INCLUDING ELIGIBILITY AND SELECTION CRITERIA. THIS OFFICE ENSURES THAT FUNDS ARE PROPERLY CREDITED TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS AND MONITORS STUDENTS' CONTINUING ELIGIBILITY TO RECEIVE FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE UNITED STATES: EACH GRANT IS ASSIGNED A GRANTS ADMINISTRATOR WHO MONITORS ALL EXPENDITURES TO ENSURE FUNDS ARE USED IN ACCORDANCE WITH GRANTOR POLICIES AND REGULATIONS. IN ADDITION, AN ACCOUNTANT IS ASSIGNED TO RECORD AND REPORT ALL GRANT REVENUES AND EXPENDITURES TO THE GRANT ADMINISTRATOR AND GRANTOR ON A REGULAR BASIS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: ALL FUNDING DECISIONS ARE MADE BY THE SUMMIT ENDOWMENT COMMITTEE, A COMMITTEE OF THE SUMMIT HEALTH BOARD. THE ENDOWMENT MANAGER PROCESSES GRANT APPLICATIONS, ASSISTS GRANTEES IN DEVELOPING SOUND PROGRAM EVALUATION METHODOLOGIES, RECEIVES AND SUMMARIZES PERIODIC REPORTS, AND VISITS PROGRAM SITES, REPORTING ALL ACTIVITIES TO THE SUMMIT ENDOWMENT COMMITTEE. AS WELL, ENDWOMENT COMMITTEE MEETING MINUTES ARE SHARED WITH WAYNESBORO HOSPITAL'S, CHAMBERSBURG HOSPITAL'S, AND SUMMIT HEALTH'S BOARD OF DIRECTORS.

Grants or assistance provided is for scholarships and grants to Simpson College students which are applied directly to the student's tuition charges. The Office of Financial Assistance awards scholarships and grants to students based on a variety of different criteria for each scholarship.

THE UNIVERSITY AWARDS FEDERAL AND STATE FINANCIAL AID FUNDS EACH YEAR BASED UPON A STUDENT'S FINANCIAL NEED. ADDITIONALLY, THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES INSTITUTIONAL AID VIA UNIVERSITY GRANTS ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENTS, FINANCIAL NEED, AND OTHER STANDARDS. THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID VERIFIES THE ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENTS AND THE PERSONAL INCOME DATA PROVIDED FOR ON THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) OF EACH STUDENT TO DETERMINE THE AMOUNT OF AID AWARDED ON AN AS NEEDED BASIS. THE UNIVERSITY ALSO OFFERS SCHOLARSHIPS FUNDED THROUGH SPECIAL ENDOWMENTS AND DONATIONS, WHICH ARE AWARDED BASED ON SIMILAR STANDARDS AS WELL AS DONOR'S CRITERIA. THE OFFICES OF FINANCIAL AID AND FINANCE CONTINUOUSLY MONITOR STUDENT ELIGIBILITY FOR THESE AWARDS.

ELIGIBILITY FOR THE SCHOOL'S SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS IS DETERMINED USING THE FEDERAL NEEDS ANALYSIS METHODOLOGY AS SET FORTH BY THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION. THE MONIES USED TO GRANT ASSISTANCE TO THE STUDENTS COME OUT OF THE GENERAL OPERATING FUND FROM UNRESTRICTED DONATIONS.

SCHOLARSHIPS/GRANTS ARE PROVIDED TO STUDENTS THROUGH FINANCIAL AID, BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED AND FEDERAL OR STATE MANDATED REGULATIONS. DONOR RESTRICTED SCHOLARSHIPS ARE ALSO MONITORED AND DISTRIBUTED THROUGH FINANCIAL AID PROCESSES TO COVER EDUCATIONAL EXPENSES ESTIMATED OR CHARGED BY THE UNIVERSITY.

THE ORG. UTILIZES VARIOUS DATABASES TO STORE & MONITOR ALL DATA PERTAINING TO THE AWARDING AND DISBURSEMENT OF GRANTS RECEIVED IN THE U.S. ALL GRANTS RECEIVED ARE PROPERLY APPLIED AS PAYMENTS TOWARD STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS APPROPRIATELY. ALL PARTICIPATING GRANTING ORGANIZATIONS HAVE COMPLIANCE REQUIREMENTS THAT ARE ADHERED TO & AUDITED ANNUALLY IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE OFFICE OF MGT. AND BUDGET (OMB) CIRCULAR A-133, AUDITS OF STATES, LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, AND NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS. AS SUCH, THE ORG. PRESENTS SCHEDULES OF EXPENDITURES OF FEDERAL AND STATE AWARDS SUMMARIZING ALL EXPENDITURES USING THE ACCRUAL BASIS OF ACCOUNTING.
NORTH AMERICAN UNIVERSITY pays the scholarships direCtly to students.

THE COLLEGE AWARDS GRANTS ON A FISCAL YEAR BASED ACCORDING TO THE OVERALL YEARLY BUDGET. INDIVIDUAL AWARDS ARE PACKAGED BASED ON AN OVERALL COLLEGE STRATEGY EMPLOYING NEED AND MERIT CRITERIA. THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE WORKS WITH OUTSIDE CONSULTANTS TO PREPARE PACKAGES. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE WORKS WITH STUDENTS TO ACCEPT AND/OR ADJUST INDIVIDUAL GRANTS. THE COLLEGE ALSO PROVIDES CHARITABLE SUPPORT TO U.S. SECTION 501(C)(3) PUBLIC CHARITIES IN FURTHERANCE OF ITS MISSION
CASH GRANTS ARE CREDITS TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS.

THESE FUNDS REPRESENT FINANCIAL AID ISSUED TO STUDENTS IN THE FORM OF FEDERAL AND STATE GRANTS, SCHOLARSHIPS, TUITION DISCOUNTS, AND INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL AID. STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS FROM FRANCISCAN UNIVERSITY ARE MONITORED TO ENSURE THEY MEET THE ACADEMIC REQUIREMENTS OR OTHER CRITERIA ASSOCIATED WITH THE RESPECTIVE AWARD. ALL AID IS PROCESSED THROUGH THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AND IS POSTED TO THE STUDENTS' RECEIVABLE ACCOUNTS.

DISBURSEMENTS TO STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS AND FINANCIAL AID ARE MADE IN ACCORDANCE WITH INSTITUTIONAL PROCEDURES TO ENSURE THAT THOSE RECEIVING AID ARE QUALIFYING RECIPIENTS. FEDERAL FINANCIAL AID AND/OR ASSISTANCE FROM GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES IS DISTRIBUTED AND MONITORED IN ACCORDANCE WITH FEDERALLY APPROVED NEED ANALYSIS CRITERIA OR OTHER AGENCY PROVIDED CRITERIA. THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS TO INDIVIDUALS ARE MONITORED THROUGH UNIQUE GENERAL LEDGER ACCOUNTS FOR EACH GRANT. EXPENDITURES FOR EACH GRANT ACCOUNT ARE REVIEWED AND ANALYZED USING AD-HOC REPORTS TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE.

FINANCIAL AID IS AVAILABLE TO STUDENTS WHO CAN SHOW FINANCIAL NEED, ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, LEADERSHIP/SERVICE, ATHLETICS ABILITY, AND/OR TALENT. ACADEMIC AND LEADERSHIP AWARDS ARE DETERMINED THROUGH THE ADMISSIONS AREA, ATHLETICS AWARDS ARE DETERMINED BY THE RESPECTIVE COACH, TALENT/DEPARTMENTAL AWARDS ARE DETERMINED THROUGH THOSE ACADEMIC AREAS, AND THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE COORDINATES ALL AWARDS WITH FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITUTIONAL NEED-BASED AID.
Scholarships are awarded based on established criteria, including donor restrictions.

NORTHWEST NAZARENE UNIVERSITY MONITORS THE USE OF ITS GRANT FUNDS AS REQUIRED BY THE INDIVIDUAL GRANT PROGRAMS AND DONOR CRITERIA ESTABLISHED AT THE TIME OF THE ORIGINAL DONATION. THESE ARE MONITORED THROUGH THE ANNUAL AUDITING PROCESS AS WELL AS THROUGH FEDERAL AND STATE REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. ISIR/FAFSA AND HIGH SCHOOL TRANSCRIPTS SHOWING ELIGIBILITY FOR GRANTS ARE MAINTAINED IN THE STUDENT'S FILE FOR A PERIOD OF 7 YEARS AFTER THE STUDENT WITHDRAWS OR FINISHES THEIR PROGRAMS. GRANT AMOUNTS APPEAR ON THE AWARD LETTER IN THE FILE AS WELL AS ON THE INDIVIDUAL'S FINANCIAL AID RECORD IN THE DATABASE.

AIE - LA did not provide cash grant funds directly to its scholarship recipients; rather, it provided scholarships to both first and second-year students in the form of reduced tuition of at least 50% of the posted annual tuition. AIE - LA, at the discretion of the Board of Directors, provided additional discounts based on the need of each student following a personal conversation regarding this need and a financial evaluation by the school.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: Grant funds disbursed by the College are predominantly available as merit or need based scholarships. These scholarships are disbursed by the Financial Aid office and are credited directly to the student's account to pay for tuition, room and board. They are then monitored by the Financial Aid Office and the Student Accounts Office, both of whom are notified if the student's enrollment status changes during the semester. These offices monitor whether the grantee is taking the necessary classes and is therefore utilizing the grant as it was intended. If a student's enrollment changes, award adjustments are made. Other grant funds are disbursed by the College through Accounts Payable. Qualification and use of these payments are monitored by the respective departments responsbile for the disbursement.

VIRTUALLY ALL UNIVERSITY FUNDED SCHOLARSHIPS ARE TIED TO THE STUDENTS' GRADE POINT AVERAGE (GPA) OR BASED UPON FINANCIAL NEED AS DETERMINED BY THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA). ANNUALLY, THE GPA AND NEED ARE REVIEWED TO DETERMINE COMPLIANCE WITH THE UNIVERSITY STANDARD. IF A STUDENT'S GPA FALLS BELOW THE MINIMUM REQUIREMENT, THE SCHOLARSHIP IS EITHER REMOVED OR REDUCED BY HALF. STUDENTS CAN APPEAL TO HAVE THE SCHOLARSHIP RESTORED IF THEIR GPA RETURNS TO THE REQUIRED LEVEL. NEED BASED SCHOLARSHIPS ARE CARRIED FORWARD EACH YEAR ONCE THE STUDENT HAS COMPLETED THE FAFSA. THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES ASSISTANCE TO CERTAIN LOCAL GOVERNMENTAL AND NOT-FOR-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS THAT PROVIDE CRITICAL INFRASTRUCTURAL SUPPORT TO THE UNIVERSITY. THE ASSISTANCE IS CONSIDERED A DONATION AND THE UNIVERSITY DOES NO FURTHER MONITORING OF THE USE OF THE FUNDS.

OTTAWA UNIVERSITY OFFERS ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS AND AWARDS. ALL FUNDS ARE AWARDED ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, SERVICE TO COMMUNITY, LEADERSHIP AND INVOLVEMENT IN SCHOOL ACTIVITIES. ALL SCHOLARSHIPS AND AWARDS ARE OFFERED FOR FOUR YEARS OF STUDY FOR FRESHMEN AND UNTIL THE COMPLETION OF DEGREE REQUIREMENTS FOR TRANSFER STUDENTS. ALL STUDENTS MUST MEET THE STATED CRITERIA TO MAINTAIN ELIGIBILITY. GRANTS EARNED BY THE STUDENT FROM EXTERNAL FUNDING SOURCES ARE FULLY CREDITED TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT WITHOUT REDUCING ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS AND AWARDS OFFERED BY OTTAWA UNIVERSITY. ACTIVITY AWARDS ARE OFFERED TO STUDENTS PARTICIPATING IN SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES BASED ON A COMPETITIVE REVIEW BY THE GRANTING DEPARTMENT. ACTIVITY AWARDS ARE AVAILABLE IN MUSIC, ART, THEATRE, FORENSICS, AND DEBATE. ATHLETIC AWARDS ARE OFFERED ON THE BASIS OF AN EVALUATION BY THE COACH OF EACH SPORT. OTTAWA UNIVERSITY OFFERS NEED BASED GRANTS TO STUDENTS WHO DEMONSTRATE AN EXCEPTIONAL LEVEL OF NEED AND THE POTENTIAL TO SUCCEED. OTTAWA UNIVERSITY IS COMMITTED TO BEING A RESIDENTIAL CAMPUS. FINANCIAL AID AWARDS ARE OFFERED TO ENCOURAGE STUDENTS TO LIVE ON-CAMPUS. OTTAWA UNIVERSITY IS ABLE TO HELP STUDENTS MEET A SIGNIFICANT PORTION OF THE DIRECT COST OF EDUCATION THROUGH A COMBINATION OF RESOURCES. STUDENTS ARE HIGHLY ENCOURAGED TO SUBMIT THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) TO DETERMINE ELIGIBILITY FOR ADDITIONAL GRANTS, WORK-STUDY PROGRAMS AND LOW-INTEREST LOANS. THE ADMINISTRATIVE SOFTWARE MONITORS FINANCIAL AID ON AN ONGOING BASIS FOR GRANTS, SCHOLARSHIPS AND OTHER AID THAT MAY BE PENDING, AWARDED, ETC. THIS INFORMATION IS THEN POSTED TO THE GENERAL LEDGER AS WELL FOR BALANCING/REPORTING PURPOSES.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2, Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
ExplntnTxt: SCHOLARSHIPS ARE PROVIDED TO STUDENTS BASED ON NEEDS ASSESSMENTS AND/OR PERFORMANCE. ONCE THE STUDENT HAS BEEN APPROVED TO RECEIVE THE GRANT, THE AMOUNT IS CREDITED TO THE STUDENT'S BAKER COLLEGE ACCOUNT. THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MONITORS THE STUDENT TO MAKE SURE THE AWARD STAYS IN COMPLIANCE. IF THE STUDENT DOES NOT CONTINUE TO MEET THE GRANT REQUIREMENTS, THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT MAY BE REDUCED. GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE TO ORGANIZATIONS IN THE UNITED STATES ARE BUDGETED EACH YEAR BY THE BAKER COLLEGE CAMPUS. THE CAMPUS PRESIDENT DETERMINES WHICH ORGANIZATION BENEFITS FROM A GRANT BASED ON THE COMMUNITY'S NEEDS. IF THE GRANT EXCEEDS THE BUDGET, THE BOARD OF REGENTS MUST APPROVE THE FUNDING. THESE GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE ARE AWARDED TO OTHER TAX-EXEMPT ORGANIZATIONS TO BE USED IN ANY WAY THE RECIPIENTS SEE FIT TO FURTHER THEIR MISSION AND TAX EXEMPT PURPOSE; THE USE OF THESE FUNDS IS NOT MONITORED BY THE BAKER COLLEGE CAMPUS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: FORM 990, SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: INSTITUTIONAL GIFT AID IS AWARDED IN VARIOUS FORMS VIA THE FOLLOWING SELECTION PROCESS: 1) ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS: THE SELECTION OF THESE STUDENTS IS MADE BY THE OFFICE OF THE UNDERGRADUATE, GRADUATE, PH D AND LAW ADMISSIONS, AND THE STUDENT'S APPLICATION FOR ADMISSION SERVES AS THE SCHOLARSHIP APPLICATION, 2) TALENT AWARDS (ATHLETICS AND MUSIC): THE DECISION REGARDING THE AWARD RECIPIENTS IS MADE BY THE APPROPRIATE DEPARTMENT AND/OR COACH. STUDENTS ARE EITHER RECRUITED OR NOMINATE THEMSELVES FOR AWARD CONSIDERATION. SELECTION IS USUALLY BASED UPON PERFORMANCES AND AUDITIONS, AND 3) NEED BASED AWARDS: THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE DETERMINES ELIGIBILITY BASED UPON THE FAFSA. SELECTION IS MADE WITHIN APPROPRIATE UNIVERSITY GUIDELINES. NOTE: DUE TO THE NATURE OF THE SCHOLARSHIPS/AWARDS, THE AMOUNTS ARE NETTED WITH REVENUES, WHICH IS CONSISTENT WITH THE AUDITED FINANCIAL PRESENTATION. THUS, THE AWARDS ARE NOT REPORTED AS GRANTS. STUDENT LOANS: ST. MARY'S PARTICIPATES IN TWO FEDERAL LOAN PROGRAMS: 1) THE CAMPUS-BASED FEDERAL PERKINS STUDENT LOAN PROGRAM, IN WHICH SELECTION OF STUDENT RECIPIENTS IS MADE BY THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE BASED UPON THE FAFSA AND FEDERAL REGULATIONS, AND 2) THE FFLEP PROGRAM, IN WHICH THE STUDENT SELF-SELECTS THE LENDER AND THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE CERTIFIES ELIGIBILITY BASED UPON FEDERAL REGULATIONS.

THE ORGANIZATION HAS SET PROCEDURES IN MONITORING AND DETERMINING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS. ELIGIBLE STUDENTS ARE CHOSEN AS GRANT RECIPIENTS BASED ON CRITERIA SUCH AS ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT AND FINANCIAL NEED.

Part I Line 2 THE UNIVERSITY GRANTS LISTED ON SCHEDULE I REPRESENT SCHOLARSHIPS OFFERED TO STUDENTS WHO MATRICULATE AT THE UNIVERSITY. AS SUCH, NO MONITORING OF THE GRANT FUNDS ARE REQUIRED BECAUSE THE STUDENT MAY ONLY USE THE SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS TO DEFRAY THE COST OF TUITION.
SCHOLARSHIPS ARE ISSUED AND AMOUNTS ARE USED TO OFFSET STUDENT TUITION.

FOR ALL SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS, STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES HAS ESTABLISHED SPECIFIC CRITERIA IN REGARDS TO ELIGIBILITY AND SELECTION. THE ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS OF THE STUDENTS ARE DOCUMENTED AND MONITORED FOR COMPLIANCE. THE ACTUAL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE CREDITED TO THE STUDENT'S TUITION BILLS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: Potential grant recipients complete application forms specific to particular grant funding sources. The Financial Aid office reviews applications to assure that eligibility requirements such as GPA, credit hours, residency and enrollment status are met. Student applicants receive an award letter identifying the funding programs and award amounts are applied as non-cash credit to student accounts receivable to further assure that proceeds are utilized for the intended purposes. The Registrar's office provides information such as withdrawal notices to facilitate the Financial Aid office in periodically monitoring eligibility criteria and assuring that funds not utilized for the intended purpose are returned to the original funding program.

A FILE IS CREATED FOR EACH GRANTEE, WHICH CONTAINS THE OFFICIAL INSTITUTIONAL STUDENT INFORMATION RECORD FROM THE FEDERAL PROCESSOR FROM WHICH ELIGIBILITY IS DETERMINED ACCORDING TO FEDERAL, STATE, AND INSTITUTIONAL GUIDELINES FOR THE AWARDING OF FINACIAL ASSISTANCE.

GRANTS (FEDERAL/STATE) PASSED THROUGH TO STUDENTS ARE MONITORED USING OUR INTERNAL APPLICATION (POWERFAIDS), THE STATE(PHEAA) AND FEDERAL (COD - COMMON ORIGINATION AND DISBURSEMENT) ELECTRONIC SYSTEMS. A VALIDATION OF RECORDS AMONG ALL THREE SYSTEMS IS CONDUCTED PERIODICALLY THROUGHOUT THE ACADEMIC YEAR AND FOR SEMESTER END RECONCILIATIONS. THOSE SYSTEMS VERIFY THE CRITERIA FOR THE GRANTS HAVE BEEN MET AND THE DOLLAR AMOUNTS RECEIVED HAVE BEEN DISSTRIBUTED APPROPRIATELY.
Schedule I, Part 1, line 2- Students receiving scholarships, grants, or other assistance, are evaluated on the basis of academic achievement, financial need, and other similar standards.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Procedures For Monitoring The Use Of Grant Funds To U.S.
ExplntnTxt: AFTER A STUDENT HAS BEEN ACCEPTED TO THE UNIVERSITY OF MOUNT UNION, THEY MUST FILE A FAFSA. MOUNT UNION CONSIDERS ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS, OUTSIDE SCHOLARSHIPS, FEDERAL GRANTS AND STATE ELIGIBILITY IN THAT RESPECTIVE ORDER. IF THE STUDENT NEEDS FURTHER ASSISTANCE, THE COLLEGE OFFERS FEDERAL LOANS, COLLEGE GRANTS AND EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITIES. FINANCIAL AID BASED ON NEED IS AWARDED ON FAFSA CALCULATIONS AND THE RESULTING FINANCIAL AID THAT IS TO BE MET. ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED ON HIGH SCHOOL GPA, CLASS RANK AND STANDARD TEST SCORES. NEED-BASED GRANTS CAN BE ALLOCATED TO RETURNING STUDENTS BASED ON PREVIOUS YEARS AS LONG AS FINANCIAL NEED IS STILL PRESENT. ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS CONTINUE BASED ON THE STUDENT'S CUMULATIVE GPA AT THE END OF THE YEAR.
THE USE OF FUNDS IS MONITORED VIA THE ACCOUNTS PAYABLE PROCESS. ALL FUNDS DISBURSED ARE REVIEWED FOR COMPLIANCE WITH DONOR INTENT.

St. John's University consistently strives to place an outstanding higher education within the financial reach of all qualified applicants. The University awards millions of dollars in federal and state financial aid funds each year based upon a student's financial need. Additionally, the University provides financial aid funding via University grants-in-aid, scholarships and tuition remission. Grants-in-aid are awarded on the basis of demonstrated financial need assessed by the use of a standard financial aid application, currently the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA), which analyzes the family income data provided on the FAFSA through the federally mandated Federal Methodology. All need-based financial aid must be awarded according to a student's calculated financial need. Scholarship awards are primarily provided on scholastic achievement. University scholarships are highly competitive and available to students through a combination of academic achievement and personal commitment, display of values, compassion and pursuit of excellence which embody the spirit and mission of the University. The University has many scholarships funded through special endowments and donations. In most instances, academic merit and financial need are considered along with the particular requirements of the scholarship selection process. Grants-in-aid are awarded to needy students and students who have special abilities or make significant contributions to the University. Additionally, various associations, corporations, foundations and unions provide scholarships for recipients whom they select.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS: TEXAS WESLEYAN UNIVERSITY'S OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID ADMINISTERS MULTIPLE FEDERAL, STATE, PRIVATE, AND UNIVERSITY GRANTS, SCHOLARSHIPS, LOAN AND WORK STUDY AWARDS. FEDERAL AND STATE PROGRAMS ARE ADMINISTERED ACCORDING TO THE U.S. LAW AND REGULATIONS PROMULGATED BY THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION AND THE U.S. DEPARTMENT HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES AS WELL AS THE REGULATIONS OF THE STATE OF TEXAS. UNIVERSITY SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS ARE ADMINISTERED ACCORDING TO THE POLICIES OF THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID IN SUPPORT OF THE UNIVERSITY'S STRATEGIC PLAN. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE USES THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) AND A NUMBER OF SUPPORTING DOCUMENTS OF VERIFICATION TO DETERMINE A STUDENT'S ELIGIBILITY FOR ALL NEED BASED PROGRAMS. ADDITIONALLY, STUDENTS' ELIGIBILITY IS DETERMINED BASED UPON ACADEMIC QUALIFICATIONS, SPECIAL TALENTS, AND DONOR STIPULATED REQUIREMENTS. POLICIES AND PROCEDURES ENSURE THAT THE DETERMINATION OF AID ELIGIBILITY AND THE SUBSEQUENT DELIVERY OF AID IS DELIVERED IN A FAIR AND EQUITABLE MANNER.

THE COLLEGE ISSUES SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS WHO ARE REQUIRED TO MATRICULATE AT THE COLLEGE. THE STUDENT DOES NOT HAVE ANY DISCRETION ON HOW FUNDS ARE USED; ALL FUNDS ARE USED TO DEFRAY THE COSTS OF PARTICIPATING IN THIS PROGRAM, THEREFORE, THE COLLEGE IS NOT REQUIRED TO FURTHER MONITOR THE USE OF THE FUNDS. THE COLLEGE MAINTAINS A COMPUTERIZED SYSTEM WITH INTEGRATED CONTROLS TO ENSURE THAT SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS ARE MADE IN ACCORDANCE WITH ESTABLISHED CRITERIA AS APPROVED BY SENIOR MANAGEMENT AND FEDERAL AND STATE AUTHORITIES, AS APPROPRIATE. A SERIES OF REPORTS HAVE BEEN DEVELOPED AND ARE USED BY MANAGEMENT TO IDENTIFY AND ADDRESS ANY EXCEPTIONS. ANNUALLY, THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID AWARDING PROCESS IS AUDITED BY AN INDEPENDENT ACCOUNTING FIRM. GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE TO GOVERNMENTS AND ORGANIZATIONS IN THE UNITED STATES ARE REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY THE COLLEGE'S PRESIDENT AND CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER. IN EACH CASE, THE COLLEGE IS AWARE OF THE CHARITABLE USE OF THE FUNDS, WHICH IS TYPICALLY FOR THE GENERAL PURSUIT OF THE RECEIVING ORGANIZATION'S EXEMPT PURPOSES AND NOT EARMARKED FOR A SPECIFIC USE. THE COLLEGE BELIEVES IN EACH INSTANCE THAT THESE FORMS OF ASSISTANCE ARE IN THE COLLEGE'S BEST INTEREST IN PROMOTING ITS IMAGE AND THE PURSUIT OF ITS EXEMPT PURPOSE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES FINANCIAL AID TO STUDENTS TO ENABLE THEM TO ATTEND THE UNIVERSITY. ALL FINANCIAL AID RECIPIENTS ARE SELECTED ON AN EQUAL OBJECTIVELY DETERMINABLE BASIS WITH OTHER RECIPIENTS. THAT IS, ALL STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS ARE JUDGED WORTHY BASED ON THE UNIVERSITY'S ASSESSMENT OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS. A LIST OF RECIPIENTS OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS IS ON FILE AT THE UNIVERSITY IN THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE.

THE COLLEGE PROVIDES PAYMENT OF THE GRANTS TO THE STUDENT AS A CREDIT TO THE STUDENTS' RECEIVABLE ACCOUNT; THE GRANTS ARE NOT DIRECTLY PAID TO THE STUDENTS. FOR THE GRANT TO BE AVAILABLE TO THE STUDENT, THE COLLEGE MONITORS THE STUDENTS ENROLLMENT AND THE STUDENT MUST BE ENROLLED AND ACTIVE FOR THE TIME PERIOD THE GRANT IS OFFERED. IF THE STUDENT LEAVES THE PROGRAM EARLY, THE GRANT IS NOT REFUNDED TO THE STUDENT AND THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT IS RATABLY ADJUSTED TO REFLECT THE INCOMPLETE PERIOD.

All grants are awarded to enrolled students based on either financial need or merit. Grants are applied directly to the student's account. Scholarships for financial need are determined by the Financial Aid Office. Scholarships for merit are determined by the Admissions Office.

THE COLLEGE'S OFFICE OF FINANCIAL PLANNING MONITORS ALL AWARDS TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH FEDERAL AND STATE REGULATIONS. ADDITIONALLY, THE COLLEGE ENGAGES AN INDEPENDENT AUDIT IN ACCORDANCE WITH OMB A-133.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: WISCONSIN SCHOOL OF PROFESSIONAL PSYCHOLOGY OFFERS A MINORITY SCHOLARSHIP TO QUALIFIED INCOMING MINORITY STUDENTS. ELIGIBILITY FOR THE SCHOLARSHIP IS BASED UPON MINORITY STATUS, PROVEN ACADEMIC EXCELLENCE, AS WELL AS FINANCIAL NEED

The Need-based Grant is funded by Alaska Bible College and utilized to assist students with a financial need. To qualify, a student must be enrolled full-time (12+ credits) in a degree or certificate program, must maintain a 2.0 GPA, and must maintain a current financial account with the Business Office. Students complete and submit an application along with financial information to help a committee determine each student's financial need. Decisions are made by the committee and awards are given after the 6-week grade check each semester.
IN THE 2013/2014 FISCAL YEAR, THE GRANTEES WERE APPROVED BY THE UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT AND CONFIRMED WITH THE EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT.
The University of the Incarnate Word determines whether an individual qualifies for scholarships or grants by an application process that does not discriminate.

Grant applications are reviewed and approved by the appropriate financial aid professionals. Upon approval, funds are applied directly to the student's account as an offset against charges such as tuition and fees. Grants cannot exceed the student's Cost of Attendance (COA). In the event that the COA is reduced due to a decrease in the student's course load or other circumstances impacting School charges, the related grant is accordingly reduced.

ENDOWED AND ANNUAL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED ON CERTAIN CRITERIA SET BY THE INSTITUTION (DUNWOODY) AND DONORS. STUDENTS APPLY FOR SCHOLARSHIPS STARTING SPRING QUARTER OF THE PREVIOUS SCHOOL YEAR. APPLICATIONS ARE COMPILED AND REVIEWED BY A SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE. THE SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE CHOOSES THE STUDENT OR STUDENTS WHO ARE MOST DESERVING OF THE AWARD BASED ON THE CRITERIA AND FINANCIAL NEED. STUDENTS ARE NOTIFIED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE OF THE ACCEPTANCE TO THE AWARDS WHICH THEN BECOME PART OF THEIR FINANCIAL AID PACKAGE. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE DISBURSED TO THE STUDENTS ACCOUNT AS A CREDIT ON A QUARTERLY BASIS WHICH REDUCES THEIR TUITION. STUDENTS ARE REQUIRED TO WRITE A THANK YOU NOTE TO THE DONORS OF THE SCHOLARSHIP SHOWING THEIR APPRECIATION. IF A THANK YOU NOTE ISN'T WRITTEN, THE STUDENT DOESN'T RECEIVE THE SCHOLARSHIP. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE MONITORED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. IF A STUDENT WITHDRAWS FROM SCHOOL, THE SCHOLARSHIP IS REVOKED.
ALL STUDENT AID AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE USED FOR TUITION AND RELATED EXPENSES AT THE COLLEGE.

SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE REPRESENT STUDENT FINANCIAL AID. WHEN AWARDING AID, BRANDMAN UNIVERSITY FOLLOWS ALL LAWS AND REGULATIONS OF FEDERAL AND STATE OF CALIFORNIA AID PROGRAMS. FOR MORE INFORMATION, VISIT OUR WEBSITE AT WWW.BRANDMAN.EDU.

GRANTS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS. THE COLLEGE MONITORS STUDENT TUITION ACCOUNTS FOR ANY STUDENT WHO RECEIVED A SCHOLARSHIP OR TUITION CREDIT. THE BURSAR'S OFFICE AND THE ADMISSIONS OFFICE ENSURE THAT STUDENTS WHO RECEIVE SCHOLARSHIPS OR TUITION CREDITS MAINTAIN FULL-TIME OR PART-TIME STUDENT STATUS AND MEET ALL OTHER REQUIREMENTS, AS REQUIRED BY THE AWARDED SCHOLARSHIP, SO THAT THE FUNDS ARE USED FOR THEIR INTENDED PURPOSE.

The College has established programs for each type of scholarship and awards funds according to the parameters of each program and as funding is available. The scholarships and grants are awarded to students to be used for educational expenses at the College including tuition, fees, and books. The awards are allocated directly to each student's account.

THE UNIVERSITY HAS A FINANCIAL AID OFFICE WHICH IS CHARGED WITH THE RESPONSIBILITY OF APPLYING SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS IN COMPLIANCE WITH ALL FEDERAL REQUIREMENTS, DONOR RESTRICTIONS ON ENDOWMENT INCOME TO BE USED FOR SCHOLARSHIPS AND INTERNAL POLICIES FOR INSTITUTIONAL SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS IN RELATION TO ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2, Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
ExplntnTxt: SCHOLARSHIPS ARE PROVIDED TO STUDENTS BASED ON NEEDS ASSESSMENTS AND/OR PERFORMANCE. ONCE THE STUDENT HAS BEEN APPROVED TO RECEIVE THE GRANT, THE AMOUNT IS CREDITED TO THE STUDENT'S BAKER COLLEGE ACCOUNT. THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MONITORS THE STUDENT TO MAKE SURE THE AWARD STAYS IN COMPLIANCE. IF THE STUDENT DOES NOT CONTINUE TO MEET THE GRANT REQUIREMENTS, THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT MAY BE REDUCED. GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE TO ORGANIZATIONS IN THE UNITED STATES ARE BUDGETED EACH YEAR BY THE BAKER COLLEGE CAMPUS. THE CAMPUS PRESIDENT DETERMINES WHICH ORGANIZATION BENEFITS FROM A GRANT BASED ON THE COMMUNITY'S NEEDS. IF THE GRANT EXCEEDS THE BUDGET, THE BOARD OF REGENTS MUST APPROVE THE FUNDING. THESE GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE ARE AWARDED TO OTHER TAX-EXEMPT ORGANIZATIONS TO BE USED IN ANY WAY THE RECIPIENTS SEE FIT TO FURTHER THEIR MISSION AND TAX EXEMPT PURPOSE; THE USE OF THESE FUNDS IS NOT MONITORED BY THE BAKER COLLEGE CAMPUS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: THE STUDENTS' FINANCIAL AND ACADEMIC STANDING IS MONITORED BY THE OFFICE OF STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES TO ENSURE THAT THE STUDENTS REMAIN IN GOOD STANDING AND CONTINUE TO MEET ANY SPECIFIC REQUIREMENTS OF THE SCHOLARSHIP OR GRANT. THE UNIVERSITY UNDERGOES AN AUDIT UNDER CIRCULAR A-133 TO AUDIT COMPLIANCE WITH FEDERAL FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE RULES AND REGULATIONS.

THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS BASED ON ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA PREDETERMINED BY DONORS AND COLLEGE POLICIES. ALL AWARDS ARE APPLIED TO TUITION AND RELATED EDUCATION EXPENSES ONLY.

THE UNIVERSITY AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON THE CRITERIA OF THE DONOR AND/OR THE UNIVERSITY. IF THE STUDENT MEETS THE PROGRAMMED RULES FOR A SCHOLARSHIP AND THE STUDENT IS REGISTERED FOR THE APPROPRIATE NUMBER OF CREDITS, THE FUNDS WILL BE TRANSMITTED TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT. ALL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE APPLIED TO THE DIRECT COSTS OF THE STUDENT, INCLUDING TUITION, FEES, ROOM AND BOARD. THE UNIVERSITY ALSO MONITORS THE ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE OF EACH STUDENT TO MAKE SURE THAT HE/SHE IS MEETING THE ACADEMIC REQUIREMENTS FOR EACH SCHOLARSHIP.

The Organization made grants to section 501(c)(3) organizations only. Therefore, additional monitoring was not deemed necessary.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2, Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
ExplntnTxt: BY INSTITUTIONAL POLICY, TCU'S OFFICE OF SCHOLARSHIP AND FINANCIAL AID ACTS AS THE FINAL APPROVAL AUTHORITY FOR ALL FINANCIAL AID ELIGIBILITY DETERMINATION. EACH STUDENT'S AWARD PACKAGE IS REVIEWED TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH APPLICABLE REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS, AND IN THE CASE OF RESTRICTED INSTITUTIONAL FUNDS, WITH THE DONOR'S INTENT AND WISHES. ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIP ELIGIBILITY IS BASED ON A SCORING MATRIX THAT EVALUATES AN INDIVIDUAL STUDENT'S SUCCESS USING NATIONAL TEST SCORES, RANK IN CLASS, AND HIGH SCHOOL GPA. THOSE WHO HAVE EXCELLED ACADEMICALLY ARE GENERALLY GIVEN THE LARGEST SHARE OF UNIVERSITY FUNDED DOLLARS. INSTITUTIONALLY FUNDED NEED-BASED FINANCIAL AID PROGRAMS ARE BASED ON ELIGIBILITY ESTABLISHED BY THE FAFSA. STUDENTS APPLYING FOR NEED-BASED GRANTS ARE REQUIRED TO SUBMIT THE CSS PROFILE APPLICATION. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE ALSO WORKS CLOSELY WITH THE DONOR RELATIONS DIVISION OF UNIVERSITY ADVANCEMENT TO ENSURE THAT OUR DONORS' WISHES ARE MET WHEN MATCHING FUNDS TO STUDENTS. ALL DONORS OF ENDOWED AWARDS ARE PROVIDED WITH A "SCHOLARSHIP AGREEMENT" OUTLINING THE UNIVERSITY'S UNDERSTANDING OF THE DONOR'S INTENT. THESE AGREEMENTS MUST BE APPROVED BY BOTH THE DIRECTOR OF FINANCIAL AID, AND THE VICE-CHANCELLOR FOR ADVANCEMENT, TO ENSURE THAT THE UNIVERSITY HAS THE CAPABILITY TO IDENTIFY APPROPRIATE RECIPIENTS. IN ADDITION TO INSTITUTIONALLY FUNDED GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS, TCU MANAGES AND ACCEPTS FIDUCIARY RESPONSIBILITY FOR A VARIETY OF FEDERAL AND STATE FUNDED FINANCIAL AID PROGRAMS. ELIGIBILITY FOR TITLE IV FEDERAL FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AND STATE FUNDED NEED-BASED AID PROGRAMS IS DETERMINED USING FEDERAL METHODOLOGY AND REQUIRES THE SUBMISSION OF THE FAFSA. PRIOR TO DISBURSEMENT, EACH RECIPIENT MUST PASS A VARIETY OF EDIT CHECKS, OR "DISBURSEMENT RULES" TO ENSURE THAT THE STUDENT IS ENROLLED IN CLASSES AND HAS SUBMITTED ALL REQUIRED DOCUMENTATION NEEDED TO SATISFY PROGRAM ELIGIBILITY. AFTER DISBURSEMENT, STUDENT AID RECIPIENTS ARE REVIEWED AT THE END OF THE 100% TUITION REFUND PERIOD FOR A FINAL ENROLLMENT STATUS DETERMINATION. STUDENTS WHO RECEIVED AID BASED ON PROJECTED FULL-TIME ENROLLMENT, BUT WHO HAVE DROPPED BELOW 12 CREDIT HOURS, ARE SUBJECT TO AN ADJUSTMENT OF THEIR AID PACKAGE. AT THE END OF THE 25%, AND FINAL REFUND PERIOD, STUDENTS ARE AGAIN REVIEWED AND SUBJECT TO AID ADJUSTMENT BASED ON FINAL COSTS FOR THE TERM. AID RECIPIENTS ARE MONITORED ON A REGULAR BASIS THROUGHOUT THE ACADEMIC YEAR. FILES ARE REVIEWED WEEKLY TO IDENTIFY UPDATED FAFSA APPLICATIONS FROM THE FEDERAL PROCESSOR AND ADJUSTMENTS ARE MADE WHEN REQUIRED. REPORTS ARE SUBMITTED TO THE TEXAS HIGHER EDUCATION COORDINATING BOARD PERIODICALLY FOR REVIEW OF STATE AID RECIPIENTS, AND THE UNIVERSITY IS SUBJECT TO PERIODIC AUDITS AND REVIEWS FROM BOTH ENTITIES. ACADEMIC SUCCESS IS THE ULTIMATE GOAL OF ALL AID PROGRAMS, AND SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS IS REVIEWED AT THE END OF EACH TERM. AT A MINIMUM, FULL-TIME STUDENTS ARE REQUIRED TO COMPLETE AT LEAST 24 CREDIT HOURS AND OBTAIN A 2.00 GPA TO MEET RENEWAL REQUIREMENTS. MOST TCU FUNDED AWARDS REQUIRE A MINIMUM GPA OF 2.50. ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS REQUIRE A 3.25 GPA. ONCE POSTED TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS, THE OFFICE OF STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES ALSO MONITORS AWARD AMOUNTS IN RELATION TO SPECIFIC CHARGES. AWARD AMOUNTS THAT APPEAR TO BE OUT OF NORM ARE REFERRED BACK TO THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE FOR REVIEW.

Several procedures and reports are used annually to monitor financial aid including: The University has in place internal controls to ensure amounts are awarded to students who continue to meet and maintain elegibility requirements. These internal controls are administered by the University's financial aid office;Independent auditors complete the A-133 audit relating to federal student aid; The FISAP report for the Department of Education; Common Data Set (CDS) which is a set of standards and definitions among the higher education community & publishers as represented by the College Board, Peterson's, U.S. News & World Report & the Wintergreen Orchard House.

THE UNIVERSITY AWARDS GRANTS/SCHOLARSHIPS ACCORDING TO UNIVERSITY POLICY. GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED TO STUDENTS ARE MONITORED BY MANAGEMENT. RECONCILIATION BETWEEN FINANCIAL AID AND ACCOUNTING ARE DONE ON A MONTHLY BASIS. Schedule I, Part III Cash grants are credited to student accounts.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Procedure for Monitoring Use of Grant Funds Inside U.S.
ExplntnTxt: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Contributions made by the University to other charitable organizations are made pursuant to University policy. Contributions by the University are made where they further the University's mission or its role as a good community citizen. All grants, including sub-grants, are accounted for separately by the University's financial accounting system and each is managed by a principal investigator. Financial activity reports are provided to principal investigators on a daily basis, with reconciliation of financial reports required on a monthly basis. Sub-grants are further monitored by obtaining a grantee's A-133 audits and evaluating the grantee's ability to comply with the terms of the sub-grant. All grant monitoring is subject to the policies and procedures of the University, which are designed to meet federal requirements. The University's Office of Institutional Compliance, Office of Research Services, Restricted Accounting and others are charged with ensuring that all DePaul employees are aware of their responsibilities in developing and maintaining a compliance-conscious environment. Additionally, the Office of Institutional Compliance, Office of Research Services, Restricted Accounting, Principal Investigators and others are charged with ensuring that the University's policies and procedures, as well as local, state and federal laws are followed. This is accomplished through conducting risk assessments, monitoring operational activities, providing online, classroom and/or one-on-one training and other tools that foster compliance. Grants and assistance to students represents financial assistance in the form of institutional scholarships. All scholarships are administered through the University's financial aid system. Institutional scholarships are credited to the student's internal tuition account and represent an offset to tuition and other fees assessed by the University. Grants and assistance to University staff and their eligible spouse, dependents, or an unrelated second domiciled adult represent staff tuition waivers, pursuant to a written benefits plan. Staff tuition waivers are administered through the University's benefits system and, like institutional scholarships for students, are credited to the individual's internal tuition account to offset tuition charges. Taxability of tuition waivers is determined pursuant to sections 127 and 117(d) of the Internal Revenue Code.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING OF SCHOLARSHIPS - THE BUSINESS OFFICE NOTIFIES THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE OF AMOUNTS AVAILABLE TO AWARD TO STUDENTS EACH ACADEMIC YEAR. FINANCIAL AID OFFICE SELECTS RECIPIENTS BASED UPON CRITERIA ESTABLISHED FOR EACH TYPE OF FUNDING. FINANCIAL AID OFFICE NOTIFIES THE BUSINESS OFFICE OF EXPENDITURES FOR EACH TERM DURING THE ACADEMIC YEAR. AT YEAR-END, FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AND BUSINESS OFFICE RECONCILE ACCOUNTS FOR ALL FUNDS. FOR DONOR-CONTRIBUTED SCHOLARSHIPS (ENDOWED OR ANNUALLY FUNDED), THE DEVELOPMENT OFFICE PROVIDES ANNUAL REPORTS TO THE DONORS REGARDING THE USE OF THOSE FUNDS. PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING RESEARCH GRANTS - THERE ARE SEVERAL DIFFERENT DEPARTMENTS THAT OFFER RESEARCH GRANTS AT WILLAMETTE. EACH DEPARTMENT HAS DIFFERENT MONITORING PROCEDURES FOR THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS. HOWEVER, THE MONITORING PROCEDURES TYPICALLY INVOLVE THE FOLLOWING: A WRITTEN AND/OR VERBAL REPORT ON THE RESEARCH PROJECT MUST BE SUBMITTED DURING AND/OR AT THE CONCLUSION OF THE PROJECT; RECEIPTS MUST BE SUBMITTED FOR REIMBURSEMENT OF PROJECT EXPENDITURES. FINAL PAYMENT OF GRANT FUNDS IS OFTEN CONTINGENT ON THE AFOREMENTIONED ITEMS. THE DEPARTMENT THAT AWARDS THE GRANTS HANDLES THE RELATED MONITORING OF THOSE GRANT FUNDS. PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING OTHER AWARDS AND PRIZES - AWARD/PRIZE RECIPIENTS ARE DETERMINED BY CRITERIA ESTABLISHED BY THE RESPECTIVE DEPARTMENTS. DEPARTMENTS WORK WITH THE ACCOUNTING OFFICE TO MAKE SURE THAT THE AWARD FUNDS ARE DISBURSED TO THE CORRECT STUDENT OR FACULTY MEMBER.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: ORGANIZATION'S PROCEDURE FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS
ExplntnTxt: PART I, LINE 2 THE COLLEGE'S OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID IS RESPONSIBLE FOR AWARDING AND MONITORING ALL FEDERAL AND STATE GRANT ASSISTANCE. STUDENTS APPLY FOR FINANCIAL AID BY COMPLETING A FAFSA FORM WHICH CAPTURES THE DATA REQUIRED DETERMINING ELIGIBILITY BASED ON FEDERAL AND/OR STATE REGULATIONS. DOCUMENTATION TO SUPPORT ELIGIBILITY IS KEPT FOR EACH INDIVIDUAL STUDENT ON FILE IN THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. WHEN FUNDS ARE AWARDED, STUDENT ELIGIBILITY IS MONITORED THROUGH THE COLLEGE'S OPERATIONAL SYSTEM AID MODULE TO ENSURE THERE ARE NO CHANGES IN STATUS THAT MIGHT AFFECT THEIR ONGOING ELIGIBILITY. TOTAL GRANT FUNDS AWARDED ARE TRACKED TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH AUTHORIZED AMOUNTS FROM THE FUNDING AGENCY. THE COLLEGE ALSO IS REQUIRED TO SUBMIT AN ANNUAL INDEPENDENT A-133 AUDIT TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH ALL FEDERAL REGULATIONS FOR GRANT ASSISTANCE. THE SCHOLARSHIP OFFICE IS RESPONSIBLE FOR AWARDING AND MONITORING ALL INSTITUTIONAL SCHOLARSHIP ASSISTANCE. CONTINUING STUDENTS APPLY FOR SCHOLARSHIP AID BY COMPLETING A SCHOLARSHIP APPLICATION FORM WHICH CAPTURES THE DATA REQUIRED TO DETERMINE ELIGIBILITY BASED ON INSTITUTIONAL GUIDELINES. ENTERING STUDENTS ARE AUTOMATICALLY CONSIDERED FOR SCHOLARSHIP BASED ON THE COLLEGE'S AUDITION AND INTERVIEW PROCESS. DOCUMENTATION TO SUPPORT ELIGIBILITY IS KEPT FOR EACH INDIVIDUAL STUDENT ON FILE IN THE SCHOLARSHIP OFFICE. WHEN FUNDS ARE AWARDED, STUDENT ELIGIBILITY IS MONITORED THROUGH THE COLLEGE'S OPERATIONAL SYSTEM SCHOLARSHIP MODULE TO ENSURE THERE ARE NO CHANGES IN STATUS THAT MIGHT AFFECT THEIR ONGOING ELIGIBILITY. TOTAL SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS AWARDED ARE TRACKED TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH BUDGETED AMOUNTS. THE SCHOLARSHIP OFFICE REVIEWS ALL AWARDS EACH SEMESTER TO DETERMINE THAT THE STUDENT IS STILL ELIGIBLE FOR THE SCHOLARSHIP.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: FORM 990, SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: MONITORING OF GRANT USE ALL GRANTS ARE APPLIED TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS AFTER VERIFYING ENROLLMENT STATUS ON AN INDIVIDUAL BASIS.

APPLICANTS FOR FINANCIAL AID MUST FILL OUT THE FEDERALLY MANDATED FAFSA FORM. THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION ESTABLISHES A LEVEL OF NEED FOR AID BASED ON THE FAMILY'S TOTAL FINANCIAL SITUATION. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AT COLORADO HEIGHTS UNIVERSITY DETERMINES A STUDENT'S FINANCIAL AID AWARD AFTER REVIEWING THE RESULTS OF THE FAFSA APPLICATION. APPLICATIONS ARE REVIEWED AS THEY ARE COMPLETED AND FUNDS ARE AWARDED ON A FIRST-COME, FIRST-SERVED BASIS TO STUDENTS WITH THE GREATEST NEED. FINANCIAL AID AWARDS MAY INCLUDE A COMBINATION OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS. FINANCIAL AID IS CREDITED TO THE STUDENT'S BILL EACH TERM AFTER THE REGISTRAR CONFIRMS ENROLLMENT STATUS AND THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE DETERMINES ELIGIBILITY.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS: SCHOLARSHIPS AND PRIZES ARE AWARDED BASED ON NEED AND MONITORED ANNUALLY BASED ON STUDENTS' ACADEMIC PROFILES AND GUIDELINES AS PROVIDED TO STUDENTS. THESE GUIDELINES ARE ALSO AVAILABLE TO STUDENTS ON THE SKIDMORE COLLEGE WEBSITE.
THE ORGANIZATION AWARDS TUITION SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS OF THIS INSTITUTION AND ARE IMMEDIATELY APPLIED AGAINST THE STUDENT'S TUITION CHARGES.

THE PROCESS FOR MONITORING TUITION DISCOUNT OR GRANT/SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS AT LEES-MCRAE IS DONE BY UTILIZING A MATRIX THAT DETERMINES AND LIMITS THE AMOUNT OF ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIP AWARDED. THE VICE PRESIDENT OF ADMISSIONS AND ENROLLMENT AND THE DIRECTOR OF FINANCIAL AID MEET REGULARLY TO REVIEW THE MOST CURRENT AMOUNT OF AWARDS BEING AWARDED TO ENSURE THE COLLEGE STAYS WITHIN BUDGE AND AWARD GUIDELINES. A FINAL REVIEW IS DONE BY THE VICE PRESIDENT OF ADMISSIONS AND ENROLLMENT AND THE DIRECTOR OF FINANCIAL AID PRIOR TO AWARD LETTERS BEING MAILED.
SCHOLARSHIPS ARE GENERALLY APPLIED TO STUDENT ACCOUNT BALANCES THROUGH THE COLLEGE'S BURSAR'S OFFICE.

THE COLLEGE MAKES GRANTS TO STUDENTS BASED UPON FINANCIAL NEED AND ACADEMIC EXCELLENCE. THE SELECTION OF GRANT RECIPIENTS IS MADE BASED UPON OBJECTIVE CRITERIA. NO ONE IS DISCRIMINATED AGAINST BASED UPON RACE, RELIGION, GENDER, ETHNIC BACKGROUND, AGE, HANDICAP OR ANY OTHER REASON. THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT ASSESSES AND MONITORS THE ELIGIBILITY AND AWARDING OF GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS. IT IS ASSISTED IN ITS ON-GOING REVIEW BY THE RESOURCES OF THE REGISTRAR AND STUDENT ACCOUNTS DEPARTMENTS.

GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE IN FURTHERANCE OF THE INSTITUTION'S EXEMPT PROGRAMS ARE MAYE IN ACCORDANCE WITH PROCEDURES OR ARE SUBJECT TO CONDITIONS ESTABLISHED BY THE INSTITUTION'S GOVERNING BOARD DESIGNED TO ENSURE THAT INDIVIDUALS RECEIVING GRANTS ARE ADEQUATELY INVESTIGATED TO ENSURE THAT THEY ARE QUALIFYING RECIPIENTS. STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIP GRANTS ARE JUDGED WORTHY BY THE INSTITUTION'S ASSESSMENT ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED, AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: PART III GRANTS TO INDIVIDUALS - REGARDING THE MONITORING OF GRANTS\SCHOLARSHIPS TO INDIVIDUALS, ALL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS CURRENTLY ENROLLED AND ELIGIBLE FOR THE AWARDED AMOUNTS. THE AWARDS ARE APPLIED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT.THE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE APPLIED AND USED TO PAY FOR THE EDUCATIONAL COSTS AS DESCRIBED BY THE ENDOWED SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS.
