THE UNIVERSITY DOES NOT GIVE ANY NON-CASH SCHOLARSHIPS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE DISBURSED TO STUDENTS THROUGH CREDITING THEIR STUDENT ACCOUNTS. IF THE STUDENT HAS EXCESS SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS AS THE RESULT OF TITLE IV AID, THEN THESE FUNDS ARE AUTOMATICALLY DISBURSED TO THE STUDENT BY CHECK WITHIN 14 DAYS. IF THE EXCESS FUNDS ARE THE RESULT OF SOMETHING OTHER THAN TITLE IV AID, THE STUDENT MUST REQUEST A REFUND AND THESE FUNDS ARE DISBURSED TO THE STUDENT BY CHECK. THE UNIVERSITY'S PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING GRANT FUNDS IN THE U. S. ARE AS FOLLOWS: THE UNIVERSITY HAS APPOINTED DIRECTORS, WHO REPORT TO THE APPROPRIATE VICE PRESIDENTS, OVER ALL FEDERAL GRANT PROGRAMS. THESE DIRECTORS ARE CHARGED WITH PERFORMING ALL GRANT-RELATED ACTIVITIES INCLUDING APPLICATION, MONITORING OF EXPENDITURES AND REPORTING, WITH THE EXCEPTION OF DRAW-DOWNS OF FEDERAL FUNDS. DRAW-DOWNS ARE PERFORMED BY THE UNIVERSITY'S CONTROLLER AFTER REQUESTS ARE MADE BY THE DIRECTOR TO THE CONTROLLER. THE CONTROLLER REVIEWS THE REQUESTS FOR DRAW-DOWNS, WHICH INCLUDE DOCUMENTATION OF ALL DIRECT AND INDIRECT PROGRAM EXPENSES, BEFORE MAKING THE DRAW-DOWNS. A SINGLE AUDIT IS PERFORMED ANNUALLY BY THE UNIVERSITY'S INDEPENDENT AUDITORS.

FOR ALL SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS, STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES HAS ESTABLISHED SPECIFIC CRITERIA IN REGARDS TO ELIGIBILITY AND SELECTION. THE ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS OF THE STUDENTS ARE DOCUMENTED AND MONITORED FOR COMPLIANCE. THE ACTUAL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE CREDITED TO THE STUDENT'S TUITION BILLS. NO SCHOLARSHIPS OR GRANTS ARE AWARDED DIRECTLY TO THE RECIPIENTS.
The Business Office receives a copy of all grant contacts and reconciles project expenses monthly.
GRANT FUNDS ARE RECORDED IN A PROJECT ACCOUNT SO THAT ALL ASSOCIATED REVENUES AND EXPENSES ARE ACCOUNTED FOR RELATED TO A SPECIFIC GRANT.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS Annually tuition discount expenditures are projected and budgeted for the upcomiNg budget cycle. Projections are prepared by the Director of Student Administrative Services, delivered to the Director of Budget and submitted for approval to the Executive Vice President of Finance and the Board of Trustees. Various constituencies across campus are "allocated" a certain amount of funding to award to students, within the budgeted amounts. These awards are submitted to the Executive Vice President of Finance for approval and then routed to the Director of Student Administrative Services who then, through the Director of Financial Aid, oversees the packaging of these awards and integration with other financial aid awards to insure that no students with federal financial aid are over-awarded. Since these awards are tuition-based, they are posted to students' accounts each quarter once schedules are locked and total tuition amounts can be verified by the Director of Student Accounts and staff. Quarterly, the Director of Student Administrative Services compares actual expenses to budgeted amounts and alerts the budget manager of any potential overages. The budget is reviewed in each case to make sure overages will not cause fiscal issues. If it appears that they will, adjustments are recommended by the Director of Budget to the Executive Vice President of Finance.

THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS MATRICULATING AT THE UNIVERSITY FOR VARIOUS REASONS INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE, STUDENT INSTITUTIONAL AID AND ATHLETIC. THEREFORE, ALL FUNDS GRANTED ARE USED TO DEFRAY THE COST OF TUITION AND NO FURTHER MONITORING OF THE GRANTS IS REQUIRED.

STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS ARE JUDGED WORTHY BY THE INSTITUTION'S ASSESSMENT THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED, AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS. THE UNIVERSITY DETERMINES WHO QUALIFIES FOR LOANS BASED ON ANALYSIS BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. LOANS ARE AWARDED AS PART OF A PACKAGE CONSISTING OF FEDERAL GRANTS, FEDERAL AND UNIVERSITY LOANS, FEDERAL WORK-STUDY AND UNIVERSITY SCHOLARSHIPS. IN ALL CASES, THOSE WHO RECEIVE LOANS HAVE DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED AND HAVE COMPLETED A FEDERAL FINANCIAL AID APPLICATION FORM. THE AMOUNTS RECEIVED ARE ADDED TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT TO OFFSET THE COST OF TUITION AND FEES.

Procedure for Monitoring Grants: Grants to organizations and individuals awarded for the purpose of conducting research are monitored as follows: Subcontracts are issued with a defined scope of work and a budget and include other terms and conditions such as frequency of required reporting. The faculty member at the University of Miami responsible for the grant monitors the scientific progress via site visits, correspondence, reports, etc. Invoices submitted for payments by the outside organization or by an individual are approved by the University of Miami Faculty member responsible for the grant.

Assistance to the University students in the form of scholarships are awarded for the purpose of aiding with the cost of attending the University (i.e., for tuition, housing and meals). Scholarships are based on need and academic achievement. Total scholarships, grants and loans cannot exceed the total cost of attendance. The University publishes criteria for the eligibility requirements needed to award a scholarship. The amount of aid awarded is based on a need analysis formula developed by the federal government and includes verification of the information submitted by the student.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2, Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
ExplntnTxt: THE UNIVERSITY AWARDS GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS TO ENROLLED STUDENTS. GRANTS ARE CREDITED TO THE RECIPIENTS' ACCOUNTS FOR TUITION, FEES, ROOM AND BOARD.

HOBART AND WILLIAM SMITH COLLEGES OFFER GRANTS TO STUDENTS ON THE BASIS OF DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED AND/OR ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT. STUDENTS AND THEIR FAMILIES SUBMIT STANDARDIZED APPLICATION MATERIALS TO THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID, WHICH OVERSEES THE PROCESS OF AWARDING SUCH GRANTS. ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA FOR THE VARIOUS GRANTS IS ESTABLISHED BY THE COLLEGES. THE COLLEGES CREDIT THE TUITION ACCOUNTS OF THE STUDENTS WHO ARE AWARDED FINANCIAL AID GRANTS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: Each transaction involving grants and financial aid is monitored through the student account. In addition, the university undergoes audits of its financial aid.

VF AWARDS INTERNAL MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON THE CADET'S GRADES (GPA) FROM HIS / HER PREVIOUS SCHOOL AND FINANCIAL NEED. THERE IS A MATRIX USED TO DETERMINE THE AMOUNT TO BE AWARDED TO EACH CADET. THERE ARE ALSO AID AWARDS WHICH ARE BASED ON SUBMITTED FAFSA FORMS. BOTH FEDERAL AND STATE GOVERNMENTS HAVE CHARTS DETERMINING AID SUCH AS THROUGH PHEAA AND PELL GRANTS.

ALL FIRST-TIME STUDENTS TO MITCHELL COLLEGE ARE REVIEWED FOR MERIT AID. THERE IS NO SEPARATE APPLICATION PROCESS. IF STUDENTS ARE AWARDED MERIT AID, THE NOTIFICATION LETTER WILL BE SENT ABOUT TWO WEEKS AFTER THEIR ACCEPTANCE LETTER ARRIVES. MERIT AID IS BASED ON ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE AND/OR COMMUNITY SERVICE INVOLVEMENT. STUDENTS WHO ARE INTERESTED IN OBTAINING NEED BASED AID, EITHER FROM FEDERAL AND STATE RESOURCES OR MITCHELL COLLEGES OWN FUNDS MUST COMPLETE THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) AT WWW.FAFSA.ED.GOV. FINANCIAL AID, SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS AWARDED IS APPLIED TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS THROUGH A REDUCTION IN TUITION CHARGES.

The College has a professionally staffed financial aid office charged with the responsibility of ensuring that all recipients meet all eligibility criteria ensuring that the College is in compliance with all government regulations pertaining to financial aid.
THE ORGANIZATION EMPLOYS INDIVIDUALS RESPONSIBLE FOR MONITORING SUBCONTRACTS AND REQUIRES DOCUMENTATION TO SUPPORT REQUESTED REIMBURSEMENT.

All scholarships are awarded upon specific criteria maintained by the Financial Aid Office. Requirements for receiving scholarships depends on other factors such as grade point average family income or economic need. The Colleges financial aid staff monitors guidelines to ensure compliance. The College also undergoes the required OMB A-133 audit annually.

Harding University awards financial assistance to its students on the basis of verified financial need or merit and does not unlawfully discriminate on the basis of race, color, national or ethnic origin, religion, age, sex, disability or prior military service. Financial assistance is monitored so that it is in compliance with awarding terms and conditions. Expenditures are reviewed for allowability and compliance. Students are required to submit appropriate documents prior to approval.
Cash grants are credits to student accounts.
THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MONITORS COMPLIANCE WITH GRANT/SCHOLARSHIP CRITERIA ON AN INDIVIDUAL STUDENT BASIS.
SCHEDULE I, PART 1, LINE 2: ANNA MARIA COLLEGE PARTICIPATES IN TITLE IV FUNDING. STUDENTS MUST COMPLETE THE FAFSA FORM TO APPLY FOR AID.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2, Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
ExplntnTxt: PRINCIPIA DISTRIBUTES GRANT AND SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS ONLY TO STUDENTS WHO APPLY THROUGH AN OFFICIAL FINANCIAL AID PROCESS. ALL GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE APPLIED TO THE STUDENT'S PRINCIPIA ACCOUNT TO OFFSET TUITION, ROOM, BOARD AND FEES. ALL GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE FROM INSTITUTIONAL FUNDS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I - Organization's Procedures for Monitoring the Use of Grants
ExplntnTxt: Scholarships - There are no transfer of funds between Dance Theatre of Harlem and students. Grants received for scholarships are designed such and regular reports are provided to donors on expenditures and impact. The School Business Affairs Officer provides detailed reports on scholarship allocation to the finance office on a regular basis.

SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO THE STUDENTS BASED ON DIFFERENT CRITERIA. THE UNIVERSITY FOLLOWS ALL POLICIES AND REGULATIONS OF FEDERAL AID PROGRAMS WHEN IT AWARDS FINANCIAL AID TO STUDENTS. THE UNIVERSITY REQUIRES THE GRANTEE ORGANIZATIONS TO SUBMIT REPORTS TO SUPPORT THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS.

Piedmont College participates in the student financial assistance programs through the U.S. Department of Education. Funds are awarded and disbursed to students based on the Department of Education guidelines set forth by the Title IV programs.

THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE IS CHARGED WITH DETERMINING ELIGIBILITY, ALLOCATIONS OF GRANT FUNDS, AND MONITORING OF STUDENT ACCOUNTS. FINANCIAL NEED IS DETERMINED AFTER AN ANALYSIS OF THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) IS COMPLETED. THE COLLEGE ALSO OFFERS ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS, WITHOUT REGARD TO NEED, TO ENTERING NEW AND TRANSFER STUDENTS WITH OUTSTANDING ACADEMIC RECORDS. ALL FINANCIAL AID IS CHARGED DIRECTLY AGAINST THE STUDENT ACCOUNTS.
THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MONITORS STUDENTS ADHERENCE TO ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIP REQUIREMENTS SUCH AS GPA AND SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS.

ALAYA PRESCHOOL HAS CHILDREN WHO RECEIVE SOME SCHOLARSHIP SUPPORT IN THE FORM OF TUITION REDUCTION IN ADDITION TO OTHER CHILDREN THAT RECEIVE SUPPORT VIA CCCAP (COLORADO CHILD CARE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM). THIS IS A STATE FUNDED PROGRAM FOR LOW INCOME FAMILIES. WE DO NOT GET FULLY REIMBURSED FOR THE REGULAR COST OF CARE SO SCHOLARSHIPS ARE USED TO FUND THE DIFFERENCE FOR THESE FAMILIES.
ANNUAL A-133 AUDIT
STUDENT ELIGIBILITY DATA WAS MATCHED AGAINST SCHOLARSHIP AND GRANT AWARD CRITERIA PRIOR TO AWARDING OF FUNDS.

DURING 2013-14, 68% OF THE TOTAL DICKINSON STUDENT BODY RECEIVED FINANCIAL AID FROM THE COLLEGE. SINCE MOST OF THE COLLEGE'S GRANT AWARDS ARE MADE TO STUDENTS WITH DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED, THE MAJORITY OF THESE FUNDS SUPPLEMENTED THE CONTRIBUTION THAT ELIGIBLE FAMILIES MADE TOWARD TUITION, FEES, ROOM AND BOARD CHARGES. THE COLLEGE'S INSTITUTIONAL METHODOLOGY USED TO DETERMINE ELIGIBILITY FOR GRANT FUNDS CONSIDERS ADDITIONAL FACTORS BEYOND THE DATA ITEMS REQUESTED ON THE FAFSA. THESE INCLUDE (BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO) HOME EQUITY, A CONTRIBUTION FROM THE NONCUSTODIAL PARENT, AND IN THE CASE OF A FAMILY WITH MORE THAN ONE STUDENT IN COLLEGE, AN EVALUATION OF THE ACTUAL COSTS INVOLVED IN SUPPORTING THE OTHER STUDENT(S). PARENTS IN COLLEGE AND SIBLINGS IN GRADUATE SCHOOL ARE NOT NORMALLY COUNTED AS OTHER FAMILY MEMBERS IN COLLEGE. DICKINSON EXPECTS EACH FINANCIAL AID RECIPIENT TO WORK DURING THE SUMMER AND CONTRIBUTE A MINIMUM OF $2,000 TOWARD COLLEGE COSTS. STUDENTS ARE ALSO EXPECTED TO CONTRIBUTE A PORTION OF THEIR ASSETS EACH YEAR FOR EDUCATIONAL EXPENSES. SOME STUDENTS RECEIVE EDUCATIONAL BENEFITS FROM GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES SUCH AS THE VETERANS' ADMINISTRATION AND STATE BUREAUS OF VOCATIONAL REHABILITATION OR FROM PARENTS' EMPLOYERS IN THE FORM OF TUITION REMISSION. SUCH BENEFITS MUST BE TAKEN INTO CONSIDERATION WHEN DETERMINING THE FINANCIAL AID PACKAGE. THE FINANCIAL AID AWARD NOTICE WILL LIST ALL THE FINANCIAL AID PROGRAMS FOR WHICH THE STUDENT IS ELIGIBLE. THE AMOUNT OF FINANCIAL AID THAT THE STUDENT RECEIVES FROM THESE PROGRAMS DEPENDS ON THE STUDENT'S COMPUTED NEED. THE AMOUNT OF DICKINSON GRANT AND SCHOLARSHIP AID MAY ALSO BE INFLUENCED BY THE ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT AND PROMISE OF THE APPLICANT. STUDENTS' FINANCIAL NEED IS RECALCULATED FOR EACH YEAR OF ATTENDANCE; AS A RESULT, AWARDED AMOUNTS OF NEED-BASED AID MAY VARY AS NEED CHANGES. THE COLLEGE ATTEMPTS TO MAINTAIN APPROXIMATELY THE SAME AMOUNT OF DICKINSON GRANT FUNDS FROM YEAR TO YEAR UNLESS NEED CHANGES SIGNIFICANTLY. THE STUDENT IS REQUIRED TO SUBMIT A PROFILE APPLICATION IF, AS A RESULT OF A SIGNIFICANT CHANGE IN FAMILY CIRCUMSTANCES, ADDITIONAL ASSISTANCE IS BEING REQUESTED.

GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE ARE APPLIED TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS AFTER THE START OF EACH SEMESTER OR TERM. DOMESTIC GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE TO INDIVIDUALS REPORTED ON SCHEDULE I INCLUDE FINANCIAL AID PROVIDED TO STUDENTS STUDYING AT THE MAIN CAMPUS IN CARLISLE OR AT OTHER DOMESTIC PROGRAM LOCATIONS. FOREIGN GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE TO INDIVIDUALS REPORTED ON SCHEDULE F INCLUDE FINANCIAL AID PROVIDED TO STUDENTS STUDYING ABROAD.

The process of packaging financial aid is the culmination of the complete analysis of student need and the aid administration cycle. The process of preparation for packaging is completed accurately and confidentially to ensure effective use of all aid funds available, as well as fair and equitable treatment to all applicants.
MENLO COLLEGE REQUIRES FINANCIAL AID APPLICANTS SUBMIT EVIDENCE OF ELIGIBILITY AND MAINTAINS ONGOING RECORDS OF ATTENDANCE AND SCHOLASTIC ACHIEVEMENTS BY ALL RECIPIENTS.

THE COLLEGE AWARDS FEDERAL AND STATE GRANTS BASED UPON FINANCIAL NEED. COLLEGE FUNDED INSTITUTIONAL AND ENDOWED GRANTS/SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED UPON FINANCIAL NEED AND ACADEMIC MERIT. THE COLLEGE MONITORS THESE GRANTS AND AWARDS BY SEMESTER TO VERIFY THAT RECIPIENTS ARE MAINTAINinG THE MINIMUM STANDARDS REQUIRED TO RECEIVE THE GRANT OR AWARD.

Merit Based Scholarship: limited merit aid opportunities to students who have demonstrated high academic achievement, exemplary leadership, and strong citizenship within the community. In order to be eligible for merit aid, students must have a weighted 3.5 or higher on a 4.0 GPA scale at their current school and score within the top 25% on the SSAT. Merit aid is renewed each year if the recipient earns a weighted 3.0 or higher GPA and remains in good standing at Saint Mary's School. Need Based Scholarship: is given to students with a demonstrated need who would not otherwise have been able to afford Saint Mary's School. All need-based financial aid awards are reviewed annually. Applicants and returning students who are interested in need-based financial aid must apply each year with current financial information by the published deadlines. Tuition Remission: for the daughters and stepdaughters of all benefitted employees of the School for 50% of the tuition charges at Saint Mary's School.

SCHOLARSHIP CANDIDATES MUST MEET BASIC MINIMUM GPA REQUIREMENTS, ATTEND IN FULL-TIME STATUS, AND MUST MAINTAIN SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS IN THEIR DEGREE PROGRAM. NEW STUDENTS COMPLETE AN APPLICATION ALONG WITH AN ESSAY. ALL ELIGIBLE CANDIDATES ARE INTERVIEWED BY AT LEAST TWO MEMBERS OF THE ADMISSIONS AND STUDENT AID COMMITTEE. AT THE END OF MARCH, THE COMMITTEE MEETS TO SELECT THE AWARD WINNERS. RETURNING STUDENTS WHO WERE NOT AWARDED SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS WILL HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO APPLY FOR SCHOLARSHIP IF THEY MEET THE MINIMUM GPA REQUIREMENT IN THEIR STUDIES AT MTSO. THEY MUST PROVIDE THE ASAC SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE WITH AN ESSAY AND TWO COURSE EVALUATIONS. THESE REVIEWS ALSO TAKE PLACE AT THE MARCH SCHOLARSHIP SELECTION MEETING. WE MONITOR THE ACADEMIC PROGRESS AND GPA OF SCHOLARSHIP RECIPIENTS ON AN ANNUAL BASIS. IF CRITERIA IS NOT MET, ONE SEMESTER OF SCHOLARSHIP PROBATION IS ENFORCED GIVING THE STUDENT AN ATTEMPT AT IMPROVEMENT BEFORE THE AWARD IS REVOKED.

ALL GRANTS ARE SCHOLARSHIPS MADE TO STUDENTS AT THE UNIVERSITY. STUDENTS MUST MAINTAIN ENROLLMENT AND CERTAIN REQUIREMENTS TO MAINTAIN THEIR SCHOLARSHIPS. STUDENTS MUST SUBMIT FINANCIAL INFORMATION TO ESTABLISH QUALIFICATIONS FOR NEEDS BASED SCHOLARSHIPS.

ALL GRANTS AWARDED ARE BASED ON NEED AND CONFORM TO FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITUTIONAL REGULATIONS. ELIGIBILITY IS BASED ON A THOROUGH REVIEW AND VERIFICATION OF A FAMILY'S INCOME, ASSETS, SIZE AND NUMBER OF DEPENDENTS ENROLLED IN COLLEGE. ANNUAL EXPENDITURE REPORTS ARE SUBMITTED TO THE FEDERAL AND STATE GOVERNMENTS FOR REVIEW. THE EXPENDITURES ARE REVIEWED FOR COMPLIANCE IN AN ANNUAL AUDIT CONDUCTED BY AN INDEPENDENT ACCOUNTING FIRM.

WESTMINSTER COLLEGE FINANCIAL AID AWARDING PROCESS FINANCIAL AID IS AWARDED TO INCOMING FIRST YEAR STUDENTS ON THE BASIS OF THE RESULTS OF THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) AND BY THE USE OF A FINANCIAL AID MATRIX. THE FINANCIAL AID MATRIX IS BASED ON ACADEMIC ABILITY AND FINANCIAL NEED. WITHIN EACH CELL OF THE MATRIX THERE IS A FLOOR AND A CEILING RANGE USED FOR THE AWARDING OF INSTITUTIONAL FUNDS. A STUDENT IS PLACED INTO A FINANCIAL AID MATRIX CELL BASED ON BOTH HIGH SCHOOL GRADE POINT AVERAGE AND SAT AND/OR ACT SCORES. THE AMOUNT A STUDENT IS AWARDED BETWEEN THE FLOOR AND CEILING VALUE IN THE CELL IS BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED AS DETERMINED BY THE FAFSA. INSTITUTIONAL MERIT AWARDS (AWARDED BY ADMISSIONS) THESE ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS REGARDLESS OF FINANCIAL NEED. MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS (UNFUNDED AID) ACCEPTED FIRST YEAR STUDENTS ARE AWARDED A MERIT SCHOLARSHIP DETERMINED BY WHERE THEY FALL IN THE MATRIX BASED ON HIGH SCHOOL GRADE POINT AVERAGE AND SAT AND/OR ACT SCORES. THE MERIT SCHOLARSHIP AWARD IS THE FLOOR VALUE FROM THE RESPECTIVE MATRIX CELL. STUDENTS WHO FALL IN THE TOP 20% OF THE APPLICANT POOL MAY BE SELECTED BY THE ADMISSIONS STAFF AS A WESTMINSTER SCHOLAR. SELECTED STUDENTS ARE GUARANTEED A MERIT AWARD WHICH IS THE FLOOR VALUE FROM THE MATRIX CELL. THE WESTMINSTER SCHOLAR IS ALSO GIVEN AN OPPORTUNITY TO COMPETE FOR A LARGER FOUR YEAR AWARD THROUGH THE SCHOLARS COMPETITIONS HELD ON THE WESTMINSTER CAMPUS. THIS COMPETITION HAS FACULTY INVOLVEMENT AND STUDENT ESSAYS. THE LARGER AWARDS INCLUDE FULL TUITION PRESIDENTIAL SCHOLARSHIPS, VANCE SCHOLARSHIPS, LEMMON SCHOLARSHIPS AND TITAN SCHOLARSHIPS (WITH A RANGE OF VALUES). NOMINATED MERIT BASED SCHOLARSHIPS (UNFUNDED AID) THE NOMINATED SCHOLARSHIPS AVAILABLE TO INCOMING FIRST YEAR STUDENTS ARE: 1) THE YOUNG PRESBYTERIAN SCHOLARSHIP -TO BE ELIGIBLE A STUDENT MUST BE A MEMBER OF THE PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH USA, BE NOMINATED BY HIS/HER CHURCH AND PRESENT A MINIMUM GPA OF 3.5. 2) JERB MILLER SCHOLARSHIP -TO BE ELIGIBLE A STUDENT MUST PRESENT BE NOMINATED BY AN EDUCATOR WHO IS A WESTMINSTER COLLEGE GRADUATE AND PRESENT A MINIMUM GPA OF 3.5. 3) LEGACY SCHOLARSHIP (FUNDED AID) -TO BE ELIGIBLE A STUDENT MUST PRESENT A CUMULATIVE GPA OF 3.0 AND HAVE A PARENT OR GRANDPARENT WHO EARNED A DEGREE FROM WESTMINSTER COLLEGE. MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS ARE RENEWABLE FOR UP TO THREE YEARS. THE STUDENT NEEDS TO MAINTAIN THE REQUIRED SCHOLARSHIP GPA (IF ONE EXISTS), OTHERWISE REMAIN IN GOOD ACADEMIC STANDING. INSTITUTIONAL NEED BASED AWARDS (UNFUNDED AID) NEED BASED INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL AID IS AWARDED TO STUDENTS BASED ON THE RESULTS OF THE FAFSA AND THE DETERMINATION OF THE STUDENTS DEMONSTRATED NEED. A STUDENT IS REQUIRED TO FILE A FAFSA FORM IN ORDER TO BE CONSIDERED FOR NEED BASED FINANCIAL AID. THE RESULTS OF THE FAFSA DETERMINE THE STUDENT'S EXPECTED FAMILY CONTRIBUTION (EFC). THE CALCULATION USED TO DETERMINE THE STUDENT'S FINANCIAL NEED IS: DIRECT COST OF ATTENDANCE* - EFC = STUDENT'S NEED (*DIRECT COST OF ATTENDANCE: TUITION & FEES, ROOM & BOARD FOR RESIDENT AND OFF CAMPUS STUDENTS, TUITION & FEES ONLY FOR COMMUTERS) THE CALCULATED STUDENT NEED IS REDUCED BY: FEDERAL NEED BASED FINANCIAL AID STATE NEED BASED FINANCIAL AID FUNDED GIFT AID INSTITUTIONAL MERIT THE REMAINING UNMET NEED, AFTER THE REDUCTIONS, IS MET BY USING INSTITUTIONAL NEED BASED GIFT AID WITH THE TOTAL OF INSTITUTIONAL AID BEING CAPPED BY THE CEILING VALUE FROM THE MATRIX CELL FOR THE STUDENT. INSTITUTIONAL NEED BASED AWARDS ARE USUALLY RENEWED PROVIDED THAT THE STUDENT CONTINUES TO DEMONSTRATE FINANCIAL NEED. FINANCIAL AID PACKAGING STUDENTS RECEIVE A FINANCIAL AID PACKAGE ANNUALLY WHICH INCLUDES ALL SOURCES OF FINANCIAL AID THAT THEY ARE ELIGIBLE AND QUALIFY FOR. AWARDS THAT MAY BE INCLUDED IN A FINANCIAL AID PACKAGE ARE: FEDERAL GRANTS (PELL AND SEOG) STATE GRANTS INSTITUTIONAL MERIT AWARDS INSTITUTIONAL NEED BASED AWARDS INSTITUTIONAL ENDOWED AWARDS FEDERAL LOANS (STAFFORD AND PERKINS) FEDERAL WORK STUDY THE COLLEGE CONTROLLER DETERMINES THE AMOUNT AVAILABLE IN ALL INSTITUTIONAL FUNDS ON AN ANNUAL BASIS. WESTMINSTER COLLEGE UNFUNDED AND FUNDED AID IS PORTABLE FOR OFF-CAMPUS STUDIES IF THE PROGRAM IS REQUIRED BY THE STUDENT'S MAJOR. THESE FUNDS ARE PORTABLE UP TO THE LESS OF 1) THE TUITION OF THE OFF CAMPUS STUDIES PROGRAM, OR 2) THE LIMIT OF A STUDENT'S WESTMINSTER COLLEGE AWARDED AID WHERE A PARTICULAR STUDY-ABROAD PROGRAM'S TUITION IS GREATER THAN THE WESTMINSTER COLLEGE AID THE STUDENT IS ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE FOR THE SAME PERIOD OF ENROLLMENT. BEFORE THESE FUNDS WILL BE PAID TO THE STUDY ABROAD PROGRAM ON THE STUDENT'S BEHALF, THE STUDENT IS REQUIRED TO PROVIDE A COPY OF THE INVOICE FOR THE STUDY ABROAD PROGRAM, WITH A SEPARATE LINE ITEM FOR TUITION. STUDENTS ARE REQUIRED TO HAVE THE INSTITUTION PROVIDE A COPY OF THE ACADEMIC TRANSCRIPTS FOR THE TERM(S) ABROAD TO WESTMINSTER COLLEGE. WESTMINSTER COLLEGES FINANCIAL AID OFFICE USES THE FINANCIAL AID MANAGEMENT SYSTEM POWERFAIDS TO MAINTAIN FINANCIAL AID AWARD RECORDS AND AMOUNTS.

ALL SWARTHMORE COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE DISBURSED/POSTED ELECTRONICALLY (AND INTERNALLY) DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENTS ACCOUNT. FURTHERMORE, STUDENTS RECEIVING SAID FUNDS ARE UNABLE TO WITHDRAWAL IT FROM THEIR STUDENT ACCOUNT.
THE SCHOOL PROVIDES GRANTS IN THE FORM OF CREDITS AGAINST TUITION INVOICES. GRANT FUNDS ARE NOT ACTUALLY DISBURSED FROM THE SCHOOL.
GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE REPRESENTS STUDENT FINANCIAL AID. WHEN AWARDING AID, CHARLES R. DREW UNIVERSITY FOLLOWS ALL LAWS AND REGULATIONS OF FEDERAL AND STATE OF CALIFONIA AID PROGRAMS

INDIVIDUALS IN THE U.S. ARE DEFINED AS THOSE LIVING IN THE U.S. AT THE TIME THE AID WAS AWARDED. THE ABOVE IS A BEST ESTIMATE BASED ON CERTAIN ASSUMPTIONS REGARDING WHERE PERSONS WERE LIVING WHEN THE AID WAS AWARDED AND DOES NOT REPRESENT THE DEGREE TO WHICH AID IS AWARDED TO INTERNATIONAL STUDENTS.

Subrecipient grants - Lehigh University maintains a policy defining its procedures for monitoring the use of sponsored funds by subrecipients who are performing a portion of a sponsored project externally awarded to Lehigh. The policy provides guidance to ensure that subrecipients conduct their portions of sponsored projects in compliance with laws, regulations, terms and conditions of awards and subawards, and that reimbursed costs incurred by subrecipients are allowed. Other Assistance - Assistance offered from instititional funds by Lehigh to our students is awarded on the basis of merit and/or financial need. The selection criteria is based on the calculated expected family contribution, which is derived by using complex formulas involving families' income, assets, and household sizes. The student financial aid office administers and monitors these grants using system-generated reviews, along with cross checks on an ad hoc basis. Results from these reviews are regularly evaluated. Subsequently, follow-up corrective actions are taken when appropriate, and potentially include award revisions or cancellations. These provisions are designed to help ensure that student assistance funds are awarded to eligible recipients, in accordance with applicable federal, state, institutional, and other program legislation, as well as relevant internal university policies and operational guidelines.
GRANT QUALIFICATIONS: STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS ARE JUDGED WORTHY BY THE COLLEGE'S ASSESSMENT ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED, AND OTHER SIMILIAR STANDARDS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2, Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
ExplntnTxt: GRANTS AT THE COLLEGE ARE LIMITED TO TUITION WAIVERS AND SCHOLARSHIPS. TUITION WAIVERS ARE GRANTED ACCORDING TO TERMS AS SET FORTH IN THE EMPLOYEE HANDBOOK. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED IN STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES ACCORDING TO GUIDELINES AS PUBLISHED IN THE ACADEMIC CATALOG. FUNDS ARE CREDITED DIRECTLY TO A STUDENT'S ACCOUNT TO ENSURE THE PROPER USE OF FUNDS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2, Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
ExplntnTxt: THE OFFICE OF SPONSORED PROJECTS ADMINISTRATION DIRECTS AND FACILITATES PRE- AND POST-AWARD PROCESSES BY ENSURING COMPLIANCE WITH FEDERAL, STATE AND UNIVERSITY GUIDELINES. IT ALSO OVERSEES REGULATORY COMPLIANCE ACTIVITIES TO ENSURE SAFE, ETHICAL AND RESPONSIBLE CONDUCT OF RESEARCH. IN ADDITION, THE OFFICE IS RESPONSIBLE FOR ENHANCING THE RESEARCH INFRASTRUCTURE OF THE INSTITUTION AS WELL AS DEVELOPING AND MONITORING POLICIES RELATED TO THE STEWARDSHIP OF RESEARCH ACTIVITIES.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part III, column(b), Estimated Number of Recipients

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2, Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
ExplntnTxt: THE UNIVERSITY OF DAYTON IS AN INDEPENDENT UNIVERSITY THAT PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO ITS STUDENTS. THE STUDENTS QUALIFY TO RECEIVE THIS AID BASED UPON THEIR FINANCIAL NEED AND ACADEMIC TALENT. RECORDS ARE MAINTAINED THAT DOCUMENT THE STUDENTS' FINANCIAL NEED, ELIGIBILITY TO QUALIFY FOR THE SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS AND THE AMOUNTS AWARDED ON AN ANNUAL BASIS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PART I, LINE 2 - PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING USE OF GRANTS FUNDS IN U.S.
ExplntnTxt: ALL GRANTS AWARDED ARE BASED ON NEED AND CONFORM TO FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITUTIONAL REGULATIONS. ELIGIBILITY IS BASED ON A THOROUGH REVIEW AND VERIFICATION OF A FAMILY'S INCOME, ASSETS, SIZE AND NUMBER OF DEPENDENTS ENROLLED IN COLLEGE. ANNUAL EXPENDITURE REPORTS ARE SUBMITTED TO THE FEDERAL AND STATE GOVERNMENTS FOR REVIEW. THE FUND EXPENDITURES ARE REVIEWED FOR COMPLIANCE IN AN ANNUAL AUDIT CONDUCTED BY AN INDEPENDENT ACCOUNTING FIRM. The college does not further monitor the usage of scholarship funds as these amounts are credited directly against students tuition account and there is no opportunity for the student to divert these funds to non-educational uses.

All University spending must be approved by a manager or higher level, depending on the amount of the expenditure. Any expenditure of $1,000 or above would have to be approved by a Dean or other budget center manager. An expenditure in excess of $10,000 must be approved by a Vice President (or that person's designee) or the President. Grants or assistance to outside organizations are segregated in the University's financial accounting system through the use of a separate account code, which allows for review by University's central finance department. Scholarships are provided to students who are required to matriculate in the University, thereby ensuring that the funds are expended for the intended purposes.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Part II,Line 1, (h) Purpose of grant assistance:
ExplntnTxt: Construction of South Orange Performing Arts Center.

THE COLLEGE MONITORS THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS THROUGH A SHARED APPROACH BY THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT AND THE BUSINESS OFFICE. ALL BUDGETED TO ACTUAL GRANT ACTIVITY IS MONITORED ON A MONTHLY BASIS AND THE FINANCIAL AID FOR EACH STUDENT IS APPROVED PRIOR TO DISBURSING FUNDS. GRANT REPORTING AND COMPLIANCE ARE MONITORED BY THE BOTH THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT AND THE BUSINESS OFFICE TO ENSURE ACCURACY.

The College offers financial aid to assist students on the basis of full-time enrollment. Factors influencing the amount and type of aid awarded include financial need, academic achievement, leadership and other personal, qualitative attributes. The Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA), which helps to establish a student's financial need, serves as the application for financial aid. Files detailing grant and scholarship requirements and criteria are reviewed to ensure individual student eligibility before awards are made. The College does not discriminate on the bases of race, sex, color, age, national origin or handicap.

SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2: SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS OF THE COLLEGE BASED ON VARIOUS CRITERIA. THESE CRITERIA INCLUDE FINANCIAL NEED, GRADE POINT AVERAGE, AND OTHERS AS ESTABLISHED BY THE SCHOLARSHIP DOCUMENTS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE APPLIED TO THE INDIVIDUAL STUDENT'S ACCOUNTS TO PAY TUITION, ROOM AND BOARD EXPENSES.THE NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS SHOWN FOR SCHEDULE I PART III IS BASED ON THE NUMBER OF GRANTS AWARDED. THIS AMOUNT IS USED AS A REASONABLE ESTIMATE OF THE TOTAL NUMBER OF STUDENTS AWARDED GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS.
All accepted students currently received either a full or half Olin tuition scholarship which is credited directly to their student accounts. It is used only to offset tuition charges.

THE PROCEDURES FOR NEED-BASED AWARDS INCLUDE REVIEW AND RESOLUTION OF ALL FEDERAL-PROCESSOR-IDENTIFIED ELIGIBILITY CONFLICTS, AND 100% VERFICATION OF REPORTED PARENT AND STUDENT INCOMES. FOR ALL FUNDS THERE IS A SEPARATION OF THE AWARDING AND DISBURSEMENT FUNCTIONS (DIFFERENT INDIVIDUALS RESPONSIBLE FOR EACH), MONTHLY RECONCILIATIONS BETWEEN STUDENT ACCOUNTS AND THE COLLEGE'S GENERAL LEDGER, AND AN ANNUAL AUDIT IN ACCORDANCE WITH OMB CIRCULAR A-133. SCHEDULE I, PART III: THE CASH GRANT IS REFLECTED ON STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS.
All assistance is in the form of grants and scholarships. These funds are applied directly to the student's account.

ENSURE A CURRENT CERTIFICATION OR AN A-133 AUDIT IS PERFORMED AND THE RELATED REPORT RECEIVED AND REVIEWED.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MONITOR THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS
ExplntnTxt: THE UNIVERSITY'S GRANTS IN THE US CONSIST OF FINANCIAL AID AWARDS WHICH ARE APPLIED AGAINST STUDENTS' RECEIVABLE BALANCES DUE TO THE UNIVERSITY. THE UNIVERSITY MONITORS THESE GRANTS BY CONTROLLING THE APPLICATION OF GRANTS TO STUDENTS' BALANCES.

The University's Office of Financial Aid monitors all recipients of scholarship awards to determine both initial and confirming eligibility based on the criteria for each type of award, which may include academic performance, financial need, and criteria established by donors of endowed scholarship funds, etc.

THE COLLEGE MONITORS THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS THROUGH CONTROLS ESTABLISHED IN THE BUSINESS OFFICE. THE VP OF FINANCE AND ADMINISTRATION RECEIVES, REVIEWS, AND APPROVES GRANT APPLICATIONS PRIOR TO SUBMISSION TO ENSURE THAT INDIRECT COSTS AND REPORTING REQUIREMENTS ARE IN PLACE. UPON GRANTING THE AWARD, THE DEPARTMENT SUBMITS THE APPROVED GRANT TO THE BUSINESS OFFICE. THE PRINCIPAL FOR THE GRANT, ALONG WITH THE STAFF ACCOUNTANT AND CONTROLLER ENSURE THAT EXPENSES SUBMITTED ARE CONSISTENT WITH THE APPROVED GRANT. THE PRINCIPAL DEPARTMENT FOR THE GRANT, ALONG WITH VPS AND ABOVE RECEIVE REVENUE AND EXPENSE REPORTS ON ALL ACTIVE GRANT FUNDS.

IN ORDER TO BE AWARDED INSTITUTIONAL FUNDS, STUDENTS MUST BE ENROLLED FULL-TIME AND MAKING SATISFACTORY PROGRESS. UNDERGRADUATE ON-CAMPUS STUDENTS COMPLETE A CROWN FINANCIAL AID APPLICATION TO HELP DETERMINE ELIGIBILITY FOR SCHOLARSHIPS, GRANTS AND DISCOUNTS. SCHOLARSHIPS, GRANTS AND DISCOUNTS ARE AWARDED BASED ON MERIT AND SPECIFIC CRITERIA. THE CROWN GRANT IS NEED-BASED USING PERCENTAGES AND MINIMUM AWARD ADAPTED FROM NOEL-LEVITZ.

THE UNIVERSITY ISSUES GRANTS AND OTHER FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE TO STUDENTS, WHICH ALLOWS STUDENTS TO FURTHER THEIR EDUCATION. GRANTED FUNDS ARE CREDITED TO THE STUDENT'S UNIVERSITY BILLING ACCOUNT AND APPLIED TO TUITION, FEES, AND OTHER COSTS OF EDUCATION. IN FISCAL YEAR 2013-2014 THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDED DOMESTIC FINANCIAL AID TO SUPPORT 1325 STUDENTS.

BASIS OF VERIFIED FINANCIAL NEED OR MERIT AND DOES NOT UNLAWFULLY DISCRIMINATE ON THE BASIS OF RACE, COLOR, NATIONAL OR ETHNIC ORIGIN, RELIGION, AGE, SEX DISABILITY OR PRIOR MILITARY SERVICE. FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE IS MONITORED SO THAT IT IS IN COMPLIANCE WITH AWARDING TERMS AND CONDITIONS. EXPENDITURES ARE REVIEWED FOR ALLOWABILITY AND COMPLIANCE. STUDENTS ARE REQUIRED TO SUBMIT APPROPRIATE DOCUMENTS PRIOR TO APPROVAL. PART III: CASH GRANTS ARE CREDITS TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS AND THE NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS REPRESENTS ONLY THE NUMBERS OF STUDENTS RECEIVING INSTITUTIONAL FUNDING. OUTSIDE GRANTS, OR APPLICATIONS OF FUNDS PROVIDED BY OUTSIDE AGENCIES (E.G. FEDERAL LOAN PROGRAMS) IS NOT INCLUDED.

SCHOLARSHIPS AND SIMILAR ALLOCATIONS ARE AWARDED BASED ON A VARIETY OF REQUIREMENTS THAT ARE RELATIVE ONLY TO THE PARTICULAR TYPE OF AWARD TO BE GRANTED. VARIOUS SCHOLARSHIPS AND SIMILAR ALLOCATIONS CAN BE AWARDED BASED ON THE FINANCIAL NEED OF THE STUDENT, THE STUDENT'S YEAR IN SCHOOL, OR ANY OTHER REQUIREMENT THAT MAY BE SPECIFICALLY NOTED IN AN ENDOWMENT.

St. Edward's University's Office of Student Financial Services monitors the use of grant funds through the following procedures: Enrollment Committee - The Enrollment Committee reviews awarding and renewal policies for the university grants and scholarships and establishes freshmen and transfer enrollment goals along with the financial aid packaging strategy necessary to achieve these goals. The committee engages a nationally recognized leader in the enrollment management consulting field to assist in the establishment and monitoring of freshmen and transfer enrollment goals and financial aid packaging. Each committee member and other key university personnel receive weekly reports throughout the financial aid awarding cycle. The Enrollment Committee is comprised of the Vice President for Academic Affairs, Vice President for Marketing and Enrollment Management, Vice President for Financial Affairs (ex-officio), Associate Vice President for Student Financial Services and Associate Vice President for Undergraduate Admission. Compliance and Funds Management - The enterprise software database used to administer financial aid, (This includes all funding sources for grants and scholarships; university, federal, state, local and private sources.) has a comprehensive compliance function. The Compliance and Funds Management Modules allow for staff to add additional functionality as necessary. The compliance function identifies grant and scholarship offers that fail to meet awarding criteria and prevents financial aid from being applied to a student if the student does not meet the disbursing criteria. The funds management function ensures the financial aid records and university general ledger records reconcile with each other. Further monitoring is accomplished through numerous reports specific to financial aid identifying codes, the individual types of grants the various forms of grants and individual funding sources. Annual Independent Audits - Annual audits are performed by an independent public accounting firm who render an opinion as to whether federal and certain state funded financial aid programs are exercised in compliance with applicable laws and regulations governing said programs.

SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED ON THE BASIS OF MERIT AND NEED. FIRST YEAR STUDENTS MAY BE AWARDED SPECIAL ASSISTANCE BASED ON NEED AND MERIT AS DETERMINED BY THE APPLICANT'S APPLICATION AND AUDITION. SECOND YEAR AND ACADEMY COMPANY STUDENTS MAY APPLY FOR SCHOLARSHIPS BY WRITING TO THE ACADEMY'S SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE WHICH MAKES ALL SCHOLARSHIP DECISIONS. DETAILS ARE AVAILABLE UPON REQUEST.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2, Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
ExplntnTxt: THE ORGANIZATION ISSUES GRANTS TO QUALIFIED INDIVIDUALS. THE GRANT FUNDS ARE THEN USED DIRECTLY AGAINST THE STUDENTS ACCOUNT AS PAYMENT TOWARDS THEIR COLLEGE EDUCATION.

THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE IS RESPONSIBLE FOR DETERMINING THAT A STUDENT IS ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE AN AWARD. WHEN FUNDS ARRIVE, THE FINANCIAL AID STAFF DETERMINES THAT THE STUDENT IS ENROLLED FOR THE SAME NUMBER OF HOURS THAT THEY WERE PACKAGED FOR, AND THAT THEY ARE MEETING THE GUIDELINES OF SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE THEN NOTIFIES THE STUDENT ACCOUNTS DEPARTMENT THAT THE AWARD NEEDS TO BE CREDITED TO A STUDENT'S ACCOUNT FOR THAT TRIMESTER.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2, Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
ExplntnTxt: THE COLLEGE HAS A FINANCIAL AID OFFICE WHO HANDLES ALL FINANCIAL AID AWARDS. STUDENTS ARE REQUIRED TO COMPLETE AN APPLICATION FOR SCHOLARSHIPS. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE SUMMARIZES ALL THE RELEVANT DATA FROM THE APPLICATIONS AND PRESENTS IT TO THE SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE CREATED FOR EACH DEPARTMENT/PROGRAM THAT HAS SCHOLARSHIP MONEY. THESE COMMITTEES CONSISTS OF FACULTY, STAFF AND ADMINISTRATION. EACH COMMITTEE REVIEWS ALL APPLICANTS AND SCHOLARSHIP REQUIREMENTS, THEN DECIDES WHO WILL RECEIVE THE AWARDS.
BOARD DETERMINES FINANCIAL NEEDS OF SCHOLARS

THE MAJORITY OF GRANT FUNDS AWARDED BY THE UNIVERSITY ARE IN THE FORM OF FINANCIAL AID TO ITS STUDENTS. THE ORGANIZATION'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AWARDS NEED AND MERIT BASE AID BASED ON THE CRITERIA ESTABLISHED BY THE UNIVERSITY. THE FINANCIAL AID PROGRAM AT SETON HILL UNIVERSITY ASSISTS STUDENTS WHO WOULD FIND IT DIFFICULT OR IMPOSSIBLE TO ATTEND COLLEGE WITHOUT SOME FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE. THE UNIVERSITY OFFERS A COMPREHENSIVE PROGRAM OF FINANCIAL AID IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS, GRANTS, LOANS, PART-TIME EMPLOYMENT, AND DEFERRED PAYMENT SCHEDULES, AND COORDINATES ITS PROGRAMS WITH THE FEDERAL AND STATE FINANCIAL AND PROGRAMS. ANY OF THESE FORMS OF FINANCIAL AID MAY BE OFFERED INDEPENDENTLY OR IN VARIOUS COMBINATIONS TO A STUDENT. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE ESTIMATES THE COST OF ATTENDING SETON HILL UNIVERSITY BY ADDING TUITION, ROOM, BOARD AND FEES PLUS AN ESTIMATE FOR BOOKS, SUPPLIES, TRANSPORTATION FROM HOME TO SCHOOL AND PERSONAL EXPENSES. THE AMOUNT OF FINANCIAL AID AN APPLICANT RECEIVES IS BASED ON THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN THE TOTAL COSTS AND THE AMOUNT THE STUDENT AND FAMILY ARE ABLE TO CONTRIBUTE TOWARD COSTS AS DETERMINED BY THE NEEDS ANALYSIS FORM.

The University's Office of Financial Aid monitors all recipients of scholarship awards to determine both initial and continuing eligibility based on the criteria for each type of award, which may include academic performance, financial need, criteria established by donors of endowed scholarship funds, etc.

THE COLLEGE HAS A LIMITED AMOUNT OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE THAT IS AVAILABLE TO QUALIFYING STUDENTS THROUGH ITS SCHOLARSHIP FUND. AWARDS ARE MADE ANNUALLY AND ARE DIVIDED OVER THE FALL AND SPRING TERM ENROLLMENTS. GENERAL QUALIFICATION REQUIREMENTS OF SOME OF THE GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED BY THE COLLEGE ARE AS FOLLOWS: CHRISTIAN WORKERS GRANT - FULL-TIME STUDENTS WHOSE PARENTS ARE IN FULL-TIME CHRISTIAN MINISTRY ARE ELIGIBLE FOR THIS GRANT. TRINITY COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIP - NEW FULL-TIME STUDENTS WHO HAVE A MINIMUM ACT COMPOSITE SCORE OF 19 OR A MINIMUM COMBINED SAT SCORE OF 950 ARE ELIGIBLE FOR THIS SCHOLARSHIP. TRINITY COLLEGE GRANT - THIS GRANT IS AWARDED TO NEW OR CONTINUING FULL-TIME STUDENTS ON THE BASIS OF NEED. PAST OR EXPECTED STUDENT LEADERSHIP IS CONSIDERED. THE COLLEGE MAINTAINS RECORDS DOCUMENTING THE SCHOLARSHIP CRITERIA, THE RECIPIENT SELECTION PROCESS, THE AMOUNT REWARDED, AND THE QUALIFIED EXPENSES FOR WHICH THE FUNDS ARE USED FOR EACH SCHOLARSHIP GRANTED.

The agency has written contracts with all of the recipients that clearly identify the responsibilities of both parties, the contract amount and how it must be drawn down. The recipients must submit adequate documentation to support all requests for funds associated with their contracts before payment is made. The agency also conducts on-site fiscal monitoring of its recipients at least once a year, with the exception of the organizations receiving On the Job Training Wage Reimbursements. The OJT Wage contracts are very straightforward and the required documentation for payment provides sufficient controls over these funds.
OFFICERS OF CSED MONITOR THE GRANTS BY REVIEW OF THE MONTHLY OR QUARTERLY FINANCIAL ACTIVITY REPORTS, SUMMARIES OF SIGNIGICANT DECISIONS AND FORM 990 RECEIVED FROM THE ORGANIZATIONS

ORGANIZATION PROVIDES NEEDS BASED SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS. STUDENTS APPLYING FOR SCHOLARSHIPS MUST PROVIDE EVIDENCE OF NEED. EACH APPLICATION IS REVIEWED BY A COMMITTEE TO DETERMINE THE AMOUNT OF SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED TO EACH STUDENT.

ExplntnTxt: ORGANIZATION IS PROVIDED WITH DOUMENTATION OF USE OF FUNDS FOR THEIR GRANTS AND IS IN CONSTANT CONTACT WITH MANAGEMENT OF MESIFTA TO ENSURE THEIR FUNDS ARE PROPERLY SPENT.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2, Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
ExplntnTxt: AFTER THE INITIAL REVIEW AND APPROVAL BY THE APPROPRIATE EMPLOYEES AT THE GRANT DEPARTMENT LEVEL, THE PAPERWORK FOR GRANT EXPENDITURES ARE THEN PASSED ON TO THE NEXT REVIEW AND APPROVAL LEVEL BY AN APPLICABLE COLLEGE OR DEPARTMENTAL ADMINISTRATOR OF GRANT EXPENDITURES. UPON APPROVAL, THE PAPERWORK IS SENT TO THE SENIOR GRANTS ACCOUNTANT FOR REVIEW AND APPROVAL PRIOR TO PAYMENT PROCESSING OF THE GRANT EXPENDITURES. THE SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS ARE ADMINISTERED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. THE SCHOLARSHIP AMOUNTS ARE INTERNALLY CREDITED TO THE INDIVIDUAL STUDENTS' BILLED TUITION TO ENSURE FUNDS ARE USED FOR THEIR INTENDED PURPOSE.

WAGNER COLLEGE MONITORS THE USE OF SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS IN THE UNITED STATES BY ENSURING THAT ALL STUDENTS WHO RECEIVE SCHOLARSHIP MONIES ARE ALWAYS REGISTERED AS STUDENTS OF THE COLLEGE. MANY DEPARTMENTS WITHIN THE COLLEGE WORK IN CONJUNCTION TO ENSURE THAT SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS ARE MONITORED EFFICIENTLY AND EFFECTIVELY. THE ADMISSIONS OFFICE REVIEWS ALL STUDENT APPLICATIONS, AND DETERMINES WHO IS ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE SCHOLARSHIPS. THE FINANCE AND BUSINESS OFFICE DRAWS DOWN FUNDS FOR SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO STUDENTS, AND THE REGISTRAR'S OFFICE MONITORS AND MAINTAINS ALL RECORDS REGARDING THE REGISTERED STATUS OF STUDENTS. PART III, LINE 1, COLUMN B WAGNER COLLEGE ESTIMATES THAT APPROXIMATELY 90% OF ALL FULL-TIME STUDENTS RECEIVE SOME SORT OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE BY THE COLLEGE. THEREFORE, THE NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS OF GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE BY WAGNER COLLEGE IS ESTIMATED BY TAKING 90% OF THE TOTAL FTE ENROLLMENT FOR THE FALL 2013 SEMESTER (2,111 FTES), RESULTING IN APPROXIMATELY 1,900 RECIPIENTS.
Scholarships and other types of financial assistance are monitored through internal transfer of funds within the university.

- The University maintains a formal policy defining its procedures for monitoring the use of sponsored funds by subrecipients who are performing a portion of a sponsored project externally awarded to the University. The policy provides guidance to ensure that subrecipients conduct their portions of a sponsored project in compliance with laws, regulations and terms and conditions of awards and subawards and that reimbursed costs incurred by subrecipients are allowed. The policy addresses the roles and responsibilities of the central offices and academic departments of the University and describes the monitoring procedures for each area. The full text of the Universitys Subrecipent Policy is available online at the following web address http//spa.wustl.edu/.

- The grants reported in Part III line 1 are scholarships to students. The use of scholarships is controlled by applying such amounts directly against balances owed by the student for tuition, fees and other qualifying educational expenses.

- The grants reported in Part III line 2 are fellowships awarded to students who may use them to pay qualified educational expenses or to support their living expenses while completing their course of study. The use of fellowship awards is not monitored by the University however an award is discontinued if the recipient student discontinues his/her course of study.

- Prizes and awards reported in Part III Line 3 are awarded to students for, among other reasons, academic excellence, writing competitions, design competitions, research and service to the local community and other students.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MONITOR THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE U.S.
ExplntnTxt: PART I, LINE 2 THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIP ASSISTANCE TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS. MANY SCHOLARSHIPS ARE BASED ON CRITERIA SUCH AS ACADEMIC STRENGTH, ATHLETIC ABILITY, LEADERSHIP, OR COMMUNITY SERVICE. NON-NEED-BASED SCHOLARSHIP FUNDING IS AWARDED THROUGH THE ADMISSIONS PROCESS AND USUALLY HAS A GRADE POINT AVERAGE (GPA) OR OTHER REQUIREMENT FOR RENEWAL IN SUBSEQUENT YEARS. TYPES OF MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS INCLUDE THE TRUSTEE SCHOLARSHIP, THE PRESIDENT'S SCHOLARSHIP AND THE INTERNATIONAL SCHOLARSHIP. THE UNIVERSITY ALSO OFFERS GRANT FUNDS THAT ARE AWARDED BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED AND DO NOT HAVE TO BE REPAID. THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE DETERMINES THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF A STUDENT'S NEED-BASED GRANT FUNDING ACCORDING TO FEDERAL AND INSTITUTIONAL FORMULAS. TYPES OF NEED BASED GRANTS INCLUDE BENTLEY SCHOLARSHIPS, AS WELL AS FEDERAL AND STATE SOURCES. ALL SCHOLARSHIP AMOUNTS ARE AUTOMATICALLY CREDITED TO THE INDIVIDUAL'S STUDENT ACCOUNT.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: grants or other assistance in the united states
ExplntnTxt: form 990, schedule i, part i, line 2 Elizabethtown College provides scholarships to students matriculating at the College. Students receiving scholarships are not permitted any discretion on how to spend those funds as all amounts are used to satisfy tuition costs. Accordingly, all funds granted are used to defray the cost of tuition and no further monitoring of the grants is required.
APPLICATIONS ARE RECEIVED AND GRANTS ARE AWARDED FOR NEED BASED ELIGIBLE STUDENTS AND FOR ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE.
GRANTS ARE MONITORED BY THE ORGANIZATION'S FINANCE PERSONNEL THROUGH THE UTILIZATION OF COST CENTERS AND OTHER INFORMATION; INCLUDING WRITTEN DOCUMENTATION AND RECEIPTS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PROCEDURES TO MONITOR THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE U.S.
ExplntnTxt: PART I, LINE 2 ALL FEDERAL TITLE IV FUNDS RECEIVED BY BRYANT UNIVERSITY ARE MANAGED IN STRICT COMPLIANCE WITH ALL REQUIREMENTS SET FORTH IN THE PROGRAM PARITICPATION AGREEMENT, A FORMAL AGREEMENT BETWEEN BRYANT UNIVERSITY AND THE U.S DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION. THE PROGRAM PARTICIPATION AGREEMENT IS PERSONALLY ENDORSED BY BOTH THE CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER OF BRYANT UNIVERSITY AND THE SECRETARY OF THE U.S.DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION. COMPLIANCE WITH ALL TITLE IV REQUIREMENTS IS MONITORED BY THE DIRECTOR OF FINANCIAL AID WITH THE ASSISTANCE OF FOUR (EXEMPT) PROFESSIONAL FINANCIAL AID ADMINISTRATORS AND FOUR (NON-EXEMPT) SUPPORT STAFF MEMBERS. COMPLIANCE CAPABILITY IS GREATLY ENHANCED THROUGH THE USE OF THE BANNER INTEGRATED MANAGEMENT INFORMATION SYSTEM AND ITS EFFECTIVE INTERFACE WITH OTHER DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION SYSTEMS. THE UNIVERSITY DID PROVIDE ASSISTANCE FOR COMMUNITY SUPPORT TO VARIOUS ORGANIZATIONS THROUGH THEIR FUNDRAISING EVENTS, ALTHOUGH NO SINGLE ORGANIZATION RECEIVED OVER $5,000 FROM THE UNIVERSITY DURING THE YEAR. THE UNIVERSITY DID NOT TAKE A CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTION ON ITS GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE TO INDIVIDUALS IN THE U.S.

CENTRAL COLLEGE PROCEDURE FOR MONITORING GRANTS:CENTRAL COLLEGE EMPLOYEES REVIEW COMPLIANCE FOR ALL FEDERAL, STATE, AND PRIVATE GRANTS RECEIVED. IN ADDITION, CENTRAL COLLEGE PARTICIPATES IN AN A-133 AUDIT ON AN ANNUAL BASIS FROM OUR EXTERNAL AUDIT FIRM.

THE UNIVERSITY AWARDS BOTH INSTITUTIONALLY-FUNDED FINANCIAL AID TO STUDENTS AS WELL AS FINANCIAL AID FUNDED FROM PRIVATE GIFTS AND VARIOUS FEDERAL, STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENT AGENCIES. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED ON AN EQUAL, OBJECTIVE AND NONDISCRIMINATORY BASIS USING ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED, AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS. THE UNIVERSITY MAINTAINS SEPARATE ACCOUNTING FOR ALL GRANTS AND STRICTLY MONITORS THAT ANY DISBURSEMENTS ARE MADE ONLY FOR THE INTENDED PURPOSE OF THE GRANT AND IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE GRANT REQUIREMENTS. AN AUDIT OF THE UNIVERSITY'S FEDERALLY FUNDED PROGRAMS, IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE "US OFFICE OF MANAGEMENT AND BUDGET ("OMB") CIRCULAR A-133 COMPLIANCE SUPPLEMENT", IS CONDUCTED ANNUALLY BY THE UNIVERSITY'S EXTERNAL AUDITORS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS
ExplntnTxt: PART I, LINE 2 Scholarships are awarded by Allen University to students based on their academic achievement, specific talents and participation in intercollegiate athletics with awards based on their performance levels. Students are also awarded need-based scholarships and grants based on their need as established by completing the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) and, if applicable, by specific criteria and guidelines for other federal and state programs.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Procedure for Monitoring Use of Grant Funds Inside U.S.
ExplntnTxt: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 SCHOLARSHIPS ARE GRANTED TO STUDENTS BASED ON ACADEMIC MERIT, ATHLETIC MERIT YND ACADEMIC DISCIPLINE. STUDENT LOANS ARE AWARDED BASED ON FEDERAL ELIGIBILITY GUIDELINES AS PROVIDED BY THE US DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION DIRECT LENDING PROGRAM. STUDENT ATHLETICS MUST FOLLOW THE RULES SET FORTH BY THE NCAA. ONCE A SCHOLARSHIP HAS BEEN AWARDED, THE UNIVERSITY CHECKS THE RECIPIENTS' GRADE POINT AVERAGE AT THE END OF EACH SCHOOL YEAR TO DETERMINE IF THEY ARE MEETING THE ACADEMIC STANDARD SET FORTH BY THE SCHOOL OR DONOR. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AT JOHNSON C. SMITH UNIVERSITY IS RESPONSIBLE FOR CHECKING EACH ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIP RECIPIENT'S GRADES BEFORE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED FOR THE NEXT SCHOOL YEAR. STUDENTS NOT MEETING SAP (SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS) WILL LOSE THEIR ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS. FOR NEEDS BASED SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS, THE PARENTS OF THE RECIPIENTS ARE REQUIRED TO SUBMIT A COPY OF THE TAX RETURN EACH YEAR TO THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE BEFORE NEW NEEDS BASED SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED. STUDENTS RECEIVING ATHLETIC SCHOLARSHIPS MUST MAINTAIN A 2.0 OR HIGHER GRADE POINT AVERAGE AND MUST PASS AT LEAST 6 CREDIT HOURS IN THE FALL SEMESTER AND 24 CREDIT HOURS FOR THE SCHOOL YEAR. THE ATHLETICS COMPLIANCE COORDINATOR CHECKS THE GRADE REPORT FOR EACH STUDENT ATHLETE. EACH STUDENT ATHLETE'S GRADE REPORT IS EXAMINED AT THE END OF THE SEMESTER TO SEE IF HE OR SHE IS MEETING THE SET STANDARDS. IF THEY ARE NOT MEETING STANDARDS, THEY WILL LOSE THEIR SCHOLARSHIPS. FOR ALL SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS, IF A STUDENT WITHDREW FROM THE UNIVERSITY BEFORE COMPLETING 60 PERCENT OR MORE OF A SEMESTER, THEIR FINANCIAL AID INCLUDING INTERNAL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE PRORATED BASED THE R2T4 (RETURN OF TITLE 4 FUNDS) CALCULATION.

REGARDING GRANTS & ASSISTANCE TO STUDENTS IN THE U.S.: THE COLLEGE DETERMINES THE STUDENTS' ELIGIBILITY PRIOR TO RELEASING THE GRANT, AND THEN MONITORS THEIR ENROLLMENT STATUS AND SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS.

THE COLLEGE (PRIMARILY THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT) MONITORS STUDENTS' FILES TO ENSURE THAT THEY RECEIVE THE NECESSARY FINANCIAL AID ASSISTANCE BASED ON GRADES, COURSE OF STUDY, FINANCIAL NEED, ETC. STUDENT FILES ARE REVIEWED ON AN ANNUAL BASIS TO ENSURE THAT THEY MEET ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS.

FINANCIAL AID DISBURSEMENTS ARE MADE TO STUDENTS QUALIFYING FOR FINANCIAL GRANTS AND ARE BASED ON DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED AS REPORTED THROUGH SCHOOL AND STUDENT SERVICE FOR FINANCIAL AID (SSSFA) APPLICATIONS. THEY ARE MONITORED IN ACCORDANCE WITH FEDERAL REGULATIONS.

MARYGROVE COLLEGE ASSISTS STUDENTS ON THE BASIS OF FINANCIAL NEED, STUDENT ACCOMPLISHMENT AND ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT. ALL STUDENTS REQUESTING FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE MUST COMPLETE THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID. THIS INFORMATION IS REVIEWED MARYGROVE COLLEGE FINANCIAL AID STAFF. GRANT AWARDS ARE CREDITED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT ACCOUNTS.

LINE 1 FOR 6/30/2014, MARYGROVE COLLEGE UPDATED THE FINANCIAL STATEMENT PRESENTATION OF ITS SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS. THIS ACCOUNTS FOR WHAT APPEARS TO BE A DROP IN FINANICAL AID AWARDS DUE TO A NETTING OF PELL EXPENSES AGAINST THE GRANT FUNDS. TOTAL GRANTS AWARDED HAVE REMAINED CONSISTENT BASED ON THE NUMBER OF STUDENTS RECEIVING FINANCIAL AID.
NEED-BASED GRANTS AWARDED BASED ON FINANCIAL AID NEEDS ANALYSIS. OTHER GRANTS/SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED BASED ON MEETING REQUIREMENTS SET FORTH BY THE DONOR.

THE COLLEGE PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIPS TO ENROLLED STUDENTS. AMOUNTS AWARDED ARE DETERMINED BY THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE COLLEGE'S AND FEDERAL AGENCY POLICIES. AMOUNTS GIVEN ARE CREDITED TO THE STUDENTS ACCOUNT.
The University awards financial aid to students based on certain eligibility requirements. The University's financial aid package is on file at the University and is available upon request.

ExplntnTxt: ALL GRANT RECIPIENTS ARE REQUIRED TO SATISFACTORILY FILL OUT A PRE-GRANT REQUEST APPLICATION CONFIRMING THE INTENDED USE OF THE FUNDS FOR CHARITABLE PURPOSES CONSISTENT WITH THE UNIVERSITY'S MISSION. THE GRANTEE ALSO ACKNOWLEDGES IN WRITING THEREIN THE REQUIREMENT THAT ALL FUNDS BE USED FOR SUCH PURPOSES, PERIODIC REPORTING ON EXPENDITURES, AND THAT FUNDS WILL NEED TO BE RETURNED TO GRANTOR IF NOT USED OR TO BE USED IN FURTHERANCE OF THE CHARITABLE PURPOSE. THESE PROVISIONS OF THE APPLICATION COINCIDE WITH THE PRIVATE FOUNDATION EXPENDITURE RESPONSIBILITY REQUIREMENTS OF IRS REGULATIONS.GRANTS TO INDIVIDUALS ARE ALL SCHOLARSHIPS MONITORED AS FOLLOWS:"Financial need" is the basis for assigning most institutional scholarship, based on analysis of family finances for tuition affordability.Some institutional scholarship is based on intern work exchangeSome institutional scholarship is based on merit assigned for different purposes for different scholarships, for instance, a donor may specify some criteria for some specific donated scholarship

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2, Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
ExplntnTxt: AWARDS TO UNDERGRADUATES ARE BASED PRIMARILY ON FINANCIAL NEED DETERMINED BY DOCUMENTED FINANCIAL AID ELIGIBILITY. INSTITUTIONAL NEED AND MERIT AWARDS, GOVERNMENT GRANTS AND OUTSIDE SCHOLARSHIPS PROVIDED AID TO 3,738 STUDENTS DURING THE YEAR. GRADUATE STUDENTS ARE ADMITTED BASED ON MERIT AS DETERMINED BY THE DEPARTMENT TO WHICH THEY ARE ADMITTED FOR STUDY AND THEY RECEIVE AID FROM THAT DEPARTMENT OR FROM EXTERNAL AGENCIES. LOANS ARE AWARDED TO ELIGIBLE STUDENTS BASED ON NEED. OVER $18 MILLION WAS PAID DIRECTLY TO STUDENTS (FORM 990, PART III, LINE 4A) WITH THE REMAINDER APPLIED INTERNALLY TO TUITION, FEES, AND ROOM AND BOARD.

THE COLLEGE FIRST INSPECTS CHARGES TO ENSURE THAT THEY ARE APPROPRIATE AND ALLOWABLE. THIS INCLUDES CHECKING CLERICAL ACCURACY AND CHECKING COMPLIANCE WITH APPLICABLE AGENCY AND FEDERAL GUIDELINES. THE COLLEGE ALSO MAKES SURE THAT EXPENSE FALLS WITHIN THE REQUIRED CATEGORIES AND BUDGET AMOUNTS. THE COLLEGE SETS UP A SEPARATE GENERAL LEDGER ACCOUNT FOR EACH GRANT THAT IS RECEIVED IN ORDER TO PROVIDE COMPLETE DOCUMENTATION AND TRACK EXPENSES.

A SCHOLARSHIP IS AN ACHIEVEMENT AWARD. AWARDS CAN BE BASED ON THE STUDENT'S AFFILIATION WITH A PARTICULAR MAJOR, BEING A PART OF A CLUB/GROUP, OR BASED ON THE STUDENT'S ACADEMIC RECORD. STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS FROM THE UNIVERSITY ARE MONITORED TO ENSURE THAT THEY MEET THE ACADEMIC REQUIREMENTS OR OTHER CRITERIA ASSOCIATED WITH THE AWARD. FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED IS ALSO PROVIDED TO STUDENTS. STUDENTS RECEIVING FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE BASED ON NEED ARE MONITORED TO ENSURE THEY MEET THE ACADEMIC REQUIREMENTS OR OTHER CRITERIA ASSOCIATED WITH THE FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE.

Scholarship recipients are selected based on established merit and need-based criteria. The Financial Aid Director and Academic Department Heads work together to select institutional scholarship recipients. Qualifications for scholarships vary. All scholarships are monitored by the Financial Aid Department.
SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2: THE STAFF COMMITTEE REVIEWS ALL REQUESTS FOR SCHOLARSHIPS TO ENSURE THAT EACH APPLICANT MEETS THE NECESSARY REQUIREMENTS.

ExplntnTxt: ALL GRANT EXPENDITURES ARE REVIEWED BY THE GRANT ACCOUNTANT FOR REASONABLENESS, ALLOWABLE EXPENDITURES, AND COMPLIANCE TO THE GRANT REGULATIONS AND CRITERIA. ALL SCHOLARSHIPS AND ASSISTANCE ARE PROVIDED AS A CREDIT TO THE STUDENT'S TUITION ACCOUNT.

In addition, the University has established research policies and procedures as guidelines to principal investigators in managing their grant at Brandeis University.

ExplntnTxt: PART I, LINE 2 The University provides grants and scholarships to students and applies the financial aid directly crediting each student's account.

THE ORGANIZATION PROVIDES FINANCIAL AID ONLY TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS ENROLLED AT THE UNIVERSITY. THE ADMISSIONS DEPARTMENT IS RESPONSIBLE FOR MANAGING THE FELLOWSHIP AND SCHOLARSHIP ALLOCATION FOR NEW STUDENTS. THE FACULTY AND THE ADMISSIONS DEPARTMENT WORK TOGETHER TO AWARD FELLOWSHIPS OR SCHOLARSHIPS TO NEW STUDENTS.
FINANCIAL AID IS AWARDED TO ELIGIBLE STUDENTS IN ACCORDANCE WITH DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION REGULATIONS AND REQUIREMENTS, AND MOUNT CARMEL HEALTH SYSTEM FOUNDATION REQUIREMENTS

THE TUITION RATE FOR ACADEMIC YEAR 2013-2014 WAS $41,400. ALL UNDERGRADUATES RECEIVED A SCHOLARSHIP CREDIT ON THEIR TUITION BILL FOR THAT AMOUNT WHICH IS NOT REFLECTED ABOVE IN SCHEDULE I, PART III. IN ADDITION, COOPER UNION AWARDED FEDERAL PELL GRANT TO 165 STUDENTS FOR $720,088 WHICH IS NOT REFLECTED ABOVE IN SCHEDULE I, PART III. STUDENTS WHO CAN DEMONSTRATE NEED, AS CALCULATED BY THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID, MAY BE ELIGIBLE FOR ADDITIONAL FINANCIAL AID. FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MONITOR THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS
ExplntnTxt: PART I, LINE 2 GRANTS TO ORGANIZATIONS IN THE U.S. THE ALLOCATION OF GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE TO LOCAL ORGANIZATIONS AND MUNICIPALITIES IS DETERMINED ON AN ANNUAL BASIS BY THE SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT FOR FINANCE AND ADMINISTRATION & TREASURER. GRANTS TO INDIVIDUALS IN THE U.S. ELIGIBILITY FOR BOWDOIN GRANT ASSISTANCE IS "NEED BASED," DETERMINED THROUGH ANALYSIS OF INCOME, ASSET AND TAX INFORMATION SUBMITTED ON THE COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIP SERVICE/FINANCIAL AID PROFILE, FEDERAL FAFSA AND FEDERAL INCOME TAX RETURNS. THE COLLEGE DOES NOT OFFER MERIT BASED SCHOLARSHIPS OTHER THAN SCHOLARSHIPS TO NATIONAL MERIT SCHOLARS. THE COLLEGE MAINTAINS A FINANCIAL AID OFFICE TO ENSURE THAT AWARDS ARE IN COMPLIANCE WITH ESTABLISHED POLICIES AND PROCEDURES.

THE COLLEGE MAINTAINS SEPARATE ACCOUNTS FOR EACH GRANT THAT WE RECEIVE. ON AN ANNUAL BASIS, WE RECEIVE AN AUDIT, IN ACCORDANCE WITH OMB CIRCULAR A-133 AND GOVERNMENT AUDITING STANDARDS. THE COLLEGE HAS PROCEDURES IN PLACE FOR MONITORING GRANTS TO ENSURE PROPER COMPLIANCE. CHAMPLAIN OFFERS BOTH MERIT AID AND NEED-BASED AID. MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS ARE RENEWED ANNUALLY PROVIDED THE STUDENT IS ENROLLED FULL-TIME AND MEETS ALL ACADEMIC STANDARDS. NEED-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS ARE RENEWED ANNUALLY BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED; THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) FORM MUST BE COMPLETED IN ORDER TO BE CONSIDERED FOR THESE AWARDS. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MONITORS STUDENTS TO ENSURE CONTINUED ELIGIBILITY FOR THE TYPE OF AID THEY ARE RECEIVING. AT THE END OF EACH SEMESTER (FALL, SPRING, SUMMER), EVERY FINANCIAL AID RECIPIENT'S PROGRESS IS REVIEWED BY THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID. STUDENTS ARE MEASURED USING BOTH QUALITATIVE AND QUANTITATIVE STANDARDS. THE PURPOSE OF THIS REVIEW IS TO MEASURE WHETHER A STUDENT IS MAKING SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS TOWARDS GRADUATION. THESE STANDARDS APPLY TO ALL TYPES OF FINANCIAL AID: FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITUTIONAL AID. STUDENTS WHO FAIL TO MEET THE SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS REQUIREMENTS MAY BECOME INELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE FINANCIAL AID UNTIL THEY ARE IN COMPLIANCE WITH THESE REQUIREMENTS.
THE COLLEGE DIRECTLY CREDITS EACH STUDENTS' ACCOUNT WHO RECEIVES ANY FEDERAL FINANCIAL AID OR OUTSIDE SCHOLARSHIPS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: STUDENTS ELIGIBILITY IS MONITORED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AND AUDITED ANNUALLY BY THE A133 AUDIT.

EACH GRANT IS ASSIGNED A SEPARATE DEPARTMENT ACCOUNT NUMBER. REPORTS ARE THEN PRINTED WHICH SHOW ALL FUNDS RECEIVED AND DISBURSED. THESE GRANT REPORTS ARE PRINTED ON A MONTHLY BASIS BY THE PERSON RESPONSIBLE FOR THE GRANT. THE ACCOUNTING DEPARTMENT ALSO PRINTS GRANT REPORTS ON A MONTHLY BASIS AS A CHECK THAT DISBURSEMENTS ARE NOT GREATER THAN FUNDS RECEIVED AND THAT FUNDS ARE BEING DISBURSED FOR GRANTS APPROVED.

Academic excellence and demonstrated financial need are used to determine each student's financial aid. The financial aid consists of any combinAtion of grants and loans and are reviewed each year based on a student's academic record and/or demonstrated need. The free application for federal student aid, which helps to establish a student's financial need, serves as the application for tuition scholarships. Schedule I, Part III Cash grants are credits to student accounts.

Wheaton Franciscan Healthcare and Franciscan Ministries maintain files and records to manage the decision-making and award process for organizations that it provides community sponsorship dollars to. Decisions are made by a Community Sponsorship Committee with leaders who hold positions in Diversity, Strategic Planning, Mission Services, Marketing and Philanthropy. The Committee generally strives to sponsor organizations that have missions that align with the mission, vision and values of Wheaton Franciscan Healthcare and/or Franciscan Ministries. The committee also looks for certain other criteria when deciding which organizations will receive contributions, including but not limited to supporting healthcare or housing related activities within the Southeast Wisconsin, Iowa, and Illinois markets, supporting programming that work to further diversity and cultural competency, aligning with other WFH business relationships or service lines, supporting student academic achievement or workforce development initiatives, and finally, supporting environmental "green" initiatives. Leaders periodically meet with representatives of sponsored organizations to discuss objectives including how dollars will be spent. Additionally, Wheaton Franciscan Healthcare may, at a later date, ask for documentation in order to monitor that funds were spent for their intended purpose. Currently, confirmation letters are sent to sponsored organizations when award dollars are given, that confirm the dollar amount awarded and the intended purpose, with a request that the recipient acknowledge receipt of the funds in written correspondence. Files are maintained in the Organizational Change and Leadership Performance Department to include copies of letters of request, award and denial letters, additional documentation if requested, along with acknowledgement receipts from sponsored organizations.

ALL GRANT FUNDS ARE MONITORED WITH AT LEAST TWO DIFFERENT DEPARTMENTS WHICH CREATES CHECKS AND BALANCES TO ENSURE THAT THE FUNDS ARE TRACKED, REPORTED AND USED AS REQUIRED IN THE GRANT LANGUAGE. TITLE IV GRANT FUNDS ARE AWARDED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AND APPLIED TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT VIA FINANCIAL AID TRANSMITTAL. AS STUDENTS COMPLETE THEIR REQUIREMENTS FOR RECEIVING AID, WEEKLY TRANSMITTALS ARE RUN AND STUDENTS, WITH THE PROPER CODING ARE SELECTED TO RECEIVE AID. THE TRANSMITTAL GENERATES A LISTING OF EACH AWARD, BY TYPE WITH TOTALS, AND IS USED TO RECORD THE GRANT EXPENSE TO THE GENERAL LEDGER. FEDERAL AWARDS AND GRANTS ARE VERIFIED TO A RECEIVABLE IN THE GENERAL LEDGER THAT IS RECORDED FROM AN AUTHORIZATION LETTER AND TO THE AVAILABLE BALANCE IN THE G5 PAYMENT MANAGEMENT SYSTEM. IF THE AVAILABLE BALANCE IS SUFFICIENT, THE FUNDS ARE DRAWN DOWN THROUGH THE G5 PAYMENT MANAGEMENT SYSTEM INTO THE FEDERAL FUNDS CHECKING ACCOUNT. A BANK ACH REPORT IS GENERATED TO VERIFY THAT THE FUNDS ARE RECEIVED. THE GENERAL LEDGER ACCOUNTS ARE VERIFIED TO GRANTS BY TYPE ON THE FINANCIAL AID SYSTEM AND BILLING TRANSACTIONS ON THE BILLING FILE. THESE SYSTEMS ARE RECONCILED TO EACH DRAW DOWN.
The college provides scholarships under an application process.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Procedure for Monitroing Grant Funds in the United States
ExplntnTxt: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2: Grants are put into a separate and unique fund and the expenditures are monitored against the proposal and award. The College manages an extensive financial aid program to ensure that a highly qualified and diverse population is able to matriculate and continue to graduation. The assistance programs take two major forms: merit scholarships and need-based financial aid. The financial aid department monitors the amounts given by the grant.

GRANTS GIVEN TO CSUSM ARE FOR STUDENT SCHOLARSHIPS AND THE UNIVERSITY MONITORS THE FUNDS GIVEN TO EACH STUDENT. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE OF THE UNIVERSITY QUALIFIES APPLICANTS FOR SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON CRITERIA OVER WHICH THE FOUNDATION HAS NO CONTROL. EXPENDITURES ON GRANTS AND CONTRACTS ARE CLOSELY MONITORED BY THE FOUNDATION STAFF TO COMPLY WITH SPONSOR REQUIREMENTS.

AS PART OF OUR MISSION, SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED ON SELECTION BY A COMMITTEE UPON SUBMISSION OF AN APPLICATION TO BE USED TOWARDS THE COST OF ATTENDANCE. THESE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED ON A TRIMESTER BASIS. ADDITIONALLY, TUITION LEVERAGE AWARDS ARE OFFERED BASED ON MERIT. THESE AWARDS ARE FOR TUITION ONLY AND FOLLOW THE STUDENT FOR THEIR PERIOD OF ENROLLMENT AS LONG AS THEY MAINTAIN GOOD STANDING.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: All WellSpan non-research grant activities must be coordinated through the York Health Foundation and Gettysburg Hospital Foundation to insure that grant projects are implemented, evaluated, and monitored in accordance with applicable granting agency regulations, with WellSpan policies and procedures, and are consistent with the strategies and priorities of the organization. WellSpan has defined the processes by which grants are identified, developed, reviewed, approved, and monitored by the organization. This policy covers non-research grants applied for and received by an entity of WellSpan Health. It does not cover grants made by the organization. Research grants are defined as those that involve "a systematic investigation designed to develop or contribute to generalizable knowledge (45CFR 46.102(d))" and are overseen by Emig Research Center (Policy #619 Extramural Research Funding)

THE COLLEGE'S GRANTS ARE PRIMARILY MONITORED IN THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT THROUGH THE UTILIZATION OF WRITTEN AND ELECTRONIC DOCUMENTATION. STUDENTS RECEIVING GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE DEEMED WORTHY BY THE COLLEGE'S ASSESSMENT ON THE BASIS OF ACHIEVEMENT AND FINANCIAL NEED.
GRANT FUNDS ARE MONITORED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AND ACCOUNTING OFFICES.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS - PART I, LINE 2:
ExplntnTxt: THE INSTITUTE ENSURES THAT ITS GRANTS OF FINANCIAL AID ARE USED BY STUDENTS FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES BY CREDITING THE AID DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS OR THROUGH ITS FINANCIAL AID COMPLIANCE PROCESSES. THE INSTITUTE ALSO PROVIDES FUNDING FOR TRAVEL EXPENSES, WHICH HAS BEEN INCLUDED IN THE TOTAL ABOVE, FOR STUDENTS WHOSE PROJECT PROPOSALS HAVE BEEN APPROVED BY THE PRESIDENT.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2, Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
ExplntnTxt: MIT PROVIDES SEVERAL TYPES OF GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE TO INDIVIDUALS AND ORGANIZATIONS. FOR PRIZES AND AWARDS, THE INDIVIDUAL OR ORGANIZATION MUST HAVE MET THE SPECIFIC CRITERIA TO BE SELECTED FOR THE PRIZE OR AWARD. IN THE CASE OF FELLOWSHIPS AND SCHOLARSHIPS, THE INDIVIDUAL IS REQUIRED TO UTILIZE THE FUNDS IN FURTHERANCE OF THEIR EDUCATION AT MIT. MIT MAKES GRANTS TO SEVERAL LOCAL CHAPTERS OF NATIONAL FRATERNITIES, SORORITIES AND INDEPENDENT LIVING GROUPS. THESE ORGANIZATIONS ARE COMPRISED OF MIT STUDENTS, AND HOUSE THESE STUDENTS. GRANTS ARE MADE TO SUPPORT THE OPERATIONAL COSTS OF THE EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES OF THE HOUSES (SO THAT THE HOUSES STAY CONSISTENT WITH MIT'S MISSION). IN ORDER FOR AN ORGANIZATION TO RECEIVE AN IRDF GRANT, THEY MUST GO THROUGH A RIGOROUS APPLICATION PROCESS. MIT GENERALLY DOES NOT MAKE DISBURSEMENTS TO INDIVIDUALS OR ORGANIZATIONS FOR CHARITABLE PURPOSES, EXCEPT THROUGH THE MIT COMMUNITY SERVICE FUND. THIS FUND'S RESOURCES COME PRIMARILY FROM CONTRIBUTIONS FROM MEMBERS OF THE MIT COMMUNITY. MIT DISBURSES THESE FUNDS FOR CHARITABLE PURPOSES INCLUDING SMALL GRANTS, INSUBSTANTIAL IN THE AGGREGATE, TO LOCALLY BASED CHARITABLE ORGANIZATIONS FOR THE PURPOSE OF FOSTERING BETTER COMMUNITY RELATIONS. PROCEDURES OF THE INSTITUTE WITH RESPECT TO ADMISSIONS, SCHOLARSHIPS, FELLOWSHIPS, AND STUDENT LOANS ARE PUBLICIZED IN THE INSTITUTE BULLETIN WHICH CONSTITUTES ITS CATALOGUE. GRANTS ARE MADE IN THE CONTEXT OF ACADEMIC OR RESEARCH PROGRAMS: RECIPIENTS SPEND THEIR GRANT FUNDS UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE PROGRAM AND ARE ACCOUNTABLE THROUGH THE PROGRAM FOR THE USE OF THE FUNDS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Form Sch I Part I Line 2
ExplntnTxt: GENERAL INFORMATION ON GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE THE COLLEGE REVIEWS THE FUND BALANCES FOR THE ENDOWED SCHOLARSHIPS ANNUALLY AND THE BOARD APPROVES PROPOSED AMOUNTS TO AWARD FROM THE ENDOWMENT SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS EACH YEAR. OTHER INSTITUTIONAL SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS ARE INCLUDED IN THE COLLEGE'S BUDGET THAT IS APPROVED BY THE BOARD. EACH SCHOLARSHIP OR GRANT AWARDED HAS WRITTEN CRITERIA USED TO DETERMINE HOW THE FUNDS ARE AWARDED. COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS AWARDED MUST FIRST BE APPLIED TO TUITION, FEES AND HOUSING CHARGES (IF APPLICABLE) BEFORE IT CAN BE DISBURSED TO THE STUDENT.
PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE US: GRANTS ARE MADE TO ACCREDITED SCHOOLS AND SEMINARIES. BOTH FINANCIAL AND NARRATIVE REPORTS OF GRANT ACTIVITIES ARE REQUIRED.

THE UNIVERSITY MAINTAINS STUDENT FINANCIAL AID RECORDS AND FOLLOWS APPROPRIATE SELECTION CRITERIA FOR ALL GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE AWARDED TO STUDENTS. THE UNIVERSITY HAS AN ANNUAL COMPLIANCE AUDIT CONDUCTED IN ACCORDANCE WITH OMB CIRCULAR A-133 EACH YEAR. FOR THE YEAR ENDED 6/30/2014, THE AUDIT REPORTED THAT THE UNIVERSITY COMPLIED, IN ALL MATERIAL RESPECTS, WITH THE COMPLIANCE REQUIREMENTS OF ITS MAJOR FEDERAL PROGRAMS.
HOPE SCHOLARSHIP/GRANT FUNDS ARE DISBURSED TO THE RECIPIENT UPON PROOF OF ELIGILIBITY (I.E. FINANCIAL NEED OR ACADEMIC MERIT) AND UPON PROOF OF EXPENSE INCURRED.

99% OF TOTAL GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE ARE RELATED TO INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL AID FOR WHICH STUDENTS APPLY THROUGH THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. ALL AID IS AWARDED BASED ON CERTAIN GUIDELINES AND IS CREDITED DIRECTLY TO STUDENTS' TUITION ACCOUNTS. ALL AWARDS ARE DIRECTLY RELATED TO THE STUDENTS' EDUCATION AT THE INSTITUTION'S PHYSICAL LOCATION IN THE UNITED STATES. IN ADDITION TO MANDATORY CLASS ATTENDANCE, STUDENTS ARE REQUIRED TO COMPLETE A REVIEW OF ART WITH INSTRUCTORS AT THE END OF EACH SEMESTER TO RECEIVE CREDIT. TRAVELING SCHOLARS WORKS ARE REVIEWD BY COMMITTEE A YEAR LATER AND ONE INDIVIDUAL IS SELECTED FOR A ONE PERSON SHOW AT THE MFA. FACULTY ENRICHMENT AWARDS ARE GIVEN TO CURRENT, ON-SITE FACULTY MEMBER TO PURSUE VARIOUS PROJECTS.

ExplntnTxt: Rocky Mountain College awards financial aid which comes from federal and state funds, endowment funds, donations, etc. The students are selected based on the individual fund requirements and is posted to their account as a reduction. If funds exceed tuition and fees, the student is given the extra funds for living expenses.

ADMISSION TO POMONA COLLEGE IS ON A NEED BLIND BASIS. THIS POLICY IS MAINTAINED TO ACCOMPLISH DIVERSIFICATION OF THE STUDENT BODY REGARDLESS OF THE FINANCIAL STATUS OF THE APPLICANTS. A PERMANENT FILE OF ALL STUDENTS WHO ARE RECIPIENTS OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS IS MAINTAINED IN THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE OF POMONA COLLEGE. AN ACCOUNTING SYSTEM TRACKS ALL AWARDS TO INDIVIDUAL STUDENTS FOR TUITION AND OTHER COSTS OF ATTENDING THE COLLEGE.

In addition to the $33,635,571 of grants and other assistance to individuals in the united states that was included in the audited financial statements, an additional $538,550 of financial aid, which includes emergency student assistance, HBD Graduate scholars, national merit scholarships and research awards, is included on Schedule I and Part IX, Statement of Functional Expenses.

All students who are applying for Federal financial aid are required to complete the FAFSA and the Gordon-Conwell financial aid application. The information obtained from these documents is used by the Financial Aid Office to determine eligibility of Federal and institutional aid. To assist with determining their eligibility, each student is assigned an institutional budget for the cost of attendance. This budget includes tuition, books and fees, room and board, health insurance, transportation, and a miscellaneous category. In general, Gordon-Conwell scholarships are either need-based or merit-based and any Gordon-Conwell aid that is awarded is factored into the eligibility for Federal aid.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PART III, FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE/CHARITY CARE
ExplntnTxt: ALEGENT CREIGHTON HEALTH RECOGNIZES THE RIGHT TO QUALITY HEALTHCARE REGARDLESS OF AGE, SEX, RACE, RELIGION, NATIONAL ORIGIN, OR ABILITY TO PAY. BUSINESS OFFICE STAFF HELPS PATIENTS SEEK LOCAL, STATE, AND FEDERAL REIMBURSEMENT AT NO CHARGE WHEN NO OTHER SOURCE OF PAYMENT IS AVAILABLE. FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE IS PROVIDED TO PATIENTS WITH DEMONSTRATED INABILITY TO PAY FOR MEDICALLY NECESSARY SERVICES. THESE FUNDS ARE DIRECTLY USED TO OFFSET THE PATIENTS ACCOUNTS RECEIVABLE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2, Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
ExplntnTxt: MOST DISBURSEMENTS IN FURTHERANCE OF THE ORGANIZATION'S EXEMPT PROGRAMS ARE MADE DIRECTLY IN THE ACTIVE CONDUCT OF THE ACTIVITIES CONSTITUTING THE EXEMPT PURPOSE OR FUNCTION OF THE ORGANIZATION. OTHERWISE, DISTRIBUTIONS IN FURTHERANCE OF THE INSTITUTION'S EXEMPT PROGRAMS ARE MADE IN ACCORDANCE WITH PROCEDURES OR SUBJECT TO CONDITIONS ESTABLISHED BY THE INSTITUTION'S GOVERNING BOARD OR MANAGEMENT DESIGNED TO ENSURE THAT RECIPIENTS OF SUCH DISBURSEMENTS FROM THE ORGANIZATION ARE ADEQUATELY INVESTIGATED AND GRANTED TO QUALIFIED RECIPIENTS. ALEGENT CREIGHTON HEALTH ONLY DISTRIBUTES FUNDS TO OTHER 501(C)(3) ORGANIZATIONS WITH THE SAME MISSION AND PURPOSE AS THE ALEGENT CREIGHTON HEALTH SYSTEM. THESE DISTRIBUTIONS ARE MONITORED TO ENSURE THEY ARE BEING USED AS SPECIFIED BY THE ORGANIZATION.

EMERSON COLLEGE AWARDS INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE PRIMARILY ON THE BASIS OF DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED. COLLEGE MONITORING OF THE FUNDS INCLUDES DIRECTLY CREDITING AWARDS TO THE STUDENT ACCOUNTS WHICH ASSURES THAT FUNDS ARE USED FOR THE EDUCATION PURPOSE INTENDED. ALL AID RECIPIENTS MUST MAINTAIN SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS AS OUTLINED IN THE EMERSON COLLEGE STUDENT HANDBOOK. STUDENTS RECEIVING FEDERAL AID MUST HAVE A MINIMUM OF A "C" (2.0) GRADE POINT AVERAGE BY THE END OF THEIR SECOND ACADEMIC YEAR. FINANCIAL AID RECIPIENTS MAY NOT BE IN DEFAULT ON ANY EDUCATION LOANS, OWE A REFUND ON ANY GRANT OR DEMONSTRATE ANY UNWILLINGNESS TO REPAY AN EDUCATIONAL LOAN.

Susquehanna Physician Services, Williamsport Area Ambulance Service Cooperative, and Susquehanna Health Foundation are related organizations and part of the Susquehanna Health System with consistent management oversight ensuring the use of funds for charitable purposes. Susquehanna Community Health and Dental Clinic is a former service of Susquehanna Health System that is being converted to a Federally Qualified Health Clinic (FQHC). "Look-alike" status was received effective 12/06/11. Susquehanna Health System continues to support the clinics financially until full FQHC status is obtained and they are able to operate by their own means. All requests for funding are supported by detailed records of cash receipts and disbursements, as well as cash flow projections prepared by an independent accounting firm.

THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE PROCESSES FINANCIAL AID REQUESTS. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICERS FIRST DETERMINE THE AMOUNT OF FEDERAL AND STATE STUDENT AID THAT THE STUDENT WILL RECEIVE. STUDENTS ARE THEN AWARDED SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON THEIR AVAILABLE RESOURCES AND OUTSTANDING CHARGES.

Form 990, Sch I,Line 2: Students who wish to be considered for financial aid complete an application - the PROFILE from the college scholarship service to apply for college grants and scholarships. Financial aid awards are reviewed at the end of each semester and may be withdrawn if a receipient's citizenship or academic work does not meet the standards of the college. College-sponsored grants and scholarships are limited to 8 semesters and require full-time enrollment. Financial aid receipients must maintain minimum satisfactory academic progress. Hampden-Sydney offers several scholarships, awarded without regard to financial need, which recognize outstanding academic and extracurricular achievement. All applicants for admission are automatically considered for academic scholarships.

Monitoring Use of Grants Assistance to Mercer University students in the form of scholarships are awardeD for the purpose of aiding with the cost of attending the university, i.e. for tuition, housing, and meals. Scholarships are based on academic achievement, need, and other donor requirements such as location of residence. Mercer University has criteria for the eligibility requirements needed to award a scholarship. Academic Scholarships are based on SAT scores and Grade Point Averages and are awarded by the Office of Admissions. Need based grants are made by the Office of Financial Planning and are made utilizing the federal need formula (FAFSA application). Students must be enrolled full-time to receive University scholarships/grants. Generally speaking, FAFSA data is verified for students who are selected for verification by the federal student aid program.

THE DIRECTOR OF FINANCIAL AID'S OFFICE MAINTAINS ALL DOCUMENTATION TO SUPPORT THAT THE AWARDED STUDENTS HAVE SATISFIED THE ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS FOR THE VARIOUS GRANTS PROVIDED TO THE UNIVERSITY FOR STUDENTS. CRITERIA FOR AWARDING ANY GRANTS IS ALSO MAINTAINED BY THE DIRECTOR OF FINANCIAL AID'S OFFICE AND IS APPROVED BY THE VP OF ENROLLMENT.

SALEM GRANTS FUNDS IN THE WAY OF SCHOLARSHIPS TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS IN ITS ACADEMY AND COLLEGE. SALEM MAINTAINS RECORDS ON ALL STUDENTS RECEIVING FINANCIAL AID IN THE FORM OF SALEM GRANTS OR FROM OTHER SOURCES. SALEM COLLEGE COMPLIES WITH ALL APPLICABLE FEDERAL RULES AS IT RELATES TO COLLEGE FINANCIAL AID.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PART III, COLUMN B:
ExplntnTxt: SCHEDULE I, PART III, COLUMN B: THE VAST MAJORITY OF SALEM'S COLLEGE STUDENTS RECEIVE SOME FORM OF SCHOLARSHIP FROM THE COLLEGE. SALEM PROVIDES THIS ASSISTANCE THROUGH ENDOWED SCHOLARSHIPS AND INSTITUTIONAL REMISSION (DISCOUNT). SALEM COMPLIES WITH ALL FEDERAL AND STATE REGULATION REGARDING THE REWARDING OF STUDENT FINANCIAL AID AND FILES THE REQUISITE INFORMATION WITH FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCIES AS IT PERTAINS TO ITS STUDENTS.
