HERITAGE UNIVERSITY PARTICIPATES IN FEDERAL GRANTS AND LOAN PROGRAMS. ALL OF THE STUDENT AWARDING PROCESS IS DOCUMENTED IN THE SOFTWARE USED TO DETERMINE ELIGIBILITY AND TRACK STUDENT AWARDS. FOR THOSE AWARDS WITH SUBJECTIVE SELECTION CRITERIA, THE DOCUMENTATION IS MAINTAINED BY THE PERSON RESPONSIBLE FOR SUCH AWARDS OR GRANTS. HERITAGE UNIVERSITY UNDERGOES A YEARLY AUDIT OF THE GRANTS AND OTHER FEDERAL FUNDS IN ACCORDANCE WITH A-133; A-87; AND OTHERS.

WHEN DETERMINING THE DISTRIBUTION OF GRANTS AND LOANS TO STUDENTS, THE CULINARY INSTITUTE OF AMERICA COMPLIES WITH THEGUIDELINES OF THE U.S. DEPT. OF EDUCATION - TITLE IV REGULATIONS, NY STATE BOARD OF REGENTS AND THE ACCREDITING COMMISSION OF CAREER SCHOOLS AND COLLEGES OF TECHNOLOGY (ACCSCT) AND MIDDLE STATES ASSOCIATION COMMISSION ON HIGHER EDUCATION.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS BASED ON NEED, ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE, AND/OR ENROLLMENT STATUS. SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS (SAP) IS THE MEANS USED TO MONITOR THE SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED. SAP MEASURES BOTH QUALITATIVE AND QUANTITATIVE PROGRESS. THE AWARDS ARE USED FOR TUITION, ROOM, AND BOARD.

THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID DETERMINES A STUDENT'S ELIGIBILITY BASED ON THE FAMILY'S FINANCIAL STRENGTH, WHICH INCLUDES CONSIDERATION OF FAMILY INCOME AND ASSETS, NUMBER OF CHILDREN IN COLLEGE AND IF APPROPRIATE, SPECIAL CIRCUMSTANCES. FINANCIAL AID WILL BE REVOKED WITHOUT ADEQUATE PROGRESS.
The College monitors enrollment and the Financial Aid Office of the College keeps the requisite records in either an electronic or hard copy form.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS - PART I, LINE 2:
ExplntnTxt: THE COLLEGE ENSURES THAT ITS GRANTS OF STUDENT FINANCIAL AID ARE USED FOR THE INTENDED EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES BY APPLYING THE AWARDS DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENTS' TUITION BALANCES INSTEAD OF ISSUING CHECKS. THE COLLEGE ALSO MAKES ENTREPRENEURIAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL GRANTS THROUGH ITS LAUNCH U PROGRAM AND GREEN EDGE FUND. POTENTIAL GRANTEES SUBMIT APPLICATIONS FOR THE GRANTS, AND AFTER A RIGOROUS REVIEW PROCESS, GRANTS ARE AWARDED. GRANTEES ARE REQUIRED TO SUBMIT REPORTS WHICH INDICATE HOW THE GRANT FUNDS WERE SPENT.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: GRANTS TO THE CITY OF OBERLIN - PART II:
ExplntnTxt: THE COLLEGE MADE MULTIPLE GRANTS TO THE CITY OF OBERLIN FOR THE FOLLOWING PURPOSES: GREEN EDGE FUND GRANT: $30,000; GRANT FOR FIRE TRUCK: $30,000; GRANT FOR FIREWORKS: $1,500; GRANT FOR MOBILE APP PROJECT: $1,333; TOTAL GRANTS: $62,833.

Scholarships are awarded to students of the college based on various criteria. These criteria include financial need, grade point average, and others as established by the scholarship documents. Scholarships are applied to the individual student's accounts to pay tuition, room and board expenses. Part III - The number of recipients shown for Schedule I Part III is based on the number of grants awarded. The amount is used as a reasonable estimate of the total number of students awarded grants and scholarships.
Actual amounts granted to recipients via aid posting.

The scholarship related records are maintained in the Financial Aid office. There is a scholarship committee established to formulate guidelines and procedures as to the eligibility and criteria for each scholarship being awarded. Additionally, records supporting non scholarship type grants are also maintained between grant accounting and the Office of Grants and Sponsored Research.

FAES PROVIDES VARIOUS HONORARIA, FELLOWSHIPS AND TRAVEL AWARDS THROUGHOUT THE YEAR. AMOUNTS OF THIS ASSISTANCE RANGE FROM $50 TO $5,000, WITH MOST HONORARIA AWARDS IN THE $1,000 TO $2,000 RANGE. FAES MAINTAINS RECORDS TO SUBSTANTIATE THE AMOUNTS OF ASSISTANCE, AND THE SELECTION CRITERIA AND ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS AS SET BY THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS. FAES ALSO COMPLIES WITH TAX REPORTING REQUIREMENTS FOR THESE INDIVIDUALS. FURTHER INFORMATION REGARDING THESE POLICIES CAN BE OBTAINED UPON REQUEST.

The College follows federal, state and institutional policies and regulations to monitor grants and funds: (1) the student applies for the grant; (2) grants are awarded from the various funding sources depending on need and/or academic standing; (3) the students eligibility is verified through federal, state and institutional requirements, matriculation, registration, attendance and academic progress; (4) grants and awards are processed onto the student's account; (5) where loans are involved, the College follows up with the regulatory requirements after graduation. The Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) is an integral part of this process.

THE UNIVERSITY HAS ESTABLISHED POLICIES, PROCEDURES, AND CONTROLS OVER THE AWARDING, DISBURSING, AND MONITORING OF STUDENT FINANCIAL AID OR ASSISTANCE TO INDIVIDUAL STUDENTS IN COMPLIANCE WITH FEDERAL AND STATE OF NEW JERSEY REGULATIONS AND REQUIREMENTS. IN ADDITION, THE UNIVERSITY HAS AN EXTERNAL AUDIT PERFORMED IN ACCORDANCE WITH U.S. OFFICE OF MANAGEMENT AND BUDGET CIRCULAR A-133 AND NEW JERSEY OFFICE OF MANAGEMENT AND BUDGET CIRCULAR 04-04. THE UNIVERSITY HAS PROCEDURES AND CONTROLS IN PLACE OVER THE AWARDING, DISBURSING, AND MONITORING OF SUBAWARDS MADE TO ORGANIZATIONS. THESE INCLUDE REVIEWING THE ANNUAL FINANCIAL STATEMENT AND SINGLE AUDIT REPORTS OF THE ORGANIZATION AND REVIEWING ALL SUPPORTING DOCUMENTATION INCLUDING INVOICES RECEIVED BY THE ORGANIZATION.

THE COLLEGE REVIEWS ALL OF AMERICAN SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA'S EXPENDITURES FOR WHICH ITS GRANTS ARE INTENDED. ASSISTANCE FOR INDIVIDUAL STUDENTS IS PROVIDED THROUGH FEDERAL, STATE AND COLLEGE PROGRAMS AND EXTERNAL AGENCIES. THE COLLEGE ADMINISTERS THESE PROGRAMS. TYPICALLY, FINANCIAL AID FUNDS ADMINISTERED BY THE COLLEGE ARE AWARDED ON THE BASIS OF FINANCIAL NEED (AS DETERMINED BY THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT, DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION, STATE AGENCIES, THE COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIP SERVICES, AND BARD COLLEGE), ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, AND PROMISE. THE COLLEGE'S OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID IS RESPONSIBLE FOR AWARDING AND MONITORING FEDERAL AND STATE FINANCIAL AID DISTRIBUTIONS. STUDENTS APPLY FOR FINANCIAL AID BY COMPLETING A FAFSA FORM WHICH DETERMINES ELGIBILITY. STUDENT ELIGIBILITY IS PERIODICALLY MONITORED TO ENSURE THAT GRANT AWARDS ARE USED FOR THEIR INTENDED PURPOSE.

SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS FOR STUDENTS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO A STUDENT'S UNIVERSITY ACCOUNT AND APPLIED TO TUITION, FEES, ROOM AND BOARD. ALL FINANCIAL AID IS SUBJECT TO REVISION BASED ON AVAILABILITY, CHANGES IN FAMILY CONTRIBUTION, HOUSING STATUS, AND/OR CREDIT LOAD. SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS MUST BE MAINTAINED ACCORDING TO STANDARDS PRESCRIBED BY THE UNIVERSITY. ANNUAL RENEWAL OF FINANCIAL AID IS CONTINUOUS IF INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL NEED REMAINS, ALL REQUIRED DOCUMENTS ARE COMPLETED BY THE PUBLISHED DEADLINE AND SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS IS MAINTAINED CONSISTENT WITH THE UNIVERSITY'S POLICY.

SCHOLARSHIPS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO INSTITUTIONAL CHARGES. DIRECT COSTS INCURRED TO SUPPORT THE PRIMARY FUNCTIONS OF WALSH COLLEGE ARE SPECIFICALLY IDENTIFIED TO THE BENEFITING ACTIVITY. RESTRICTED FUNDS, INCLUDING FEDERAL AWARDS, ARE RECORDED IN SEPARATE FUNDS AND DIRECT EXPENDITURES OF THESE PROGRAMS ARE RESTRICTED TO THE EXCLUSIVE PURPOSE OF THE AWARD. ALL SPONSORED PROJECTS ARE INCLUDED IN THE DIRECT COST BASE. INDIRECT COSTS ARE ALLOCATED PROPORTIONALLY AS PRESCRIBED IN OMB CIRCULAR A-21. ANY UNDER RECOVERY OF INDIRECT COSTS FROM ANY SPONSORED ACTIVITY IS NOT CHARGED TO ANY OTHER SPONSORED PROJECT EITHER DIRECTLY OR INDIRECTLY.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2, Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
ExplntnTxt: DISBURSEMENTS IN FURTHERANCE OF THE UNIVERSITY'S EXEMPT PROGRAMS ARE MADE IN ACCORDANCE WITH PROCEDURES OR SUBJECT TO CONDITIONS ESTABLISHED BY THE INSTITUTION'S GOVERNING BOARD DESIGNED TO INSURE THAT INDIVIDUALS AND ORGANIZATIONS RECEIVING DISBURSEMENTS FROM THE ORGANIZATION IN FURTHERANCE OF ITS EXEMPT PROGRAMS ARE ADEQUATELY INVESTIGATED TO INSURE THAT THEY ARE QUALIFYING RECIPIENTS. STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS, STUDENT LOANS, ETC. ARE JUDGED WORTHY BY THE INSTITUTION'S ASSESSMENT ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEEDS AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part III, column(b), Estimated Number of Recipients
ExplntnTxt: NAME=MERIT-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS,DESCRIPTION=TOTAL FOR AWARD CATEGORY DIVIDED BY AVERAGE AWARD AMOUNT.;NAME=NEED-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS,DESCRIPTION=TOTAL FOR AWARD CATEGORY DIVIDED BY AVERAGE AWARD AMOUNT.;NAME=DEMOGRAPHIC-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS,DESCRIPTION=TOTAL FOR AWARD CATEGORY DIVIDED BY AVERAGE AWARD AMOUNT.;NAME=PROGRAM/CAREER-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS,DESCRIPTION=TOTAL FOR AWARD CATEGORY DIVIDED BY AVERAGE AWARD AMOUNT.;

The financial aid planning office requires students to complete the free application for federal student aid (FAFSA) form to determine eligibility for federal, state and institutional grants, scholarships and loans. This is an equitable formula that measures all assets consistently. In addition to this form, the institution does require some other guidelines in the event that funds are offered based on certain academic credentials or performance in a university sponsored activity or athletic event. These credentials are clearly stated in the university catalog and the university website. Enrollment and eligibility are monitred by the university.

The College awards scholarships and financial aid awards. These funds are disbursed by the College's Financial Aid Department in strict adherence to all Federal and state regulations. The College also grants money to Ealham Foundation, a related organization, to hold and invest the assets on the College's behalf.

GRANTS ARE MONITORED BY VARIOUS AREAS. FINANCIAL AID GRANTS ARE MONITORED BY THE FINANCIAL AID DIRECTOR TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH ELIGIBILITY, SELECTION, AND DISTRIBUTION. DOCUMENTATION IS MAINTAINED AND AUDITED ANNUALLY. OTHER DEPARTMENT GRANTS ARE MONITORED BY THE RESPONSIBLE PARTY TO ENSURE THAT EXPENDITURES COMPLY WITH GRANT REQUIREMENTS AND ARE NOT DIVERTED FOR OTHER USES. THE NC BUDGET OFFICE REQUIRES PERIODIC REPORTING FOR ALL GRANTS. THE REPORTING IS COMPLETED BY THE RESPONSIBLE DEPARTMENT AND THEN ENTERED INTO THE STATE WEBSITE BY THE CONTROLLER ANNUALLY.

FOR SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS, ALL FUNDS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY FROM THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE TO THE STUDENT'S OUTSTANDING BALANCE AT THE COLLEGE. USE IS CONTROLLED INTERNALLY BY THE COLLEGE. NECO SCHOLARSHIPS REQUIRE A MINIMUM 3.4 GRADE POINT AVERAGE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2, Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
ExplntnTxt: ST. JOHN'S HOSPITAL PARTICIPATES IN VARIOUS FEDERAL LOAN AND GRANT PROGRAMS. THESE PROGRAMS ARE ADMINISTERED IN ACCORDANCE WITH GUIDELINES ESTABLISHED BY THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION, AND THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES. THESE PROGRAMS ARE AUDITED ANNUALLY IN ACCORDANCE WITH OMB CIRCULAR A-133 "AUDITS OF INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION AND OTHER NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS".

GRANTS ARE MONITORED BY VARIOUS AREAS. FINANCIAL AID GRANTS ARE MONITORED BY THE FINANCIAL AID DIRECTOR TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH ELIGIBILITY, SELECTION, AND DISTRIBUTION. DOCUMENTATION IS MAINTAINED AND AUDITED ANNUALLY. OTHER DEPARTMENT GRANTS ARE MONITORED BY THE RESPONSIBLE PARTY TO ENSURE THAT EXPENDITURES COMPLY WITH GRANT REQUIREMENTS AND ARE NOT DIVERTED FOR OTHER USES.

THE INSTITUTION AWARDS GRANTS TO STUDENTS BASED ON CRITERIA SET FORTH IN THE INDIVIDUAL SCHOLARSHIPS. THIS CRITERIA IS EXPLAINED IN THE 2013-14 COLLEGE CATALOG BEGINNING ON PAGE 38. ANY "NEED BASED" GRANT IS BASED ON THE INFORMATION OBTAINED FROM THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA).
Grants received are applied directly to student tuition invoices. The grants are used to gap the bridge between financial aid and the full amount of tuition due from the students.

ALL INSTITUTIONAL MONEY, GRANTS, ETC. FOLLOW THE FINANCIAL AID MATRIX THAT WAS DESIGNED AND APPROVED BY THE PRESIDENT'S CABINET, OR IF MONEY WAS DONATED FOR SPECIFIC PURPOSES, BY THE WISHES OF THE INDIVIDUAL DONOR.

SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2: GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE REPRESENT STUDENT FINANCIAL AID. WHEN AWARDIng AID, CHAPMAN UNIVERSITY FOLLOWS ALL LAWS AND REGULATIONS OF FEDERAL AND STATE OF CALIFORNIA AID PROGRAMS. FOR MORE INFORMATION, VISIT OUR WEBSITE AT WWW.CHAPMAN.EDU.

Subrecipient grants - Vanderbilt University maintains a formal policy defining its procedures for monitoring the use of sponsored funds by subrecipients who are performing a portion of a sponsored project externally awarded to Vanderbilt. The policy provides guidance to ensure that subrecipients conduct their portions of sponsored projects in compliance with laws, regulations, terms and conditions of awards and subawards, and that reimbursed costs incurred by subrecipients are allowed. The policy addresses the roles and responsibilities of central offices and academic departments of the University and describes the monitoring procedures for each area. The full text of Vanderbilt's subrecipient policy is available online at the following web address: http://www.vanderbilt.edu/ocga/vupolicies/subrecipient /SubrecipientMonitoringGuidelinesfinal.pdf Other Assistance - Assistance offered from institutional funds by Vanderbilt to our students is awarded on the basis of merit and/or financial need. Such assistance helps students and their families support the cost of attendance which includes tuition, mandatory fees, room & board, books, other course materials/supplies, and allowances for personal/miscellaneous and travel expenses. Merit-based awards are competitively awarded in recognition of academic achievement, leadership, commitment to community service, contributions to society, and other forms of accomplishment. Need-based assistance is awarded on the basis of documented financial need, resulting from a need analysis evaluation accomplished in accordance with relevant and applicable federal, state, and/or institutional programs, policies, and eligibility requirements. Financial Aid - The units responsible for administering student financial aid at Vanderbilt regularly initiate system-generated reviews, as well as other cross-checks on an ad hoc basis. Results from these reviews, along with recurring management reports, are regularly evaluated. Subsequently, follow-up corrective actions are taken when appropriate and potentially include award revisions or cancellations. These provisions are designed to help ensure that student assistance funds are awarded to eligible recipients, in accordance with applicable federal, state, institutional, and other program legislation, as well as relevant internal University policies and operational guidelines/criteria.

A budget based on the grant proposal is entered into the accounting system. Purchases are monitored and approved by the controller and assistant controller. Wages paid are supported by time and effort reports. The grants coordinator reviews grant expenditure reports monthly. Quarterly financial reports are submitted for federal grants.

THE ORGANIZATION ONLY MAKES GRANTS TO OTHER ORGANIZATIONS WHICH ARE ALSO TAX-EXEMPT. INDIVIDUAL SCHOLARSHIP RECIPIENTS ARE SELECTED BY THE UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE ACCORDING TO ITS CRITERIA. IN FISCAL YEAR 2014, 4 MEDICAL SCHOOL STUDENTS WERE CHOSEN FOR $5,000 SCHOLARSHIPS.
We have a scholarship committee that meets regularly and decides on students to receive scholarship based on a combination of need, academic performance, attendance and behavior.

THE GOOD SAMARITAN HOSPITAL OF CINCINNATI, OHIO ("HOSPITAL") PROVIDES GRANTS TO OTHER ORGANIZATIONS AND INDIVIDUALS ON A VERY LIMITED BASIS. IN THOSE INSTANCES, THE DEPARTMENT GRANTING THE FUNDS IS RESPONSIBLE FOR OBTAINING AND STORING ALL NECESSARY INFORMATION FROM THE OTHER ORGANIZATION AND INDIVIDUALS RELATIVE TO HOW THE FUNDS WILL BE SPENT. GENERALLY, GRANTS ARE PROVIDED, ON BEHALF OF HOSPITAL THOUGH TRIHEALTH, INC. ("TRIHEALTH"), A SUPPORTING ORGANIZATION OF HOSPITAL, WHICH PROVIDES ADMINISTRATIVE SUPPORT SERVICES TO HOSPITAL. AS SUCH, TRIHEALTH IS RESPONSIBLE FOR MONITORING THE USE OF HOW THE FUNDS WILL BE SPENT.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS - PART I, LINE 2:
ExplntnTxt: THE MAJORITY OF GRANTS GIVEN TO STUDENTS IN THE UNITED STATES PRIMARILY CONSIST OF NEED-BASED GRANTS. STUDENTS MUST APPLY FOR THESE FINANCIAL AID AWARDS BY COMPLETING TWO FORMS THAT ESTABLISH ELIGIBILITY FOR NEED-BASED AID. THESE ARE STANDARD FORMS USED IN HIGHER EDUCATION FOR THIS PURPOSE: COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIP SERVICE FINANCIAL AID PROFILE AND FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID. SCHOLARSHIPS AND SIMILAR AMOUNTS GIVEN TO STUDENTS AS FINANCIAL AID ARE APPLIED BY THE COLLEGE DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT TO ENSURE THAT THE GRANTS ARE USED FOR THEIR INTENDED PURPOSE. HAMPSHIRE COLLEGE GRANT AID ASSISTANCE IS GENERALLY LIMITED TO THE AMOUNT OF TUITION. THE COLLEGE ALSO OFFERS FINANCIAL AID IN THE FORM OF MERIT-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS. THESE ARE SIMILARLY APPLIED BY THE COLLEGE DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT TO ENSURE THAT THE GRANTS ARE USED FOR THEIR INTENDED PURPOSE AND DO NOT EXCEED THE AMOUNT OF TUITION.
THE COLLEGE REVIEWS AND MAKE SURE ALL STUDENTS RECEIVING GOVERNMENT GRANTS ARE ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE THOSE GRANTS BEFORE DISBURSEMENT OF FUNDS.
Grant funds are credited to student accounts in the form of need-based financial aid that reduce the comprehensive fee.

The College follows federal and state guidelines and internal non-discriminatory guidelines for institutional funding. Institutional funding is based on need, academic qualifications and institutional program needs and is monitored by the financial aid office.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Procedures for Monitoring the use of grant funds in U.S.
ExplntnTxt: The awarding of Financial Aid starts after a student is accepted into Bluffton University. Those students who need financial support have to file an application for Federal Student Aid. Bluffton University offers University funds, state and federal grants and student loans. Need-based financial aid grants are awarded based on the calculations from FAFSA and the resulting financial need of the students. Academic scholarships are determined at the time of acceptance and based off of high school GPA and board scores.

SAINT MARY'S DISTRIBUTES SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON NEED AND MERIT. NEED BASED SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE USING THE INFORMATION FROM THE RESULTS OF THE FAFSA (FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID). MERIT BASED SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BY THE ADMISSIONS OFFICE USING THE INFORMATION FROM THE STUDENT'S OFFICIAL HIGH SCHOOL TRANSCRIPTS AND THE RESULTS OF THE STANDARDIZED TEST (ACT, SAT, ETC.). FOR STUDENTS RECEIVING GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS WITH RENEWAL CONDITIONS, FULFILLMENT OF THOSE CONDITIONS ARE VERIFIED BY THE FINANCIAL AID ADMINISTRATOR PRIOR TO THE AWARD BEING RENEWED (GPA, YEAR OF ATTENDANCE, ETC.)

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: ALL SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED ARE FOR USE TO REDUCE TUITION AND FEES AT WINEBRENNER AND CANNOT BE RECEIVED AS CASH OR USED ELSEWHERE.

THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIP, GRANT, LOAN AND WORK STUDY OPPORTUNITIES TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS. THESE FUNDS ARE OFFERED TO STUDENTS ON AN OBJECTIVE AND NONDISCRIMINATORY BASIS. EACH PROGRAM HAS DIFFERENT CRITERIA AND EACH CASE IS CONSIDERED SEPARATELY. THERE IS A WRITTEN POLICY AND GUIDELINES TO ASSIST STUDENTS AS THEY SEEK THE APPROPRIATE FINANCIAL AID PACKAGE. RECORDS ARE MAINTAINED FOR THE GRANTS AWARDED.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: FORM 990, SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: LAFAYETTE COLLEGE MAINTAINS A POLICY DEFINING ITS PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF SPONSORED FUNDS BY SUB-RECIPIENTS WHO ARE PERFORMING A PORTION OF A SPONSORED PROJECT EXTERNALLY AWARDED TO LAFAYETTE. THIS POLICY PROVIDES GUIDANCE TO ENSURE THAT SUB-RECIPIENTS CONDUCT THEIR PORTION OF SPONSORED PROJECTS IN COMPLIANCE WITH THE LAWS, REGULATIONS, TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF AWARDS AND SUB AWARDS, AND THAT REIMBURSEMENT COSTS INCURRED BY SUB-RECIPIENTS ARE ALLOWED.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: FORM 990, SCHEDULE I, PART III, LINE 1
ExplntnTxt: THE COLLEGE CONSIDERS THE AWARDING OF FINANCIAL AID (PRIMARILY GRANTS, SCHOLARSHIPS, LOANS, AND WORK-STUDY) TO ITS STUDENTS, INCLUDING NON-RESIDENT ALIEN STUDENTS TO BE A US BASED ACTIVITY AS STUDENTS OF THE COLLEGE ARE DEEMED TO BE LIVING IN THE UNITED STATES THROUGHOUT THEIR COMPLETION OF THE COLLEGE'S ACADEMIC CURRICULUM AND SUPPORTING PROGRAMS. THE COLLEGE AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS ON THE BASIS OF MERIT AND/OR FINANCIAL NEED. THE SELECTION CRITERIA IS BASED ON THE CALCULATED EXPECTED FAMILY CONTRIBUTION, WHICH IS DERIVED BY USING COMPLEX FORMULAS INVOLVING FAMILIES' INCOME, ASSETS, AND HOUSEHOLD SIZE INCLUDING, AMONG OTHER FACTORS, DEPENDENTS IN COLLEGE. THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE ADMINISTERS AND MONITORS THESE AWARDS TO HELP ENSURE THAT THESE FUNDS ARE AWARDED TO ELIGIBLE RECIPIENTS IN ACCORDANCE WITH APPLICABLE FEDERAL, STATE, AND OTHER REQUIREMENTS, AS WELL AS RELEVANT INTERNAL COLLEGE POLICIES AND OPERATIONAL GUIDELINES. ACADEMIC PRIZES, AWARDS, FELLOWSHIPS, AND INTERNSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED ON A REVIEW BY THE APPLICABLE ACADEMIC DEPARTMENT. ALL AWARDED SCHOLARSHIPS ARE CREDITED TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT AT THE COLLEGE AND ARE APPLIED TO BILLED CHARGES.

THE THREE AREAS OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE TO STUDENTS ARE LOANS, GRANTS, AND EMPLOYMENT (WORK-STUDY). THESE ARE GENERALLY AWARDED ON THE BASIS OF FINANCIAL NEED, DETERMINED BY AN ANALYSIS OF FAMILY INCOME AND ASSETS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE ANOTHER SOURCE OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE, AWARDED ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, ATHLETICS OR PERFORMING ARTS, COMMUNITY SERVICE OR LEADERSHIP. CRITERIA FOR MERIT BASED AWARDS MAY ALSO INCLUDE A FINANCIAL NEEDS REQUIREMENT. THE UNIVERSITY MONITORS THE AMOUNT ISSUED BY CALCULATING A COST OF ATTENDANCE, ASSESSING AN ESTIMATED FAMILY CONTRIBUTION (EFC), AND DERIVING A LEVEL OF FINANCIAL NEED. ONCE THE AMOUNT OF AID HAS BEEN DETERMINED FOR THE INDIVIDUAL, IT IS DISPERSED TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT AND IS CONTROLLED BY THE BURSAR'S OFFICE. SEVERAL REPORTS/SURVEYS ARE USED ANNUALLY TO MONITOR THE DISTRIBUTION OF GRANT ASSISTANCE; FOR EXAMPLE, FISAP REPORT TO USDE, A-133 AUDIT, FEDERAL IPEDS REPORT, STATE ANNUAL AUDIT, AND VARIOUS SURVEYS THAT TYPICALLY USE INFORMATION FROM THE COMMON DATA SET (CDS).

THE COLLEGE OFFERS SEVERAL SCHOLARSHIP OPPORTUNITIES FOR STUDENTS. THE PRIMARY SCHOLARSHIPS AND THE GUIDELINES FOR QUALIFYING ARE: FOUNDERS SCHOLARSHIPS - THESE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS UPON ACCEPTANCE TO A BACHELOR OF SCIENCE DEGREE PROGRAM AT VAUGHN. TO BE CONSIDERED, APPLICANTS MUST ATTAIN A CUMULATIVE HIGH SCHOOL AVERAGE OF AT LEAST A "B" AND A COMBINED SAT1 SCORE OF AT LEAST 1000. STUDENTS WHO MEET THESE MINIMUM CRITERIAS WILL BE CONSIDERED FOR AWARDS, BASED ON THEIR GRADES AND EXAM SCORES, BY VAUGHN COLLEGE'S SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE. THE AWARDS MAY BE RENEWABLE FOR UP TO FOUR YEARS OF CONSECUTIVE STUDY, PROVIDING THE RECIPIENT MAINTAINS A 3.0 CUMULATIVE GRADE POINT AVERAGE (GPA). BOARD OF TRUSTEES GRANTS - THE BOARD OF TRUSTEE ALLOCATES FUNDS TO BE USED IN AWARDING GRANT-IN-AID ASSISTANCE TO NEW AND CONTINUING STUDENTS. GRANTS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS WHO ARE MATRICULATING ON A FULL OR PART-TIME BASIS IN BACHELOR AND ASSOCIATE DEGREE PROGRAMS. RECIPIENTS ARE SELECTED ON THE BASIS OF THEIR ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE AND FINANCIAL AID STATUS. AWARDS ARE DESIGNATED FOR A SPECIFIC ACADEMIC YEAR AND ARE RENEWABLE EACH SEMESTER BASED ON SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE AND THE AVAILABILITY OF FUNDS. TRANSFER STUDENT SCHOLARSHIP - STUDENTS WHO TRANSFER TO THE COLLEGE HAVING COMPLETED 24 OR MORE CREDITS AT AN ACCREDITED COLLEGE OR UNIVERSITY, AND WHO HAVE ACHIEVED A CUMULATIVE GRADE POINT AVERAGE OF AT LEAST 3.0 (INCLUDING ALL COURSES AT EVERY INSTITUTION ATTENDED) MAY BE AWARDED SCHOLARSHIPS TO TRANSFER. THE AWARDS MAY BE RENEWABLE FOR UP TO THREE YEARS OF CONSECUTIVE STUDY, PROVIDING THE RECIPIENT MAINTAINS A 3.0 CUMULATIVE GPA. ACADEMIC EXCELLENCE SCHOLARSHIPS - ACADEMIC EXCELLENCE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED EACH YEAR TO CONTINUING STUDENTS ON THE BASIS OF OUTSTANDING ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT AND SELECTION FOR ACADEMIC HONORS. THE CRITERIA APPLIED IN DECIDING ELIGIBILITY FOR THESE AWARDS INCLUDE CUMULATIVE GPA AND SATISFACTORY COMPLETION OF AT LEAST TWO SEMESTERS (29 CREDITS/UNITS OR MORE) AS A MATRICULATED STUDENT.

A NUMBER OF COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AVAILABLE TO DEGREE STUDENTS. COMPLETION OF A SCHOLARSHIP APPLICATION FORM IS REQUIRED. FORMS ARE AVAILABLE THROUGH THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. AN APPLICATION MUST BE SUBMITTED 30 DAYS PRIOR TO THE QUARTER FOR WHICH THE SCHOLARSHIP IS BEING REQUESTED.

THE FINANCIAL AID COMMITTEE DETERMINES AND APPROVES ALL AWARDS. ELIGIBILITY FOR A NYTS SCHOLARSHIP IS PRIMARILY BASED ON NEED AND AVAILABILITY OF FUNDS. APPLICANTS MUST BE REGISTERED FOR A MINIMUM OF EIGHT CREDITS PER SEMESTER. A CREDIT FOR THE AWARDED AMOUNT IS APPLIED TO THE RECIPIENTS' ACCOUNT; NO ACTUAL CASH IS AWARDED DIRECTLY TO RECIPIENTS.

STUDENT AID IS GIVEN IN THE FORM OF TUITION REMISSION, WHICH IS APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT. OTHER AID IS GIVEN THROUGH CASH STIPENDS FOR LIVING EXPENSES. THIS AID IS DISBURSED EACH SEMESTER WHEN THE STUDENT ARRIVES. THE STUDENT MUST MAINTAIN SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS IN ALL OF THEIR CLASSES.

Pitzer College awards scholarships only to individual undergraduate students. These scholarships are awarded based upon academic achievement and/or demonstrated financial need. The Financial Aid Office, with the assistance of the Registrar's Office, monitor student enrollment each semester to ensure that students remain qualified for financial aid. The College also awards tuition to dependents of its employees who meet the requirements of the College's Tuition Remission Program. Employee dependent's must be enrolled at one of the undergraduate schools of The Claremont Colleges. Tuition is paid directly to the undergraduate college after grades are submitted to the Human Resources Office as evidence of course completion.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PART I, LINE 2 - PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS
ExplntnTxt: SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS ARE CREDITED TO THE STUDENTS ACCOUNT MAINTAINED WITH OLLU.

HANOVER COLLEGE ONLY AWARDS INSTITUTIONAL AND PRIVATELY FUNDED FINANCIAL AID AWARDS AS ASSISTANCE FOR STUDENTS BASED ON A CASE-BY-CASE BASIS, BASED ON MERIT, NEED AND EXTRACURRICULAR ACTIVITIES. IN DOING SO THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT ADHERES STRICTLY TO ALL FEDERAL AND STATE REGULATIONS AND IS SUBJECT TO THE COMPLIANCE AND INTERNAL CONTROL REQUIREMENTS OF 0MB-A133, IN WHICH THEY FOLLOW ALL APPLICABLE GUIDELINES.

GRANTS ARE AWARDED IN THE FORM OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE TOWARDS THE PAYMENT OF TUITION AND FEES IN WHICH CASE THE GRANT AMOUNTS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT. OTHER GRANTS ARE AWARDED FOR VARIOUS REASONS TO STUDENTS, FACULTY AND STAFF FOR EDUCATIONAL OR WORK RELATED ACTIVITIES. IN THESE CASES EXPENSE VERIFICATION IS REQUIRED IN THE FORM OF RECEIPTS AND OTHER APPROPRIATE DOCUMENTATION.

PART II - THE OFFICE OF THE CHIEF OPERATING OFFICER MONITORS ALL FUNDS ALLOCATED TO EXTERNAL ORGANIZATIONS. PART III- THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES ASSISTANCE IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS THAT ARE ALL APPLIED TO STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS RECEIVABLE BALANCES AT THE BURSAR'S OFFICE.
Hiram College provides financial aid and grants to students. These funds are administered by financial aid professionals.

THE STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS ARE JUDGED BY THE COLLEGE ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED AND OTHER OBJECTIVE STANDARDS. ALL AWARDED FUNDS ARE TREATED AS REDUCTIONS TO TUITION. NO FUNDS ARE DISBURSED TO INDIVIDUALS.

ACADEMIC AWARDS ARE MONITORED AT THE TIME OF ADMISSION. ALL STUDENTS ARE REVIEWED FOR ACADEMIC AWARD ELIGIBILITY. THE SAME CRITERIA IS USED FOR ALL STUDENTS, INTERNATIONAL OR NOT. IF STUDENTS ARE ELIGIBLE THEY ARE NOTIFIED ALONG WITH THEIR OFFER OF ADMISSION. RENEWAL IS BASED, AMONG OTHER THINGS, ON CUMULATIVE GPA, RESIDENTIAL STATUS, ETC. FRANCISCAN INSTITUTE (FI) AWARDS ARE REVIEWED FOR ELIGIBILITY AND AMOUNTS ARE DETERMINED BY FI. ATHLETIC AWARDS ARE IN ADDITION TO ACADEMIC AWARDS AND ARE DETERMINED BASED ON THE SPORT, NCAA STANDARDS, INTERNAL FUNDS AVAILABILITY, AND NEGOTIATIONS BETWEEN THE COACH AND ATHLETE.

Every student who receives financial aid from the University must complete an annual Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) form and make satisfactory academic progress in order to retain their aid. Reviews are also conducted on each student to ensure that their grades, academic standing, and major continue to qualify them for the financial aid. These review processes are conducted annually at the end of the University's spring term, prior to the renewal of financial aid packages for the students.
THE COLLEGE AWARDS AND MONITORS THE SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED IN ACCORDANCE WITH INSTITUTIONAL POLICIES AND PROCEDURES.

THE STUDENTS MUST APPLY FOR THE GRANTS AND MEET THE REQUIREMENTS OF THE VARIOUS GRANTS. THE PROCESS BY WHICH EACH GRANT IS AWARDED AND MONITORED IS FORMALIZED IN A POLICY WHICH IS UPDATED BY THE ASSOCIATE DIRECTOR OF FINANCIAL AID.
MONITORING BY TRUSTEES

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Procedure for Monitoring Use of Grant Funds Inside U.S.
ExplntnTxt: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Washington College awarded $25,032,285 in scholarships for 6/30/14. Washington College offers several types of financial aid to help qualified full-time undergraduate students meet their college expenses. College-sponsored tuition scholarships, tuition grants, work/study, and low-interest loans are available to full-time undergraduate students who demonstrate financial need and who meet the College's admission criteria. In addition to College-sponsored financial aid, eligible students can receive assistance from federal, state, and independent aid programs. Grant and scholarship assistance from all sources is first applied to full-time tuition charges. Grant and scholarship assistance in excess of tuition is then applied to direct college charges for fees, and on campus room and board. The Federal Government makes FFELP funds available to undergraduate students to attend post-secondary institutions. Eligibility is based on financial need, and application is through the normal financial aid application process of Washington College.

INSTITUTIONAL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED AND ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT. ELIGIBILITY IS EVALUATED USING THE FAFSA AS WELL AS SAT AND ACT SCORES FOR NEW INCOMING STUDENTS, OR GPA FOR TRANSFERRING STUDENTS. PAPER COPIES OF THE FAFSA, SAT AND ACT SCORES, AND GPAS ARE KEPT IN PAPER FORMAT FOR ONE YEAR BEFORE BEING STORED PERMANENTLY IN AN ELECTRONIC FORMAT.

THE COLLEGE BASES AWARDS ON FINANCIAL AID BY SEVERAL CRITERIA; MERIT, NEED, PERFORMANCE, EMPLOYEE DISCOUNT, ATHLETIC, FEDERAL FUNDED AND OTHER AID. ONLY STUDENTS CURRENTLY ENROLLED IN CLASSSES ARE AWARDED AID.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE U.S. FUNDS ARE DISTRIBUTED BASED ON NEED AND MERIT. STUDENT AID IS HANDLED BY THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT AND CREDITED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT ACCOUNT. EACH STUDENT APPLIES FOR FINANCIAL AID BY FILLING OUT A FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA). THE AWARD IS BASED ON THE INFORMATION IN THIS APPLICATION. STUDENT CAN ALSO APPLY FOR GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON ELIGIBILITY.

Grant funds are monitored in two areas, depending on the use. Grant funds for financial aid are monitored by the Student Financial Services office, which oversees the awarding and compliance for all financial aid to University students. Grants for research and faculty development are monitored by the Assistant to the VPAA for Finance, Administration & Sponsored Programs. All grants are monitored for compliance and proper reporting by the Business Office of the University, overseen by the Assistant Vice President for Business & Finance and Controller.
Institutional scholarships and grants are monitored by disbursing funds from financial aid to the business office.
Grants, scholarships, loans and work-study funds are awarded to students based on demonstrated financial need using nationally recognized needs analysis standards.

THE ORGANIZATION HAS STUDENTS FILE A FAFSA TO CONSIDER THEM FOR THE NEED BASED AID. NEW STUDENTS GO THROUGH A PROCESS CALLED 'FACULTY REVIEW', WHERE THEIR ACADEMIC RECORDS ARE CAREFULLY EVALUATED BY FACULTY CHAIRS AND PROGRAM DIRECTORS. THEY MAY RECOMMEND OUTSTANDING STUDENTS FOR A MERIT SCHOLARSHIP TO THE SCHOLARSHIP REVIEW TEAM. IN ORDER FOR A GRANTEE TO RECEIVE AN AWARD, THEY MUST BE FULLY ADMITTED AND MAINTAIN ACADEMIC STANDARDS ACCORDING TO OUR STUDENT ACADEMIC PROGRESS (SAP) POLICIES, BE REGISTERED IN CLASSES TAKING A FULL-TIME LOAD, AND NOT HAVE ANY FEDERAL OR STATE AID IN DEFAULT STATUS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2, Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
ExplntnTxt: FINANCIAL AID ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS * COMPLETE THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) ANNUALLY AND AS EARLY AS JANUARY 1 (TEMPLE'S PRIORITY DEADLINE IS MARCH 1) * SIGN STATEMENTS ON THE FAFSA STATING THAT: * YOU ARE NOT IN DEFAULT ON A FEDERAL STUDENT LOAN AND DO NOT OWE MONEY ON A FEDERAL STUDENT GRANT AND * YOU WILL USE FEDERAL STUDENT AID ONLY FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES * COMPLY WITH TEMPLE UNIVERSITY'S SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS STANDARDS * REMAIN IN GOOD STANDING ON EDUCATIONAL LOANS AND GRANTS PER THE NATIONAL STUDENT LOAN DATABASE SYSTEM (NSLDS) * REMAIN ENROLLED AT LEAST PART-TIME PER SEMESTER FOR FEDERAL LOANS (6 CREDITS AS AN UNDERGRADUATE STUDENT AND 4.5 CREDITS AS A GRADUATE STUDENT) * BE ENROLLED IN AN ELIGIBLE DEGREE PROGRAM AT TEMPLE UNIVERSITY * BE A CITIZEN OR ELIGIBLE NON-CITIZEN WITH A VALID SOCIAL SECURITY NUMBER * HAVE A HIGH SCHOOL DIPLOMA * BE REGISTERED FOR THE SELECTIVE SERVICE IF YOU ARE MALE AND 18-25 YEARS OF AGE * COMPLY WITH ANY AND ALL FEDERAL VERIFICATION REQUESTS MADE BY STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES RESEARCH ADMINISTRATION PROCESSING AN AWARD - NEGOTIATION OF SUBAWARD(S) IF THE UNIVERSITY RECEIVES AN AWARD AND A PORTION OF THE ACTIVITY IS TO BE SUB-CONTRACTED TO ANOTHER ENTITY, SPONSORED PROGRAMS ASSISTS THE PI IN DEVELOPMENT OF A SUB-CONTRACT WHICH OUTLINES THE SUB-CONTRACTOR'S ROLE IN MEETING THE REQUIREMENTS OF THE AWARD. SPONSORED PROGRAMS FORWARDS THE SUB-CONTRACT TO THE SUB-CONTRACTOR FOR REVIEW AND SIGNATURE. UPON RETURN OF THE EXECUTED DOCUMENT, THE PI SHOULD COMPLETE A FINANCIAL IMPACT STATEMENT. SPONSORED PROGRAMS FORWARDS THE SUB-CONTRACT AND FINANCIAL IMPACT STATEMENT TO UNIVERSITY COUNSEL, WHERE REVIEW AND APPROPRIATE SIGNATURE(S) AND SEAL (IF NECESSARY) ARE OBTAINED. WHEN THE UNIVERSITY IS THE RECIPIENT OF A SUB-CONTRACT SIMILAR PROCEDURES ARE FOLLOWED.

DESCRIPTION OF ORGANIZATION'S PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANTS THE CHRIST HOSPITAL PROVIDES FUNDING TO COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS THAT SUPPORT THE MISSION OF THE CHRIST HOSPITAL PRIMARILY FOCUSING ON 1) THOSE ORGANIZATIONS THAT EDUCATE THE COMMUNITY ABOUT HEALTH, WELLNESS AND PREVENTION, 2) THOSE INITIATIVES THAT IMPROVE THE HEALTH OF THE COMMUNITY, AND 3) THOSE INITIATIVES THAT ARE FOCUSED ON KEY CLINICAL SERVICE AREAS OF THE CHRIST HOSPITAL (INCLUDING CARDIOVASCULAR, MUSCULOSKELETAL, WOMEN'S HEALTH, PRIMARY CARE, ETC.). PRIOR TO RELEASING FUNDS, THE CHRIST HOSPITAL REVIEWS THE FUNDING RECIPIENT TO ENSURE THE FUNDS WILL BE USED TO FURTHER THE ABOVE STATED FUNDING CRITERIA.

WLC AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS MEETING CERTAIN FINANCIAL NEED TESTS AND ACADEMIC MERIT LEVELS. STUDENTS RECEIVING FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE MUST MEET SPECIFIC CRITERIA SUCH AS ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINE ARTS ABILITIES, FINANCIAL NEED, OR OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS SET BY THE BOARD OF REGENTS OR DONORS OF RESTRICTED OR ENDOWED FUNDS.

SCHEDULE I, PART 1, LINE 1 THE COLLEGE PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS MATRICULATING AT THE COLLEGE. ALL SCHOLARSHIPS ISSUED ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY AGAINST THE STUDENT'S TUITION BALANCE; THEREFORE, THE STUDENT CAN EXERCISE NO DISCRETION IN THE USE OF THE FUNDS. SINCE ALL SCHOLARSHIPS DEFRAY THE COST OF TUITION, NO FURTHER MONITORING OF THE SCHOLARSHIPS IS REQUIRED.

MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS TO ORGANIZATIONS IN THE UNITED STATES: THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID DETERMINES STUDENT ELIGIBILITY AND MAKES AWARDS FOR NEED BASED SCHOLARSHIPS. ACADEMIC DEPARTMENTS DETERMINE ELIGIBILITY AND AWARDS ACADEMIC MERIT BASED SCHOLARSHIPS WITH ASSISTANCE FROM THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID. BOTH OFFICES PERFORM POST AWARD MONITORING TO DETERMINE CONTINUED ELIGIBILITY. THE RESEARCH AND ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICES OFFICE (RAS) PERFORMS SUB-RECIPIENT MONITORING IN ACCORDANCE WITH UNIVERSITY POLICY. RAS AND PRINCIPLE INVESTIGATORS MONITOR STATEMENT OF WORK COMPLETION, PROGRESS REPORTS, DELIVERABLES, CHANGE TO SCOPE AND BUDGETS. THEY ALSO REVIEW AND APROVE SUB-RECIPIENT INVOICES.

Scholarships are awarded based on merit. The Bursar's office monitors the use of such funds to the extent that they are used exclusively for tuition and fees. When scholarships are awarded, the amount disbursed goes directly against the balance a student has with the Bursar's office. With respect to grants received by organizations within the United States, the College requires pass-through reports (attestation of effort) from its subrecipients as outlined in the grant agreement with the subrecipient. The Time and Effort attestation must be approved by the principal investigator of the grant to ensure receipt of work performed.

KILIAN COMMUNITY COLLEGE AWARDS ALL STUDENT SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS ON THE FINANCIAL AID AWARD LETTER. THE BUSINESS OFFICE CREDITS THE STUDENT ACCOUNT WITH THE SCHOLARSHIP. THESE FUNDS ARE THEN USED TO ASSIST WITH TUITION AND FEES ON THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT.

INSTITUTIONAL GRANTS ARE OFFERED BY THE COLLEGE TO ATTRACT AND RETAIN STUDENTS. DISBURSEMENTS ARE MADE IN ACCORDANCE WITH PROCEDURES OR ARE SUBJECT TO CONDITIONS ESTABLISHED BY THE COLLEGE'S GOVERNING BOARD DESIGNED TO ENSURE THAT INDIVIDUALS AND ORGANIZATIONS RECEIVING DISBURSEMENTS FROM THE COLLEGE, IN FURTHERANCE OF ITS EXEMPT PROGRAMS, ARE ADEQUATELY INVESTIGATED TO ENSURE THAT THEY ARE QUALIFYING RECIPIENTS. STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS ARE JUDGED WORTHY BY THE COLLEGE'S ASSESSMENT ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED, AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS.

SCHOLARSHIPS & GRANTS ARE PROVIDED BASED THE COLLEGE'S ASSESSMENT OF THE RECIPIENTS ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED, AND OTHER STANDARDS ESTABLISHED BY THE COLLEGE. APPLICATIONS ARE REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT.

The College provides scholarships and financial aids to students based on need and academic performance. The funds are credited directly to the student's account. Records are maintained in accordance with College's policies. The College's finanical aid office adheres strictly to all federal and state regulations and is subject to the compliance and internal controls of OMB A-133.
All grants are issued through the UDM Financial Aid office. The FA counselors communicate with students and monitor students' status and educational programs.

THE GRANTS MADE BY THE UNIVERSITY ARE PRIMARILY FOR STUDENT AID AND SCHOLARSHIPS. A LIST OF RECIPIENTS OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS IS ON FILE AT THE UNIVERSITY AND IS AVAILABLE UPON REQUEST. ALL STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS ARE JUDGED WORTHY BY THE UNIVERSITY ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC AND ATHLETIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED, AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2, Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
ExplntnTxt: THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE DETERMINES IF A STUDENT IS ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE A SCHOLARSHIP FROM THE UNIVERSITY AND, IF ELIGIBLE, WILL APPLY THE APPROVED SCHOLARSHIP PAYMENT TO THE RESPECTIVE STUDENTS TUITION ACCOUNT. NO CHECKS ARE ISSUED TO THE STUDENTS DIRECTLY. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MONITORS THE USE OF THE FUNDS TO ENSURE THEY ARE USED FOR THEIR INTENDED PURPOSE.
SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS ARE ADMINISTERED AND MONITORED BY THE UNIVERSITY.

SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 Scholarships and fellowships are awarded by Queens University of Charlotte to students based on their academic achievement, talent in the fine arts, and participation in intercollegiate athletics. The awards are based on their performance levels. Students are also awarded need-based scholarships and grants based on their need as established by completing the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) and, if applicable, by specific criteria and guidelines for other federal and state programs.

THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIP ASSISTANCE TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS THROUGH THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID. THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID MONITORS THE APPROPRIATENESS OF THE AWARDS AND THESE AMOUNTS ARE APPLIED TO EACH STUDENT'S ACCOUNT.
THE COLLEGE AWARDS FINANCIAL AID PRIMARILY BASED UPON ACADEMIC MERIT. THE FUNDS ARE AWARDED VIA ADHERENCE TO A MATRIX WHICH DETERMINES THE AMOUNTS BASED UPON GRADE POINT AVERAGE AND SAT SCORES.
Students receiving Scholarships and fellowships are judged worthy by the institution's assessment on the basis of academic achievement, financial need and other similar standards.

THE COLLEGE HAS A FINANCIAL AID OFFICE WITH THE NECESSARY STAFF, POLICIES AND PROCEDURES TO ENSURE THAT THE COLLEGE ADHERES TO AND COMPLIES WITH FEDERAL REGULATIONS REGARDING ELIGIBILITY FOR STUDENT FINANCIAL AID. THE COLLEGE ALSO HAS ADEQUATE STAFFING IN ITS OTHER GRANT PROGRAMS WITH ELIGIBILITY GUIDELINES TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE. THE COLLEGE ALSO UNDERGOES THE REQUIRED OMB CIRCULAR A-133 AUDITS.

The University monitors it grants to ensure such grants are used for proper purposes and are not otherwise diverted from the intended use by having the Enrollment Services Office provide the Financial Aid Office with a weekly report identifying any financial aid refunds to students. This process ensures that all grants and scholarships are being applied and used for their intended purpose. All financial aid is electronically posted to each students account by the bursar.

INDIVIDUALS: GRANT FUNDS AWARDED TO STUDENTS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THEIR STUDENT ACCOUNTS. USAGE IS MONITORED BY VIRTUE OF DIRECT ACCOUNT POSTING. ELIGIBILITY AND AWARDING OF THE GRANTS IF DETERMINED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. ORGANIZATIONS: ACCOUNTS PAYABLE DEPARTMENT MAINTAINS THE DOCUMENTATION FOR THE AMOUNT PROVIDED TO ORGANIZATIONS. SELECTION OF THE ORGANIZATION AND THE AMOUNT IS DETERMINED BY A MEMBER OF SENIOR STAFF (PRESIDENT OR CFO).

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MONITOR THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE U.S.
ExplntnTxt: PART I, LINE 2 ALL GRANTS AWARDED ARE BASED ON NEED AND/OR MERIT AND CONFORM TO FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITUTIONAL REGULATIONS. ELIGIBILITY IS BASED ON A THOROUGH REVIEW AND VERIFICATION OF A FAMILY'S INCOME, ASSETS, SIZE AND NUMBER OF DEPENDENTS ENROLLED IN COLLEGE. ANNUAL EXPENDITURE REPORTS ARE SUBMITTED TO THE FEDERAL AND STATE GOVERNMENTS FOR REVIEW. THE FUND EXPENDITURES ARE REVIEWED FOR COMPLIANCE IN AN ANNUAL AUDIT CONDUCTED BY AN INDEPENDENT ACCOUNTING FIRM. THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDED FINANCIAL SUPPORT TO BOSTON REDEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY, AS PART OF THE CITY OF BOSTON, WHICH ASSISTS THE ORGANIZATION TO DEVELOP DOWNTOWN BOSTON AND SURROUNDING NEIGHBORHOODS PURSUANT TO COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT. THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDED FINANCIAL SUPPORT TO CAMBRIDGE STREET DEVELOPMENT CORP, A 501(C)(3) ORGANIZATION WHICH ASSISTS THE ORGANIZATION TO DEVELOP THE CAMBRIDGE STREET AREA OF THE CITY OF BOSTON. THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDED FINANCIAL SUPPORT TO THE WASHINGTON CENTER FOR INTERNSHIPS AND ACADEMIC SEMINARS, A 501(C)(3) ORGANIZATION WHICH ASSISTS THE ORGANIZATION IN PROVIDING INTERNSHIP OPPORTUNITIES FOR SELECTED STUDENTS.

THE COLLEGE PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS ENROLLED IN ITS PROGRAMS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED ON STUDENT ACHIEVEMENTS IN ACADEMICS, PERFORMING ARTS, AND ATHLETICS. TO BE CONSIDERED FOR SCHOLARSHIP ASSISTANCE, STUDENTS MUST APPLY FOR ADMISSION, SUBMIT ACADEMIC TRANSCIPTS OF PRIOR EDUCATIONAL WORK, SUBMIT TEST SCORES (ACT/SAT), AND SUBMIT AN APPLICATION FOR THE SCHOLARSHIP PROGRAM. SOME SCHOLARSHIPS REQUIRE ADDITIONAL RECOMMENDATIONS OR CERTIFICATIONS BY THIRD PARTIES. ACADEMIC PROGRESS OF SCHOLARSHIP RECIPIENTS IS MONITERED, AND THEY MUST EARN A MINIMUM AMOUNT OF COLLEGE CREDITS AND A MINIMUM GPA EACH SEMESTER IN ORDER TO MAINTAIN ELIGIBILITY.

The College's Financial Aid Office monitors all recipients of scholarships awards to determine both initial and continuing eligibility based upon the criteria for the type of award. Various criteria may include, but is not limited to, academic performance, financial need, or other criteria established by donors of scholarship funds.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS - PART I, LINE 2:
ExplntnTxt: All scholarships and grants are based on financial need or academic merit. Individuals receiving distributions from the University are chosen based upon objective and non-discriminatory criteria which are consistent with the overall tax-exempt purpose of the University. Scholarships are either applied to students' individual accounts at Denison, or sent directly to the off-campus program within the United States at which the student is studying.

TO ENSURE OUR GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE USED FOR THE PROPER PURPOSES THE EDGEWOOD COLLEGE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE PERFORMS REGULAR MAINTENANCE AND RECONCILIATIONS WITH OUR BUSINESS OFFICE MONITORING THAT ALL FUNDS AWARDED TO A PARTICULAR STUDENT ARE BEING PROPERLY CREDITED TO THEIR STUDENT ACCOUNT. ANY CHANGES OR ADJUSTMENTS TO ORIGINAL AWARDS THAT AFFECT GRANT AND SCHOLARSHIP FUNDING ARE MADE WITHIN POWERFAIDS, THE FINANCIAL AID SOFTWARE PROGRAM. THESE CHANGES TO AWARDS ARE ELECTRONICALLY TRANSMITTED AT LEAST WEEKLY TO THE BUSINESS OFFICE. THE RESULTING CHANGES ARE THEN DISPLAYED ON THEIR STUDENT ACCOUNT. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE HAS THE ABILITY TO GENERATE REPORTS AS NEEDED FOR MONITORING AND RECONCILIATION PURPOSES. THESE REPORTS ARE COMPARED TO REPORTS GENERATED BY THE BUSINESS OFFICE TO ENSURE THAT ALL PROGRAM AMOUNTS ARE ACCURATELY REFLECTED. ADDITIONALLY, WE HAVE A YEARLY AUDIT PERFORMED BY AN OUTSIDE ACCOUNTING FIRM GUARANTEEING WE ARE STAYING IN COMPLIANCE WITH ALL FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITUTIONAL POLICIES AND PROCEDURES AS WELL AS ASSURING FUNDING IS BEING USED AS INTENDED.

All students seeking need based financial assistance are required to complete the FAFSA. Eligibility, or need, is determined through federal methodology and resulting Expected Family Contribution as set against standard cost of attendance. Need based aid is awarded based on federal and/or state eligibility requirements and institutional aid is awarded according to institutional policy. Amounts of aid awarded are in compliance with governing regulations or institutional policy. In compliance with Title IV regulations, total aid from all sources cannot exceed need or the annual cost of attendance, regardless of the level of need. Aid awards are posted to student accounts as an offset to semester charges. Institutional policy prohibits the release or refund of aid to students unless total charges for the semester have been paid.

SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED THROUGH THE FINANCIAL AID AND ADMISSION OFFICES. ANNUAL REVIEW OF QUALIFICATIONS FOR EACH LEVEL OF SCHOLARSHIPS IS DONE AFTER THE SPRING TERM. SATISFACTORY PROGRESS GUIDELINES FROM THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION ARE FOLLOWED FOR ALL STUDENTS RECEIVING ANY TYPE OF SCHOLARSHIP AID. OUR ADVANCEMENT OFFICE ASSIGNS ENDOWED SCHOLARSHIPS. ENDOWED SCHOLARSHIPS (FUNDED INSTITUTIONAL AID) REPRESENTS LESS THAN 20% OF OUR AWARDED SCHOLARSHIPS.

THE COLLEGE SUPPORTS A NEED BASED FINANCIAL AID POLICY THAT IS REPRESENTATIVE OF ITS ACADEMIC AND SPIRITUAL GOALS AS AN UNDERGRADUATE, JESUIT LIBERAL ARTS COLLEGE. THE COLLEGE ACCEPTS STUDENTS REGARDLESS OF THEIR ABILITY TO PAY NEED-BLIND ADMISSIONS AND THEN MEETS 100 OF THEIR NEED, AS CALCULATED ACCORDING TO NATIONALLY RECOGNIZED FINANCIAL AID CRITERIA. THE COLLEGE USES A CONSERVATIVE NEEDS ANALYSIS, INSTITUTIONAL METHODOLOGY WHICH IS AGREED UPON BY MORE THAN 2,000 MEMBERS OF THE COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIP SERVICE ASSEMBLY. THE FINANCIAL AID PROGRAM IS GENEROUS AND ALL STUDENTS ARE ENCOURAGED TO APPLY REGARDLESS OF THEIR SOCIO-ECONOMIC BACKGROUND. APPROXIMATELY SIXTY-ONE PERCENT OF ALL STUDENTS RECEIVE SOME FORM OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE. A LIST OF RECIPIENTS WHO RECEIVE FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE IS MAINTAINED BY THE COLLEGE. THERE MAY BE SOME RECIPIENTS WHO ARE RELATED TO OFFICERS, TRUSTEES, OR OTHER DISQUALIFIED PERSONS SUCH RECIPIENTS ARE SELECTED ON AN EQUAL OBJECTIVELY DETERMINED BASIS WITH OTHERS. THE COLLEGE PROVIDES GRANTS TO CERTAIN CHARITABLE ORGANIZATIONS WITHIN THE WORCESTER, MA AREA. THESE GRANTS ARE CLOSELY TIED TO PROMOTING THE COLLEGES CHARITABLE AND EDUCATIONAL MISSION AND CONTRIBUTE TO THE ENRICHMENT OF THE GREATER WORCESTER AREA. SINCE THESE GRANTS ARE MADE TO CHARITIES, THE COLLEGE DOES NOT MONITOR THE USE OF THE GRANT FUNDS.

Every full-time traditional undergraduate student is considered for merit-based financial aid. Merit-based aid is determined by the Admissions and Financial aid department's analysis of a student's academic credentials, such as standardized test scores and high school transcripts. A student interested in receiving need-based financial aid is required to submit a Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FASFA) for each school year. Once all the eligibility criteria are met and all necessary documents are obtained, either through review of the ISIR or by efforts of the financial aid counselor, the financial need of the student is determined by the difference between the cost of attendance at Xavier and the EFC toward those costs. After the financial need for the student is calculated the financial aid package for each student is determined by the Banner system based on the student's financial need, academic merit, talent, enrollment status, level in school, and dependency status. Award letters (via e-mail or regular mail) are then prepared and sent to each student, notifying them of what types of awards they are deemed eligible to receive. The student then has the option to decline any aid that is offered to them. Xavier uses passive acceptance of aid offered.

GRANT FUNDING IS AWARDED TO STUDENTS BY STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES WITHIN ESTABLISHED BUDGET LEVELS BASED ON UNIVERSITY POLICIES. GRANT FUNDS ARE CREDITED TO INDIVIDUAL STUDENT ACCOUNTS ELECTRONICALLY. STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES WORKS WITH ADVANCEMENT STAFF TO ENSURE THAT RESTRICTED FUNDS ARE AWARDED WITHIN ESTABLISHED CRITERIA, AND WITH FINANCE STAFF TO DETERMINE AVAILABILITY OF FUNDS. STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES MAINTAINS INTERNAL POLICIES AND PROCEDURES FOR THE CORRECT AWARDING AND ADJUSTING OF INSTITUTIONAL FUNDS. ANNUAL AUDITS ARE CONDUCTED TO ASSURE COMPLIANCE WITH ALL POLICIES AND PROCEDURES. NORTHEASTERN UNIVERSITY (NU) HAS A FULL TIME EMPLOYEE TO MONITOR SUBAWARDS. - NU FOLLOWS FEDERAL REGULATIONS AS PART OF THE SUBRECIPIENT MONITORING UNDER A-133. - NU REVIEWS THE FEDERAL AUDIT CLEARINGHOUSE AND INSTITUTION'S A-133 REPORTS. - DESK REVIEWS ARE PERFORMED, AND PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATORS APPROVE ALL INVOICES.

procedures for monitoring the use of grant funds in the U.S.: Jefferson HOSPITAL ASSOCIATION, INC. MAINTAINED RECORDS TO SUBSTANTIATE THE AMOUNT OF THE GRANTS OR ASSISTANCE, THE GRANTEES' ELIGIBILITY FOR THE GRANTS OR ASSISTANCE, AND THE SELECTION CRITERIA USED TO AWARD GRANTS OR ASSISTANCE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: form 990, part ix, line 1 & schedule i, part ii, line 1
ExplntnTxt: Difference between schedule i & statement of functional expenses: THE ORGANIZATION IS REPORTING THE CONTRIBUTIONS PAID ON SCHEDULE I, WHICH IS NOT NECESSARILY ON THE ACCRUAL BASIS BECAUSE THE ORGANIZATION RECORDS LONG-TERM PLEDGES AT THEIR NPV AND RECORDS ACCRETION OF INTEREST OVER TIME. THE PLEDGES, WHEN PAID, ARE A REDUCTION OF THIS LIABILITY AND NOT CURRENT YEAR EXPENSE WHICH MAY CAUSE A DIFFERENCE BETWEEN AMOUNT REPORTED ON FORM 990, PAGE 10 AND SCHEDULE I, PART II.

Disbursements in furtherance of the institution's exempt programs are made in accordance with procedures or subject to conditions established by the institutions governing board designed to insure that individuals and organizations receiving disbursements from the institution in furtherance of its exempt purpose are adequately investigated to insure that they are qualifying recipients. Students receiving scholarships and fellowships are judged worthy by the institution on the basis of criteria such as academic achievement (fellowships) and financial need (scholarships and fellowships).

THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE PROCESSES FINANCIAL AID REQUESTS. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICERS FIRST DETERMINE THE AMOUNT OF FEDERAL AND STATE STUDENT AID THAT THE STUDENT WILL RECEIVE. STUDENTS ARE THEN AWARDED SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON THEIR AVAILABLE RESOURCES AND OUTSTANDING CHARGES.
THE UNIVERSITY MAINTAINS ITS CONTRIBUTIONS TO OTHER 501(C)(3) ORGANIZATIONS IN A SEPARATE GENERAL LEDGER ACCOUNT.

SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS ARE DETERMINED BY PROGRAM COMMITTEES AND ARE RECORDED ON STUDENT LEDGERS. EACH PROGRAM SELECTS ITS INTERNAL SCHOLARSHIP AWARDEES, SUBJECT TO REVIEW BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AWARDS SDS SCHOLARSHIPS. THE UNIVERSITY ACCOUNTING OFFICE MAINTAINS RECORDS OF AMOUNTS AWARDED AND DISBURSED.

Grants and scholarships are awarded in accordance with federal, state & private donor requirements. Students eligibility is monitored on a semester to semester basis. All records documenting the awarding, eligibility & monitoring of students' grants and scholarships is maintained within the financial aid office.

A LIST OF RECIPIENTS OF SCHOLARSHIPS IS ON FILE AT THE COLLEGE. THE RECIPIENTS ARE SELECTED ON AN EQUAL, OBJECTIVELY DETERMINABLE BASIS WITH OTHER RECIPIENTS. THAT IS, ALL STUDENTS RECEIVING SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS ARE JUDGED WORTHY BY THE COLLEGE'S ASSESSMENT ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED, AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS ESTABLISHED BY THE COLLEGE COMMITTEES THAT JUDGE THE APPLICANTS. THE COLLEGE HAS PROCEDURES THAT ARE DESIGNED TO ENSURE THAT INDIVIDUALS FROM THE COLLEGE QUALIFY TO RECEIVE PAYMENTS. THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE ENSURES THAT GRANTS AND AWARDS ARE IN COMPLIANCE WITH PROCEDURES ESTABLISHED BY THE COLLEGE.

THE COLLEGE COMPLIES WITH THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION POLICY REGARDING TITLE IV FUNDS. THE COLLEGE HAS DEDICATED INDIVIDUALS PERFORM THE WORK OUTLINED IN THE SCOPE OF THE GRANT WHO WORK TO ENSURE PROPER STEWARDSHIP OF FUNDS. THESE INDIVIDUALS FOLLOW THE STATUTORY AND REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS SET FORTH IN THE GRANT. FUNDS ARE DRAWN AFTER EXPENSES ARE INCURRED. PROGRESS REPORTS ARE SUBMITTED IN COMPLIANCE WITH THE GRANT REQUIREMENTS AND APPROPRIATE DOCUMENTATION IS MAINTAINED.

THE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARED TO ECHN EMPLOYEES WISHING TO FURTHER THEIR NURSING EDUCATION OR BECOME A NURSE. THE PRIMARY PURPOSE IS TO PROVIDE FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE TO ECHN EMPLOYEES ENROLLED IN AN ACCREDITED NURSING PROGRAM THAT LEADS TO BECOMING A REGISTERED NURSE. FURTHERMORE, A PORTION OF THE FUNDS MAY BE AWARDED TO AN ECHN REGISTERED NURSE TO ASSIST THAT PERSON IN OBTAINING AN ADVANCED DEGREE. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED ON THE DETERMINATION OF A NURSING SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE. NURSING STUDENTS WHO NEED FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE TO COMPLETE THEIR EDUCATION AND WHO DEMONSTRATE SCHOLASTIC ABILITY AND PROFESSIONAL PROMISE ARE ELIGIBLE IF THEY ARE AN EMPLOYEE OF AN ECHN AFFILIATE, AT LEAST 20 HOURS PART-TIME OR FULL-TIME, FOR AT LEAST ONE YEAR; AND CURRENTLY ENROLLED IN AN ACCREDITED TRADITIONAL OR NON-TRADITIONAL NURSING PROGRAM. BACCALAUREATE APPLICANTS MUST HAVE COMPLETED THE 2ND YEAR OF A 4-YEAR PROGRAM AND ASSOCIATE DEGREE APPLICANTS MUST HAVE COMPLETED ALL PREREQUISITES AND BE ACCEPTED INTO A NURSING PROGRAM. IN MAKING THE AWARDS, THE COMMITTEE USES JOB PERFORMANCE EVALUATION AND RECOMMENDATION, GRADE POINT AVERAGE AND PROFESSIONAL GOALS. IN ADDITION, THE NUMBER OF CREDITS IN WHICH AN APPLICANT IS ENROLLED AND THE COST PER CREDIT IS FACTORED INTO ANY AWARD. IF AWARDED A SCHOLARSHIP, THE RECIPIENT AGREES TO MAINTAIN EMPLOYMENT, WHETHER FULL OR PART-TIME, AT AN AFFILIATE OF ECHN FOR A MINIMUM OF ONE YEAR. AWARDS ARE MAILED DIRECTLY TO THE EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION.
